**Garbage in, garbage out**
Charging families for each bag of rubbish they throw away seems like a good idea for the environment and for money. But it might not be. In many developed countries, people have a regular service to collect their rubbish. Rubbish bags or bins are taken away by a special truck to a dump. This service is usually free. Families pay for it through local taxes, but a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that throws away very little. 
However, collecting rubbish is not free. The more rubbish people throw away, the more trucks and workers are needed. This costs local governments more money. If rubbish disposal is free, people will throw away too much rubbish. A solution is to make families pay for the rubbish they throw away. This could encourage them to throw away less and recycle more, if local governments help with recycling.
Two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, studied this idea in some American towns. They looked at a system where families had to buy stickers to put on their rubbish bags. Only bags with stickers would be picked up. In Charlottesville, Virginia, families paid 80 cents for each sticker. This seemed like a good idea, but the costs of running the program were higher than the money made from the stickers. 
The number of bags thrown away did go down by 37%. But many people just packed more rubbish into each bag instead of buying more stickers. This is not as good as using machines to compact rubbish at dumps. The total weight of rubbish collected only fell by 14%. In other towns without this sticker system, the weight of rubbish also fell, but by only 3.5%. 
Some people even started to dump their rubbish illegally instead of paying for collection. This illegal dumping might be responsible for 30-40% of the drop in collected rubbish. On a positive note, recycling increased by 15%, which means people chose to recycle instead of paying for rubbish collection. But many people were already recycling before the sticker system started.
In a later study, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked at rubbish in more detail. They found that charging for rubbish does reduce the amount thrown away, but not by much. For example, if sticker prices go up by 10%, the amount of rubbish only goes down by 0.3%. This is less than in other studies. To throw away much less rubbish, people would need to buy less of everything. A small fee for rubbish is not likely to change much.
It is also important to think about other factors like income and education. In richer towns, people throw away more rubbish and have less time to recycle. So, is charging families for rubbish a bad idea? Not really, because free disposal is too cheap. But simple ideas can have complicated results. We often need detailed studies to understand them, and sometimes the results are not good.

**Work and Change**
Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life could change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at your job? Success in a career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their work is not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy despite their success. 
Loving your job used to be enough to be admired, but now you should think about how your job affects you as a person. This is an important question. If your skills make you boring and you cannot talk to others outside your job, then no amount of money or status will make you happy. 
I want to find out how work can help us feel fulfilled and happy, instead of just making us work for companies. Work should not just be about making money; it should help us live better lives and discover new talents. 
However, just creating more jobs is not enough. As people learn more, they want jobs that are interesting and meaningful. Work should be seen as a beautiful journey, with happy people at its center. Even jobs that used to be exciting, like being a doctor or an architect, can now be very stressful. Many workers feel unhappy and unfulfilled.
I am studying different jobs to see how they affect people. I want to understand what makes us happy, loved, and respected. I am now looking for better ways to earn a living. Many experts focus on making companies richer, but we also need to think about ourselves as people and who we want to work with.
How many of us feel truly alive at work? Many people feel like they are stuck in their jobs, unable to leave because of their skills and careers. For example, many hotel workers are smart and lively but have low pay and long hours. Hotels could be more than just places to sleep; they could be cultural centers where people from different countries meet and share experiences.
Hotel workers often do not have deep connections with guests. If hotels listened to their staff's dreams, they could offer many more services. But often, they focus only on making money. 
It is time to think about work in a new way. Work is about relationships. Many people want to feel independent at work and should be able to create their own jobs and choose their colleagues. This means they need to learn to talk to people from different backgrounds.
Good communication is important, but it is not the same as real conversation. Real conversation helps us understand each other better and creates respect. When we have these meaningful conversations, we can change the world, even if just a little bit.

**BROADCASTING: How Technology Affects Society**
The word 'broadcasting' originally meant to spread seeds widely by hand. This idea is not just about farming; it also represents hope for growth and success. It suggests that if we plan well, we can have a good outcome. The idea of broadcasting assumes that there are resources available to help spread information.
We need to think about why a new technology that sends words and pictures electronically was set up in a way that fits this farming idea. Television, which is a technology for communication, is connected to other forms of communication like the telegraph and telephone. However, from the beginning, television was seen as a way to reach many people at once from a central place. This way of broadcasting matched the social and economic structures of modern societies.
There were some attempts to create different ways of using television. In the early 1930s, radio enthusiasts in Britain tried to make two-way television, which could replace regular telephones. Many science magazines wrote about how to build television equipment, and many people experimented with it. But in 1938, big companies made rules for television that pushed these amateur efforts aside. This meant that the chance for a more equal and community-based form of television was lost in Britain.
Broadcasting was not only about money; it was also connected to the structure of modern societies. In the early 1930s, television was mostly used for public shows in the USA and was seen as competition for movies. Many people watched television in public places, especially in Britain and Germany.
The idea of community-based television was not successful. Instead, companies saw a chance to sell television sets to homes. As working-class people began to earn more money in the 1920s, having a home with entertainment became possible for many people in Western countries. Now, this is happening all over the world.
There is a clear link between social changes and how broadcasting is organized. As societies modernized, power and money became more centralized, and traditional communities broke apart. People became more mobile, which made them feel more isolated compared to earlier, stable communities. Centralized broadcasting helped governments share important information with all citizens and created a sense of community in the nation.
However, broadcasting can also be seen positively as a way to support democracy. During the time between the World Wars, many countries recognized the importance of broadcasting for giving everyone equal access to information needed for participating in society.
Television is changing now, and the term 'broadcasting' may not fit as well as before. In the future, it might only refer to a specific way of using audio-visual technology during a certain time of social change.

**Clutter**
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you still do not feel safe. It is normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes we want too many things. Advertisements make us feel insecure. They often tell us that if we do not have certain things, we are not good enough. 
To see how much advertisements affect you, try not to look at any ads when you walk down the street. We see many ads on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, and the internet. All of these tell us to buy more things.
**Caves**
Many researchers and universities study caves. They look at where caves come from, how water moves in them, and the plants and animals that live there. Caves are small but interesting parts of nature. They make us curious and want to learn more. Because caves are important, many people study them, especially in places where caves affect our lives. 
However, visiting caves can be hard for some people. This means that many cave studies are done by both scientists and people who visit caves for fun.
**Weather Watch**
Many people have watched the weather for a long time without any special tools. This helped create the science of meteorology, which studies the weather. Since the 17th century, this science has become very advanced. Now, we use satellites and electronic tools to get weather information quickly. Computers can solve complex math problems much faster than people can.
Meteorology uses many difficult words that are hard to understand. But human experience is still very important for making weather forecasts. What people observe can help scientists understand the weather better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**
Not long ago, I thought that opera was mainly theatre. Now, I think differently. After working at a national opera house, I learned that music is the most important part of opera. This is how it should be. But I come from the world of theatre, where words and actors are very important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once it starts, and the audience usually understands the language of the actors.
At music performances, like concerts or operas, many people do not know much about music. Some feel embarrassed about this. Most people are amazed by the talent of the musicians. A great singer or a good orchestra is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows us years of hard work. Watching great music is like watching a sports match. We know athletes do something similar to what we do when we run, but they do it much better.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often do not understand how hard acting is and may not be impressed by an actor's long speech. They often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" This does not mean theatre audiences are less demanding than music audiences. Many people enjoy both theatre and music. In theatre, audiences and performers are more equal, no matter how difficult the play is.
Does music need to learn from theatre? I think yes. I have seen how a different approach can make the experience better for concert-goers. Live music is very emotional and can connect with the audience. However, the way music is often presented, with strict dress codes and a focus on conductors and soloists, can make it feel like there is a big difference between the performers and the audience.
Sometimes, music audiences clap between songs or after a great performance. This is a way to show appreciation, but it can also interrupt the flow of the music. 
Many people are working to bring new audiences to concerts and operas. They want to make people feel that "serious" music is for everyone. I remember a special event called "In Search of Angels," where the performance moved from a cathedral to the town. It was a wonderful experience, and many audience members felt they were part of it.
I wish music could be more adventurous like the best theatre. Sometimes, using unusual places for performances can surprise both performers and audiences. It might not be comfortable, and the sound might not be perfect, but theatre audiences are used to following artists into different spaces. 
I know that many plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. However, I believe that music performances can change for the better. I love both theatre and music, and I want more people to enjoy them like I do.

**Sand**  
I think sand is amazing because it can be changed into useful things like glass and concrete. But I do not like it when it is on the beach. To me, sand is a problem. It gets in my face, my food, and it can even take my car keys and coins. When I am wet, sand sticks to me and is hard to wash off, even with a strong hose. But when I step on a towel, get in a car, or walk on a clean carpet, the sand falls off easily. For days, I find sand everywhere when I take off my shoes and socks. Sand stays with you for a long time. I would rather not have sand at all.
**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home. A long time ago, they used simple locks, but now we have electronic locks that use cards. However, many people still prefer to use a real key. They feel safer when they can turn a key in a lock. One company made a new electronic lock but included a real metal key because people like that better.
**Modern Art**  
I was nervous to visit the new Tate Modern gallery because I do not understand modern art very well. I like some pieces, especially furry things, bright light sculptures, and big photos. I think if I knew more about art, I would have more opinions. But art is not just about understanding; it is about feeling something. This gallery tries to help visitors understand the art better. I noticed that they have good labels that explain what the art is about. These labels helped me understand the art instead of just looking at it without knowing what it means.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
**Making Movies from Books**  
When a book is made into a movie, many parts of the story are often cut out. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help them see things in a new way. While writing a movie script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of the dialogue and descriptions from the book and still tell the same story. This does not mean that the original words were not important. It is about how people pay attention to stories in books and movies. In a book, some things are repeated to help readers remember characters and their traits. For example, we often see phrases like "he said" to show who is talking. This makes it easier to read. In plays, the dialogue often sounds like real conversations, but sometimes it can be too much and not clear.
**Watching Movies**  
When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the story. It takes us away from our everyday lives for a while. But when the movie ends and the lights come on, we are back in the real world. Some people think that watching movies is just for fun and not real art. Many older people, like our parents and teachers, enjoyed movies but did not see them as serious art.
**The Film Studios**  
The Leiper Film Company studios were made up of many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because there were many small rooms that looked the same. There were three main entrances, but none of them helped people know where to go. Most people who worked there knew how to get around, but it could be confusing for visitors. The workers created stories of romance and adventure that took people away from their everyday problems for a few hours.
**Becoming a Filmmaker**  
Many people want to make movies. There are many books and courses about how to write scripts and make films. Some competitions even give away cameras to help new filmmakers. Robert Rodriguez made a famous film called El Mariachi for only $7,000. He became well-known quickly. He wrote about how he wanted to make a great film before he turned 26, just like famous directors did when they were young. In the past, filmmakers had to work for a long time before making their first movie. They learned by working in different jobs in the film industry. For example, John Huston was 35 when he made his first film. Today, many new filmmakers have to find their own way without the help of big studios.

In the past, there were many council houses on the western side of the city. These houses were small and not very nice, made of orange brick or white plaster. In the summer, a bad smell from a factory nearby filled the air. In the mornings, you could often see a paperboy making a face because of the smell as he walked to deliver papers.
I don’t remember much from my early life, but I do remember sitting by a window and looking at the houses far away. I also have memories of my mother. She was a small woman who often seemed angry, and I never really understood why. When I went with her to small shops or around the city, I noticed that she was very lonely, even when there were many people around her. She cared a lot about behaving properly, which was not common in our neighborhood. This sometimes led to her cleaning the house a lot or telling me to "behave properly." I didn’t really understand her rules, which included not going into neighbors' gardens and sitting quietly at the dinner table.
My mother had a few friends, like Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, and Mrs. Winall, who didn’t say much. There was also Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. Looking back, I see that these women often talked about their problems, like bad legs and cold weather, and I sometimes felt like I was one of the problems.
Growing up in West Earlham was not easy. Until I was five, I stayed at home and played while my mother sat in a chair. After my fifth birthday, I went to a school half a mile away. Some kids were lucky to have a mother with a bike to take them, but my mother usually let me walk with other kids.
I remember summer holidays when I saw a little of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next door who told stories about his life at sea. Once, there was a charity event where a kind woman gave out lemonade, but my mother didn’t like it and thought they just wanted money. She often talked about how people were only after money, and she didn’t trust politicians at all.
My mother did care about my education. Sometimes, she took me to the Norwich Castle Museum on Sundays. We would look at paintings together. She didn’t mind this, and once she even made a joke about a painting of a Roman soldier, saying she wouldn’t want to meet him at night. This was a rare moment of fun with her.

**Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the side with odd numbers. It was getting dark, and the air felt wet and sticky. This side of the street was familiar to me. I remembered our neighbors, the Matzes and the Pritchards, and Han Kieffer's grocery store. I also thought of the Krings and the Pottses, where my first friends, all girls, lived. 
Even though I did not know everyone by name, I could picture the houses. I remembered the little channels in the cement that carried rainwater from the roofs to the street. I used to skate and ride my scooter there. As the street went down, the houses looked simpler. The porches were lower, and the front yards were smaller. 
Over the years, things changed. Wooden railings were replaced with iron ones. In Shillington, some houses became stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how people lived in these places that used to be shops. 
**Bachelor Fads Furniture Designer Rick Gilbert**
Rick Gilbert lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has big doors and exposed brick walls. He did not want his flat to be completely open. In his last home, it was hard to relax because his living space and work space were together. 
To make his flat better, he used a big piece of plastic to separate the office from the entrance. This created a hallway and led to the kitchen. He wanted the kitchen to be a place where he could cook for friends or make coffee for clients. 
To make the flat feel warm, he put light wood on the floors. He also mixed modern furniture with sentimental pieces from his parents or markets.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His life was full of secrets and stories. He wrote a famous book called *In Patagonia* in 1977. This book changed travel writing. It was exciting and imaginative, like a thriller or a romantic story. 
Chatwin sometimes changed facts to make his stories better. He believed that traveling could help people discover amazing histories.
**Swimming**
One summer day, it rained heavily. I ran across the lawn behind my house and jumped into the pool. I swam back and forth, watching the raindrops splash in the water. The best moments were when the rain got stronger, and the sound of birds disappeared. 
During this time, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain as it flowed to the sea. I felt tired of swimming in circles, like a tiger in a cage. 
Many places today have signs and labels. This makes the world feel less real. Walking, cycling, and swimming help us feel free and discover the wild parts of our world. A swimming journey would let me explore the mysterious places that still exist.

**Crying**
Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose for humans. But he was probably wrong. Scientists today say that crying is important for social reasons. For example, psychiatrist John Bowlby said that crying helps create a strong bond between a mother and her child. Many people believe that children cry because they feel helpless.
It is harder to understand why adults cry. The sound of crying is not as important as what we see when someone cries. In early human groups, crying may have helped people trust each other and feel close.
People cry for different reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for someone who is suffering. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to when we hear beautiful music or see a touching speech. We may also cry when we watch a sad movie, and this happens more often when we are with other people than when we are alone.
Crying has a social purpose, and scientists are still studying it.

**The Heat is On**
We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get? How will it change our lives? Many people have some idea about global warming, but not everyone knows what will happen because of it. A warmer climate will change the weather everywhere in the world. Since the atmosphere affects everything on Earth, these changes will also impact plants, animals, water, and soil.
Humans use natural resources to help us live. We grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. So, any changes to these resources are very important. The problem is that we do not know exactly how the world will change or what is causing these changes. 
Over the last 100 years, human actions have increased the amount of certain gases in the air. These gases are connected to global temperature. It seems that these gases are already affecting the climate, but we do not fully understand how everything works together. 
Scientists have found that the Earth has warmed by about 6°C in the last century. Most scientists believe this warming is not just natural and is partly caused by human pollution. Many scientists are trying to predict what will happen because of higher global temperatures. They use special computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to help them. These programs look at how temperature, pressure, and sunlight interact to predict the climate. However, these models are not perfect and can be slow and expensive to use.
Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than before. The predictions from GCMs suggest that by the year 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C. Sea levels are expected to rise by 15 to 95 cm, and there will be changes in rainfall patterns. Scientists also think that extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts, will happen more often in some places.
These changes will affect the environment and people. Climate change can change where forests and grasslands are located, the types of plants and animals in these areas, and the resources we need to survive, like food and water. Some effects may be very bad, but not all changes will be negative. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have helped increase wheat production.
However, small changes in climate can also lead to water shortages, especially in dry areas. In the Mediterranean region, there has been less rain in some places, and rain is falling more in autumn and winter instead of spring. 
Another problem is that glaciers are changing. This affects ice in the mountains and oceans, which can harm plants, animals, and human buildings. The Arctic ice is melting, which makes it easier for ships to travel but also increases the risk of icebergs.
One of the biggest effects of global warming will be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds to this. Many people live in coastal areas, so rising sea levels can cause serious problems. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo could face flooding, and many people could lose their homes. 
Small island countries are at the greatest risk. If sea levels rise too much, these islands could disappear, which would be devastating for their people and cultures.

'Mission to Mars
Wanted: a married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars. The couple should be healthy and strong. This will be the first group of astronauts to go to Mars if Dennis Tito's plans work. He wants to send a spacecraft on 5 January 2018. 
The spacecraft will go to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars' gravity to come back to Earth without using much fuel. Saving fuel is very important. The trip must happen in 2018 because the next time Mars and Earth are close is in 2031. 
This is a big project, and new technology is needed. If everything is ready in time, the spacecraft might go. Even if it does not leave Earth, the work will help future missions to Mars.'

**AESTHETICS**
Art is important, but sometimes it is hard to understand. This is because we often think of art as just a building, a book, a painting, or a statue. We forget that art is also about how people feel and experience it. When we only look at the art itself, we miss its true meaning.
Some art is very famous and admired. This can make it hard for us to see it in a new way. When art becomes a classic, it seems separate from the people and the feelings that created it. This makes it difficult to understand its importance in our lives.
To understand art better, we need to connect it with our everyday experiences. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of our daily lives. People who study art should help us see this connection.
To really understand art, we might need to forget about it for a moment. We should look at the simple things in life that we usually do not think of as art. For example, we can enjoy flowers without knowing much about plants. But if we want to understand how flowers grow, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight.
Many people enjoy things like movies, music, and comics, but they do not always think of these as art. When we think of art as only what we see in museums, we miss out on the joy in our everyday experiences. 
Art is best appreciated when it is connected to our daily lives. When we see art as part of our normal activities, we can enjoy it more.

**Observing Lions**
Many people think that lions hunting for food is amazing. They imagine lions working together like a team to catch their prey at sunset. Lions seem to be very social animals that cooperate to get their next meal. However, after studying lions in the wild for many years, we have a different view. 
When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to understand why lions hunt together, raise their young, and scare off other animals with their loud roars. We thought that if animals work together, they would have more baby lions that survive. But sometimes, if one lion helps too much, it can lose out. So, why do lions work together? We thought we would find the answer in two or three years. But lions are very good at resting and doing nothing. 
Because wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand their behavior.
**Pop Music Review**
The third album by Bedrock was very important for the band. The album, called *New Life*, changed rock music in the country for many years. It moved away from the serious and dark music of the past and brought in a lighter and more fun style. 
The songs mixed social ideas with humor and had sounds from fairground organs and brass bands. Bedrock showed that they were good at collecting ideas and writing songs. They wrote about everyday things like sunbathing and relaxing on Sundays. But the best songs had deeper feelings, like "So Low," which was about the weather, and "To the Brink," which was very emotional. 
*New Life* is great because it has 16 high-quality songs with no bad ones, which is rare for long albums.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I loved stories about 'The Sibyl,' wise women from ancient times. I first heard about one from my mother. An old woman from Cumae offered the King of Rome nine books for a lot of gold. When he refused, she burned three books and offered him six for the same price. He still said no, so she burned three more. Finally, he bought the last three for the full price. I learned a valuable lesson from this story about selling and life.
I was often lonely as a child. I wanted to play with other kids, but they would say no. My mother told me to do something interesting so they would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson.
When I got the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something that mattered to me. I don’t like to travel much, so I gave my editor a long list of places I didn’t want to go. I prefer to explore ruins because I enjoy traveling in my mind through time.
**What Happens to Your Manuscript?**
When you send your manuscript (your written work), it will probably go into a pile of other manuscripts waiting to be read. This pile is called the slush pile. Usually, a junior editor or an experienced editor will look at it. They want to find something new and interesting.
If they like your work, they will show it to a senior editor. This editor will decide if your book is good and if it can sell well. They will also think about whether you, as an author, can be successful in the future. Publishers often want to meet authors before they make an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**
In the early 1990s, working in an advertising agency was very hard. There was a big recession, which means many businesses were not doing well. This recession lasted a long time and affected many countries, including Britain. In 1991, many people lost their jobs, and many homes were taken away because people could not pay for them. Businesses, especially in the vehicle and building industries, lost a lot of money.
People who worked in advertising also faced problems. They felt a lot of pressure because they had to help their companies make money. They had to do their jobs with smaller budgets, which made things even harder. Even though they had less money to spend, the importance of marketing grew. Companies started to understand that they needed to make products that customers wanted, not just what was easy for them to make.
Because of this, marketing became more important, and marketing workers gained more respect. However, they also had more work to do. Many people thought that advertising could solve all problems, but this was not true. About half of the money spent on marketing went to advertising, so advertising workers felt responsible for the results.
In the 1980s, advertising was very successful, but in the early 1990s, it faced many challenges. The bad economy made companies think carefully about how much they spent on advertising. They wanted to see clear results for their money, but many were not sure if advertising was worth it. This made advertising workers feel like they were on trial.
Companies wanted better advertising strategies, better targeting, and better creativity. They wanted the best people from advertising agencies to work for them and to be very motivated. Advertising workers had to find ways to do more with less money, which was very difficult.
There were also other challenges. The economy was not the only problem. Changes in society, the power of retailers, and new laws about advertising made things harder. Some companies also had to learn how to advertise in other countries.
Because of all these challenges, advertising workers had to find ways to make their advertising more effective. However, help for them was not easy to find. Many companies were too busy dealing with their problems to share their ideas. The books and seminars available did not always provide useful information. They often made it seem like all advertising was perfect, which was not true. This did not help the workers who needed to create better advertising.

**The Kitchen and Cooking**
When I was in university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Most people wanted different jobs. Cooking is often seen as a hard job. Chefs work long hours, and the work can be very stressful and not well paid. But I still wanted to be a chef. I was not happy at university. The work was difficult, and the social life was not fun. Being a chef seemed like a good escape from my university life. It felt serious and honest, which I missed in college.
My wish to cook was not just because I was unhappy. I also loved the beauty of cooking. I first felt this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The food was amazing. I remember my first dish very well. After that meal, I wanted to learn all the secrets of cooking. I changed my life as a student to prepare for becoming a chef. My history degree felt unimportant to me. I learned to cook by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making special meals.
**Learning to Dive**
The swimming teacher at my school was a tough man with strong muscles and tattoos. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the edge of the pool, put my hands above my head, and roll forward into the water. I practiced this until my time was up. The next time, he made me stand up and dive from the edge. He was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he told me what to do better: "Don't look down, look up!" "Keep your legs straight!" "Point your toes!"
The following week, I went to the high diving board. It was very high, and I felt scared. I stood there, trying to be brave. I waved my arms like he taught me, looked up, and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. But when I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disappointment. But I still felt happy. I thought, "This is what they mean by 'free as a bird.'"
**The Traveller**
For many people, having a comfortable bed, clean water, and safety is very important. But some people, called travellers, choose to live differently. They take risks, like climbing dangerous mountains or sailing alone on the ocean. They might eat strange food if they have to and can live for a long time in unknown places. 
Some people think these travellers are strange. They are different from us, and we might not understand them. We can go back to our normal lives with microwaves and phones, happy that our risks are small, like crossing a busy street.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is a writer who is afraid of the sea, but he spends a lot of time on it. He does not say he is a great sailor, but he can sail well. He likes to write about his sailing experiences. Sailing gives him stories to tell.
Raban has a small boat with a device that tells him exactly where he is on the ocean. He likes this device, but he also believes that using a compass was a mistake. He thinks it changed how people connect with the sea. Now, sailors look at the compass instead of feeling the waves and the ocean. The sea, which used to be full of life, is now just a space to cross. Because of this, a sailor can use a machine to steer the boat for a long time. This is why Raban has time to watch the waves carefully.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books can help us feel at home in the world. We can relate our own experiences to those in books written a long time ago or in faraway places. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can express what we feel but in a clearer way. They can say what we are shy or confused about, and this can be surprising, especially if the author is from a different time or place. We feel thankful to these authors for helping us understand ourselves.
When we read or travel, we can escape our daily routines. Our eyes are wide open when we first arrive in a new place. This is also true when we read a great book. It helps us notice things we usually ignore. We start to see the colors of the sky, the changes in a person's face, or feelings we didn’t know we had.
**Author's Note**
These travel thoughts were published in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have made some small changes to fit the articles better, but not much else. I corrected a few mistakes, but I could have made more changes if I had more time. For example, in my article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I changed my writing to show this, it would not be the same story. Like many travelers, I was there at that time, not knowing what would happen next.
**Ecotourism**
If there were awards for tourism words that have been misused, "ecotourism" would win. This word started in the early 1980s when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized that many travelers wanted to travel without harming the places they visited. Now, "ecotourism" can mean anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a short boat trip in Australia. Any tour that includes culture, nature, or adventure can be called ecotourism. The original idea was good, but without clear rules, many travelers feel confused about what ecotourism really means.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notebook about my trip to Transylvania for 50 years, but I found it again a few years ago. It helped me remember that time, but it was not perfect. In Transylvania, I had a better time than I expected. I moved from one friendly house to another and often stayed for weeks. When I stayed in one place for a long time, I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes I only wrote short notes instead of full stories. I worried that some details were out of order when I started writing this book, but then I realized it didn’t matter much, so I let the story flow naturally.

**Fashion**
Fashion is often thought of as something new, but it has a long history. Many experts say that fashion started to grow in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries when trade became more important. As societies grew and new ways to make clothes were invented, the meanings of clothing also became more complex. Today, it is hard to know what a piece of clothing really means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people.
**Writer**
Many people think that all writers are famous and make a lot of money, but this is not true for most. Some writers have other jobs to support themselves while they write. They often write in the evenings after their full-time jobs. Others, like me, do different small jobs, such as teaching and writing articles. I have heard about a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I have never found one. Still, by working part-time and using credit cards, and with help from friends, I manage to write my novel.
**Sudden Fame**
When we started performing at small places, many people came to see us. We had to use secret doors to avoid being overwhelmed by fans. On our days off, it was hard to go outside without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched our every move, and our management took care of us. Even though I was still shy, I felt a strange confidence that comes to shy people in these situations. I felt very out of my comfort zone.

**Music - The Future Ahead**
Technology is changing our lives at work, home, and in our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there were many new ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. However, fewer people are performing live music, and there are fewer full-time jobs for musicians.
More people can access music now, and this is likely to continue because music meets many human needs. In Britain, music is important for national events and personal activities. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn to play instruments.
I believe that people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry is a big part of the economy in Britain, and musical skills are important for many jobs, especially in media. Also, playing an instrument can help develop skills in children. Research in the USA shows that making music can improve thinking skills. Studies in Europe suggest that group music lessons can help children make friends and focus better in school.
Research is also looking at how playing an instrument can help with other skills. For example, practicing regularly can help with good study habits, and playing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of this, there will likely be a continued need for music lessons in the near future.
What about the future? There are two likely changes. First, people will listen to more types of music, mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more to create and perform music. This will make it easier for people to compose music without needing a lot of technical skills, but it may also mean fewer live performances.
More people of all ages will want to make music together in their communities, reflecting their local musical traditions. To prepare for this future, music teachers need to change how they teach. They should help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This means music lessons will need to adapt to be relevant for more people and include a wider range of musical skills.
Musicians will need training to inspire and teach students of all ages. They should learn to work with different groups and develop skills in communication and management for community work. This is a big change from traditional teaching, and it will also require accountability to the public. 
This is a chance for everyone in music education to show the high quality of music teaching available. Finally, we need to make music more important in our lives. Music is essential, but we often take it for granted. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**
Sometimes, people do not respect actors. This is often because actors talk about their work in interviews. Instead of sharing their feelings, they use boring phrases or gossip. The actor Paul Scofield once wrote that acting is only real when it happens on stage. Talking about it makes it less interesting. Each time an actor performs, they start fresh and learn new things. After a play ends, they feel empty until the next performance.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester plays Hamlet, a character between being a boy and a man. His performance is simple but very strong. He shows great control and confidence. Lester plays a young man with hidden anger, but he also has a sharp sense of humor. His acting is impressive. You can see how he moves his body, waiting to act. Another actor, Handy, plays Horatio in a way that shows he is moved by something inside him.
**What is Acting?**
Acting is about showing feelings and behaviors. It raises questions about what makes a character come alive on stage.
**A Director's Rehearsal Process**
One director has a special way to start rehearsals called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. While one person speaks, the actors listen carefully. When it is their turn, they think about the words and what they mean. They take a breath and remember something related to the line. For example, if the line is about waiting in the rain, they might think of a time they waited in line. The director wants actors to be open and trust their feelings.
**The Perfect Theatre**
A perfect theatre makes you feel important. Going to see a live performance should feel special. The staff should care about the audience. The audience should feel close to the actors and understand what is happening on stage. The size of the theatre is important too. It should fit the human voice and body. If the theatre is too big, it feels wrong. Many theatres built in the late 1800s were good because they made the audience feel connected to the stage. 
When you go to the theatre, you want to see something surprising and new. If it is not special, you might as well stay home.

**Paul Simon**
Rock and roll music in the 1950s was very popular with young people. It was important because it changed the lives of many adults too. This music helped create new rock stars who were inspired by it. Paul Simon, like many young people in the US, listened to a famous radio show called Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party by Alan Freed. This show was very important for many young musicians. 
In another part of the world, a young John Lennon in Liverpool also listened to rock and roll on Radio Luxembourg. Paul Simon loved the music from Freed's show and wanted to make his own music one day.
**Snow**
One day, I was walking in the snow. I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was very strong, and I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, I fell into a hole that was about four feet deep. The snow had covered the hole, and I did not see it. I climbed out, feeling scared and worried about what would happen if the hole was much deeper. I sat against a tree to think. After an hour, I had only walked half a mile. I realized I had to change my plans.
**Qualitative Research**
Many books help researchers understand qualitative research. They talk a lot about how to collect data, but not much about how to analyze it. Analyzing data can be confusing. To help with this, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to share their experiences. We wanted to explain the process of analyzing data, not just create a guide for new researchers. This is not easy, so we let our contributors share their work in different ways, including personal stories and more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old son eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and pretending to be a dinosaur. He said, "I'm a little dinosaur." He was acting out a scene from a TV show. I asked him what he knew about dinosaurs, but he didn’t know much.
Many people think that learning on a screen is good. One writer tried an interactive program with his son. The father read the words while the son played with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes reading a book, he might have learned something. Research shows that learning is better when there is a conversation with teachers or parents. Using new technology to teach children is good, but traditional education is still very important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world’s movie-making was in Hollywood. People living there did not like this change. They thought Hollywood was becoming a place for rude people. But in the end, they accepted it because success is important. Hollywood knows which films will be popular and make money. 
In less than a hundred years, Hollywood changed from a small village to a famous town, like New York or Paris. It has changed a lot; a hundred years ago, you would walk through orange trees to get to the store. But in some ways, it is still a small village. People in Hollywood mostly talk about movies: how much money they make, who is dating whom, and who is working on which project. Many successful people want to live somewhere else but still work in Hollywood. It is the place where many people in show business want to be.
**Photography**
Photography was created by artists in the 1800s. They wanted to make a lasting record of what they saw. The new tools they used made pictures that were more real and detailed than paintings. This surprised other artists. Some art critics said photography could not be art because it depended on machines. 
But photographers believed they had found a new way to express themselves. They used their tools like other artists use brushes and pencils. They wanted to show the world and nature in their own way.
**Book Illustration**
In the past, every children’s book had pictures. This was also true for many novels for older readers. During this time, children’s publishing was mostly low-budget, which meant some work was not very good. However, the best artists always did their best work. 
The collection of black-and-white illustrations is a mix of good and not-so-good work. It is a great place to find interesting things and learn about a creative time. Many of these illustrations will be shown to the public again, either through new books or exhibitions. There are signs that this is starting to happen, and soon, a publisher will likely create a series of classic children’s book illustrations from this time.

**Blogging: Sharing Your Life Online**
A while ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone where you are online. When you say, "I am at this place," you are also showing your location to many people, not all of whom you may want to see. This shows that sharing everything online can have bad sides.
The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a lot of people. We can share our stories, photos, and feelings. But sometimes, we can get lost in this big online world. It can be scary, but we should not give up. There are people who have gone through this before us.
In the early days of the internet, some brave people started sharing their lives online. They faced many problems, like losing jobs and friends, but they learned important lessons. One of these early bloggers was Justin Hall. In January 1994, he was a 19-year-old student who began sharing his life on the web. At that time, the internet was mostly for scientists and students. Hall wanted to share his personal stories and created a blog where he wrote about everything.
In 1996, he started posting every day. Many people read his blog because he shared everything about his life. But one day, his blog disappeared, and he posted a video called "Dark Night." He had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, his partner said he had to choose between the blog and their relationship. Hall felt that sharing his life online made people not trust him. 
In 2002, another blogger named Heather Armstrong wrote a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a coworker sent her blog link to the bosses at her company, and she lost her job because of it. This shows that what we say online can have real-life consequences. 
Armstrong was sad and stopped blogging for a while, but later she got married and started a new blog about her family. Now, she is very popular as a "mommy blogger," and her writing helps her family. 
The lesson we can learn from these stories is that while the internet lets us say anything, we should think carefully before we share.

**Enough Sleep?**
Many people today feel tired. In rich and busy countries, not getting enough sleep and feeling anxious are common problems. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have trouble sleeping. Some popular books in Britain have characters who cannot sleep or are about sleep research. 
A sleep expert says, "People need more sleep." When people are busy, they sleep less. They wake up early to avoid traffic. One researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep for up to 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they started to sleep about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep.
In Europe, a university in England studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how noise at airports disturbs sleep, and how tired drivers can be dangerous. They ask students to help with their research. Students are paid £5 an hour and change their sleep patterns as instructed. 
Dr. Louise Reyner helps the students feel better. Some are worried because they wear electrodes on their heads. They think the researchers can see their dreams. But the researchers are more interested in how the body works. 
In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. The students come in the afternoon when they usually feel sleepy. They drive while answering questions. The road looks endless, and the sun is bright. The young men say they will not fall asleep. But Dr. Reyner has a video of one student trying hard to stay awake. At first, he sits up straight, but then he starts to blink and nod off. He wakes up suddenly, but the car goes off the road. 
Dr. Reyner says that drinking coffee can help. Two cups can make someone a safe driver for a while. She suggests energy drinks and chewing gum with caffeine for people who work at night. 
Scientists know that humans sleep in a daily cycle. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light sleep to deep sleep. We usually dream during light sleep. Our brain keeps our body still to prevent injuries while we dream. 
Scientists are sure that women sleep about half an hour longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they do not know why. Some researchers say sleep helps us travel through time safely. 
In the past, people had different sleep patterns. A history professor studied British life from 1500 to 1850. People went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for a while, and then slept again. This time was good for thinking and remembering dreams. Poor people enjoyed this quiet time away from their daily work. 
By the 17th century, with more artificial light, rich people changed their sleep habits to sleep more efficiently. Later, during the industrial revolution, most people worked longer hours in light. 
In some non-western cultures, people still do not have strict bedtimes. They sleep for a few hours, then wake up again. For some tribes, noises and the need to watch for danger make it hard to sleep all night. It seems that people everywhere need more sleep.

We are talking about very big cowboy boots. I stood in my expensive cowboy boots in the Arizona desert. I wore a full cowboy outfit, but I was not a cowboy. I looked at the mountains and realized I did not belong there. I flew in from Denver early in the morning. I thought I looked like a cowboy, but that changed when I saw a real cowboy at the airport. He was dirty and looked tired. He saw my new boots and raised an eyebrow, then left without saying anything.
I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. But now I don’t race anymore. I wondered what I should do next. A racing driver should have other jobs ready for when they stop racing. I thought I had some ideas, but they didn’t work out. I tried to be a commentator for races, but there were many other drivers who wanted the job. I also tried to sell classic cars, but that didn’t work either because nobody was buying them.
Being an "ex" racing driver is hard. Nobody wants to hear about how I almost became a champion. Even if I had won, people would only listen for a short time. Last year’s champion is not important anymore. I don’t want sympathy, and I don’t get any. I had a good career and made money, but I miss racing. I miss the excitement of driving fast cars and the attention from fans and reporters. 
Now, I have a lot of free time. I looked up at the blue sky and saw some small birds in a cactus. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I didn’t know there were songbirds in the desert. I realized that I, a fake cowboy in fancy boots, had a lot to learn.

**Vancouver**
In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evenings, residents walk around the city, and if you join them, you will hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver for its nice weather, beautiful views of the ocean and mountains, clean and safe places, and good schools and jobs. Some people complain about how fast new buildings are being built, but many agree that new people and tourism have helped the city grow. 
Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it was a place where many journeys began. Now, it is still a gateway to many other places.
**Writing Letters**
Journalists, like me, are not very good at writing letters. Some say this is because we do not like to write for free, but I think it is more about wanting to make our writing perfect. In our work, we try to make our words very effective, so writing a letter can feel different. Real artists, who write without thinking too much about the effect, do not have this problem. They understand how their words work together. For example, when Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he did not think about how the words sounded together; he just wrote.
**New Supermarket Opening**
Opening a new supermarket used to be a big event in Britain. A famous person, like a soap star or a royal family member, would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open all the time, so there is no need for a celebrity. Last week, people waiting to enter the new Superbuy store did not care who opened it, as long as they were first in line. A customer said that the first five men to enter would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel proud and those who arrived late feel jealous.

**Citizen Kane**
The film *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941. Many people talked about it a lot before it was released. They were worried about what William Randolph Hearst, the man the film was about, might do to them. Even though the reviews were very good, the film did not make a lot of money at first. Later, it became popular again because of television. This film has inspired many people to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said that the film was successful because he did not know what he could or could not do. He just made the film the way he wanted. He had a great team with him, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to tell the story of a newspaper owner who was like Hearst but not exactly him, Welles knew he had a great chance to show his skills as a director and actor. He took this chance with a lot of energy.
**Dermot and Carmel**
That morning, Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange. He had told her twice that he might be late and that he might stop at the golf club on his way home. He wanted to talk to someone, and the golf club was a good place for that. Carmel nodded her head but seemed like she did not really hear him. Dermot asked her, "Will you be okay? What are you going to do today?" She smiled and said, "It's funny you ask. I was just thinking that I have nothing to do today, so I will walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it is almost wrong to waste the day." Dermot smiled back and said, "You deserve to enjoy yourself. And if I am late, I won’t need any food, so don’t worry about it." Carmel replied, "No, that’s fine."
**Title Race**
Do you mind if I call myself a "mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator"? A recent study shows that job titles can cause problems at work. A survey by a big recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees think job titles create problems between coworkers. Most surprisingly, 70% of office workers said they would give up a pay raise for a better job title. This shows that people care a lot about how they are called at work. In the early 21st century, no one wants to be called "subordinate." The job titles people want sound nice (like "specialist" or "coordinator"), but they often mean the same thing as "lower level."

**The Vienna Assignment**
I was in Vienna to take photographs. This was usually why I traveled. Taking photos was not just my job; it was my passion. I loved how light fell on different surfaces. A single photo could show the beauty of a place, a city, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect picture. As long as I had film in my camera, I could keep trying. I had a simple rule: finish one roll of film, load another, and keep looking for great shots.
Once, I took a photo of smoke from a burning oil well. It became very popular, and many newspapers wanted it. It was a lucky moment. They say you create your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work freelance. I thought it was a smart choice, but life had other plans. The mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped. That is why I was in Vienna instead of a more exciting place. But I was still taking photos, and I was getting paid. That felt good to me.
My assignment in Vienna happened by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons." I took pictures of London in spring, summer, autumn, and winter. I enjoyed capturing the beauty of flowers in Hyde Park and the busy streets of Piccadilly. But I knew that many of my best photos would not be used because it was just a picture book.
After I finished my London photos, I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna. Instead of hiring someone new, they asked me to take his place. The publishers liked my work, and I was available. I was happy to go because things were not good at home. A week in snowy Vienna sounded great.
They put me in a hotel called the Europa, in the center of the old city. I had visited Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy trip, and I didn’t take many photos. This time, I was alone in January, and I knew it would be different. When I arrived, I saw the beautiful pink-grey dome over the snowy roofs of the city. I was excited to take great pictures.
On my first day, I didn’t take any photos. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to enjoy the city. The weather was cold, like the old buildings around me. I didn’t want to see what Rudi had done in spring, summer, or autumn. This was going to be my Vienna, and I wanted to discover it myself.
A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment. So, I took my time and looked carefully. The next morning, I woke up early. It had snowed overnight, and Stephansplatz was covered in fresh white snow and almost empty. I wanted to take a picture of the big cathedral, but it was hard to fit it all in one shot. Its tall spire reached into the sky, but at the bottom, it was very large. I knew I would have to find a different way to capture it.
In that beautiful weather, I felt the magic of photography. Even in the past, when people didn’t understand how it worked, they felt the same magic. You can watch a blank piece of paper turn into a photo in a dark room. Even when you know how it happens, it still feels mysterious. Maybe that is why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning did not surprise me.

**Kinetic Art**
Great news! The Hayward Gallery in London has changed into a wonderful place. This change is not because of a big, expensive show, but because of a special exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that moves or is about movement. This exhibition shows the history of kinetic art over the last 60 years. It shows that making art that moves or talks about movement has been an important part of art in the twentieth century. 
The exhibition has many paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art. The curator, Guy Brett, has studied this art for a long time. Visitors can enjoy the art without too many explanations. They can discover and connect ideas by themselves.
**David Hockney**
David Hockney is a popular artist. Many people like his work, even if they do not usually like art. People might like his art because it shows real things and is easy to understand. His art often shows fun and relaxing moments, which helps people escape from their daily lives. Some people might even like Hockney because of his fun personality and clever words in interviews.
However, some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. They say he is overrated. But others believe he is popular because people today do not always accept artists who are very popular. Hockney knows his art has limits, and he does not think it is important to compare his work to ideas of greatness. He does not say he is a great artist and believes that only time will tell how important his art is.
**Window-shopping - an Art Exhibition**
In recent years, I have seen many art exhibitions. Some are amazing, and some are not so good. I often feel frustrated when exhibitions seem to push a certain idea or message. Sometimes this works, and we see new trends in art. But often, it feels forced or not genuine.
As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was different. I worked with seven artists in an empty warehouse. The exhibition was called "Window-shopping." It was a collection of individual artworks that were connected only by the fact that they were all art. 
For example, Sam Cole made knitted cats that chased each other on a toy train track. In another piece, Matthew Crawley used a video camera and broke it while exploring inside. These artworks did not fit into a specific theme, but they worked well together. They did not get in each other's way and, I hope, they helped each other shine.
**Art History**
Some people love paintings but are afraid to think too much about them. They worry that thinking will ruin their enjoyment. Some art historians focus on theory and forget the joy of looking at art and the creativity of making it. 
This is like knowing how to cook a dish. Knowing the recipe and the cooking method does not take away from the taste of the food. In fact, knowing more about the art we enjoy can make it even more enjoyable. 
Enjoying art is not simple. What we like about art can change over time and is influenced by the society we live in. While it is important to feel and enjoy art, thinking about it is also valuable. The idea that thinking about art takes away from enjoyment is an old belief. Today, we can appreciate both the feelings and the thoughts about art.

**Metals**  
A long time ago, people in the Stone Age became interested in metals. One day, while sitting by a river and waiting for fish, an early human found a shiny yellow stone. This stone was not like other stones; it was beautiful. This is how gold may have come into the lives of these early people. Gold is soft and easy to shape, so it became very popular. Copper was also found, maybe by accident. When people saw how useful copper tools were, they started to look for copper and ways to get it from the ground. This is how metalworking began.
**St Ives**  
We walked down a narrow, cobbled street to the town of St Ives, carrying our bags. The wind was very strong, and we tried to avoid the cold waves that hit the walkway. The streets were empty, and all the windows in the houses by the water were closed. We had seen the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. The dark clouds made me think that visiting Cornwall without a car was not a good idea. I had invited my friend to come with me, promising nice walks along the beautiful coast and warm evenings by the fire.
**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is hard because it is gone. The people who lived in times of peace and times of trouble are no longer here. We cannot know exactly why they moved or how they lived. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas on people from the past. We cannot go back in time and see what happened. However, with computer modelling, we can create pictures of old landscapes and make virtual communities. These digital people can have some of the needs and abilities of real humans. We can set rules for them and see how they live. We can change things, like making it rain less or having more people, and watch how these virtual people react.

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys. One day, the main male monkey saw a strange male monkey nearby. The strange monkey wanted to join their group. If he did, the main male might lose his place. To keep the stranger away, the main male made an alarm call that means a leopard is near. The strange monkey ran back to the trees. This happened many times. But then, the main male made a mistake. He called out the alarm while walking across the open ground.  
**What Cats Catch**  
In a small village in England called Felmersham, people counted what their cats caught. In one year, seventy cats caught over 1,000 animals. A professor in America thought that all the cats in Britain might kill 100 million birds and small animals each year! But this number is not realistic. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals than the cats in the village. The important question is: can the bird population survive? The answer seems to be yes. In winter, many people feed birds, and there are many places for birds to nest. So, the cat population is not destroying the birds in Britain.  
**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are very important to the marshmen. Every morning, the buffaloes leave their sleeping place slowly. They make sad sounds as they walk to the water. They stand at the edge for a long time, tired, until the leader goes into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget what they were doing and relax. They move slowly away from the house and swim, looking tired. They spend the day in the reeds, eating green plants.  
**Picasso, Pablo**  
In 1940, Picasso painted fish while he was in a fishing town called Royan. The painting shows a fishmonger’s table with a crab and some soles. The fish look alive, but the painting is hard to understand. Picasso used flat patterns and soft colors to make it look calm, like underwater. But there is also a feeling of danger, as the fish seem to be ready to fight the crab. The painting shows both peace and a hint of violence.

**Photography**
For the last 150 years, photography has been used to show many parts of human life. It helps us see moments in time and space, from small details to big places. Photography gives us pictures from faraway places, different parts of space, and important events in our lives. It is a very important way to express what it means to be human.
However, people have been making pictures for much longer. The first pictures were made about 35,000 years ago in caves. We are not sure why these early paintings were made. They might have shown hunting events, been used for magic to help with hunting, been religious symbols, or just made homes look nicer. But pictures have always been a part of human culture.
Throughout history, people have asked if pictures are always true. The saying "seeing is believing" has made people trust images. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a true record of what we see. The camera works like our eyes and can capture images. This was seen as a big achievement because it was thought to show reality.
Some people believed that everyone could understand photographs, no matter their culture. For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander said that even a very isolated person could understand a picture of the sky. But as communication grew in the late 20th century, we need to think about how much photographs can be understood across different cultures. Is photography as influenced by culture as language is?
Today, photography is seen as a strong way to show evidence. People often show photos to say something about their lives, like "this is my grandson." Since photography was invented in 1839, it has changed a lot. It started as a way to keep records, but now photographs are often seen as historical documents. They can tell us about the people and society that made them.
I want to show that the camera is not just a tool that records events. Photography can also inspire social and political change. For example, the changes in art during the Italian Renaissance were connected to new ways of seeing. Similarly, photography has played a big role in our media culture today, showing us the hard truths of the world.

**How to Write Poetry**
Writing poetry is not easy. It can be fun, but it can also be hard. If you want to write poetry, the best way to learn is to read a lot and write a lot. You should also let your imagination be free. Some people need to feel safe before they can write a poem. Others write when they are sad. Some people write poems on a schedule, while others wait for a good idea to come to them. All of these ways are okay as long as you find your own style. 
**The Short Story**
In a short story, you should not have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be short and only used when they help the story. A memory can help the main character and move the story forward, but it should not slow down the action. Dialogue, or conversation between characters, is very important. It can show different sides of a story quickly. Too many words can make a short story boring, but it should still have enough detail to be interesting. In a short story, every word matters.
**Screenplays**
Writing a screenplay for a film is like playing chess. When you play chess, you make moves without knowing what will happen next. You learn to see the whole game, not just one move at a time. The more you play chess, the better you understand it. The same is true for writing screenplays. 
**Looking at Writing**
People naturally learn to speak, but writing is different. A long time ago, Charles Darwin said that speaking is a human instinct, but writing is not. All children learn to speak without lessons. If children do not have a language, they can create their own. But writing systems are not easy to invent. Most children in the past did not learn to read or write. Even today, some children find it hard to learn. Writing is something that takes time and practice to learn. We need to understand how writing works and how children learn to help them become better writers.

I have never started a book with so much doubt. I call it a novel, but I am not sure if that is the right word. I do not have a big story to tell, and I do not end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave the reader wondering. This book is about my memories of a man I met only a few times, and I do not know much about his life in between our meetings. I could make up stories to fill in the gaps, but I do not want to do that. I just want to write what I know.
To protect the people in this story, I have given them made-up names, and I have changed some details so no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. He may never be famous. When he dies, he might not leave any mark on the world, like a stone thrown into a river. If people read my book, it will be for its own interest. But maybe the way he lives and his special character will influence others, and after he is gone, people will realize he was a remarkable person. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know about his early life may find something useful in my book.
I think my book will help those who want to write about my friend. I do not say that the conversations I wrote down are exact. I did not take notes, but I remember well what was important to me. I have put these conversations in my own words, but I believe they show what was really said. I mentioned before that I have not invented anything, but I have taken the freedom that historians take to write words for the characters that I did not hear. I did this to make the scenes more lively and interesting. I want people to read my book, and I think it is okay to do what I can to make it enjoyable. 
Smart readers will see where I have done this, and they can choose to ignore it if they want. Another reason I feel nervous about this book is that the people I write about come from a different culture. It is hard to really know people, and I think you can only truly know your own countrymen. People are shaped by where they were born, the homes they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, the sports they liked, and the poems they read. All these things make them who they are, and you can only understand them if you have lived through those experiences. 
Because you cannot know people from another country except by watching them, it is hard to make them believable in a book. I have only written about my own countrymen before, and if I have tried to write about others in short stories, it is easier because you can give broad ideas and let the reader fill in the details. In this book, I do not say that my characters see themselves the same way I see them; they are seen through my eyes.

**POETRY RECITALS**
Poetry recitals are events where poets read their poems to an audience. In history, people often find it hard to understand the different types of poetry and poets. Today, there are many styles of poetry and different ways to present it. Some poets write poems to be read on paper, while others like to perform their poems in front of people.
There is a debate between these two groups. The first group, the "literary" poets, write poems for reading. The second group, the "popular" poets, enjoy performing their poems. Many events for poetry readings have become popular in the last twenty years. Small groups in towns hold readings in community centers or homes. Schools invite poets to read to students, and arts festivals often have well-known poets read their work.
For "pop" poets, performing is good for them. Their poems are usually simple and easy to understand. People can enjoy them right away. However, serious poets, who work hard to create deep and thoughtful poems, may not be understood by new audiences. These poets might choose to read their easiest poems instead of their best work.
Listening to poetry readings is not the same as reading poems on paper, but it can be fun and helpful. Hearing poets read their work can show the audience how to understand the poems better. It is good for the audience to have the text in front of them or to know the poems before the reading.
One reason for popular poetry recitals is to help people enjoy poetry. When poetry is mixed with music, like jazz, it can make people feel that poetry is for everyone, not just a few special people.

**Oral History**
