Historians often use oral history, which means they listen to people's stories about the past. However, this can be tricky. When someone talks about their past, their memories can be influenced by the person asking questions. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to ask about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers things. The historian's background and ideas can also affect the stories they hear. This means historians help create new evidence. But the person telling the story is also not always completely connected to the past. Their memories can be mixed with things they learned from other places, like TV or books. Sometimes, they remember the past with feelings of happiness or sadness that come from later experiences. These feelings can make their stories seem more real, but they might not always reflect what really happened.
**Animal Science**  
There are two main ways to study animal science: the physiological approach and the whole animal approach. Physiologists look at how the body works, like how nerves and muscles help animals behave. The whole animal approach studies how animals act in their natural environment. Within this approach, there are psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists usually work in labs and study a few types of animals, like rats and pigeons. Ethologists study animals in the wild and how they behave naturally. Although these two groups are different, they are starting to work together more. Physiologists believe their methods are very important, but understanding behavior also needs to be studied at a different level. For example, explaining how a bird builds a nest by only looking at nerve cells is not enough. We need to look at the behavior itself.
**The Social Sciences**  
When students start studying social sciences, they have to learn two things at once. They need to understand the subject and also learn how to study it. This means they must know the facts and research in their textbooks, as well as the methods used to gather this information. These two parts are connected. We all know about social life from our daily experiences, so it might seem like social sciences are just common sense. But each social science looks at different parts of society and uses special methods and ideas. These ideas help social scientists understand more than just everyday thinking and make each field unique.
**Classical Architecture**  
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. The Roman architect Vitruvius said that architecture includes order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, and distribution. He also used Greek words for some of these ideas. While he talked about how buildings should look, he did not focus on their function. However, he did explain how to design buildings for different uses. The roots of classical architecture are complicated. Before classical times, there were simple homes made of basic materials in Greece and Italy. These early structures did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards, but they still influenced later designs. Even though classical temples may look complex, they are essentially simple, like a one-room hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept a secret from Chen for a while. Lily was learning to drive. She drove around the gardens and the railway, even going over a small bridge with all four wheels in the air. After that, they passed the gasworks, which smelled bad. Chen found it funny that Lily was driving without telling him. He said, "So you can really drive, Lily? Good job!" Mui thought it was strange that Chen was not upset. He was excited and made plans with Lily to go for a drive on a Monday next month. They chose this day because it was usually quiet, and they wanted to leave early and come back by noon to not lose any customers. Lily would practice driving around the gardens before then. 
Mui bought a road map, which made Chen happy because she got a discount. But Lily felt a bit hurt because she thought Mui did not trust her to find the way. Soon, they were at the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was in the back seat, had to agree. Lily passed some slow cars with confidence, and Chen even clapped for her. 
After driving through the gasworks and past some boats, they parked in a quiet street near the sea. Lily was not sure about the parking signs, so she decided to pay to avoid problems. She noticed Mui looking worried in the mirror but thought it was better not to add to her worries. Lily locked the van doors carefully. Chen joked, "Don’t worry, no one will want that old van." The sisters were not happy with his joke. Lily told him he should be more grateful, and Mui said he was too quick to judge things by how they looked. 
Chen took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. He held Man Kee close and thought about how he wanted to raise him. Chen wanted Man Kee to learn about numbers and one day own many restaurants. As he looked at the sea, he felt a bit sad but also hopeful about Man Kee's future. 
Chen saw a ship far away and wanted to look at it through a telescope. At first, he could not find it, but then he did. It was a small, old ship. He lifted Man Kee to see it and said, "Do you see the ship, Son? It is special for us. It will take us back home when we are done here." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily came over and put her arm around Chen. 
Chen wanted Man Kee to see the ship, but when he let go of the telescope, it stopped working. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship was gone, and all Lily could see were seagulls flying around.

**THE WELL**
I read somewhere that if you dig a deep hole, you can see the stars when it is clear. I asked you to help me with my idea. You watched with big eyes as I pulled up the well bucket, put it on the wall, and then climbed in. I told you to let me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You held the handle while I pushed the bucket away from the wall. Suddenly, I fell into the well. I hit my head. At that moment, I saw strange lights. Later, I remembered that in cartoons, characters see stars when they hit their heads.
At first, I felt confused, then scared, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say. You called down to me, asking if I was okay. I wanted to shout back, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I stopped. I lay still and peeked at you through my eyelashes. You ran away to get help. I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge. I landed on the courtyard stones. I heard loud voices from the castle. I ran away to hide in the shadows.
My mother and father came with you and old Arthur. My mother was screaming. My father told Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You looked pale and shocked. I was hiding in the shadows, feeling excited. Then I saw the drops of water I had left from the well to where I was standing. I looked in horror at the dark spots on the dry stones. I saw a little pool of water at my feet. I looked back at the courtyard, where my father was shining a flashlight into the well. I couldn’t believe no one had seen the drops.
My mother was screaming loudly now, a sound I had never heard before. It scared me. What should I do? I had played a trick on you, but now it was serious. I realized this was worse than I thought. I felt bad for not thinking about it more. My fun plan had turned into a big problem very quickly. I needed a new idea. I took a deep breath and left my hiding place, coming out slowly. I called out softly, then louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a bit and then fell on the stones.
I sat up, feeling comforted in my mother’s arms. I said, “Phew” and “Oh dear,” and smiled bravely. I told them I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat. I said I crawled and swam through it until I got out. I thought I was almost getting away with it until my father came to me. He asked me to repeat my story. I did, but I hesitated. His eyes looked serious. I said the secret passage had fallen in after me and that the well was dangerous. I had barely escaped with my life.
When I looked into my father’s eyes, it felt like looking into a dark tunnel. It seemed like he was seeing me for the first time. My words got stuck in my throat. “Don’t be ridiculous, boy,” he said, sounding very disappointed. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked at me with a sad face. He seemed worried, not because I had a scary adventure, but because he could see I was lying. His pity felt like a strong lesson about my actions. It made me feel even worse.

**REMOVAL DAY**
Susan is a widow with grown children. She is leaving her family home. A van with the words "Removers of Distinction" is taking her things away. Fred, the removal man, is carefully packing her belongings. The house is beautiful, with four floors and a view of a small harbor. Susan remembers the years she spent there with her children. 
When they bought the house, her son Robert, who was five years old, asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" Now, Robert is an adult and is helping her move. He is making sure they take care of the piano. Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is very bossy and wants to make sure the piano is safe. 
Fred notices that Susan is not crying. He tells her that some people cry when they move. They are happy while packing, but when they see the empty house, they start to cry. Susan understands this feeling. 
She thinks about the piano. Robert said it was the movers' job to be careful. The piano is in the best room of the house. They will move it last. Sitting on the stairs, Susan remembers the day they brought the piano into the house. It got stuck on the stairs for almost two hours. Robert watched with excitement, while Francesca cried, "We can't live without a piano!" 
Peter, Susan's late husband, helped solve the problem. They left the piano outside while they moved in the other furniture. The next day, a builder took out a window. They used a crane to lift the piano through the window. The children were so happy to see it come in. 
Now, Susan thinks about how her children are busy and do not come home often. She is also having trouble going up the stairs. She worries about the piano and if the movers will notice something wrong with it. 
Fred asks if she is okay. He tells her they will move the piano soon. Robert and Francesca come to watch. Fred talks to Susan, and she feels like crying. Moving things makes her feel sad. 
Just then, the piano comes down the stairs. Fred is guiding it carefully. They take it outside and put it down by the van. Robert laughs first, and soon they are all laughing together. As they walk down the path for the last time, Susan realizes she is not crying; she is laughing.

**Online Book Reviews for Everyone**
Anyone can write book reviews online. At first, the Internet was open for everyone to share their ideas. People could publish their thoughts or create music channels. But in the beginning, you needed some technical skills to do this. 
One area that became open to everyone was book reviews. Amazon.com was the first popular online bookstore. On Amazon, anyone could write a review about a book and give it up to five stars. This was a great idea because it allowed readers to see what others thought about a book, not just what the publisher said or what professional critics wrote.
Amazon had many customers and received a lot of reviews. However, it was hard to check all the reviews because thousands were submitted every day. Amazon had a team of editors to make sure reviews followed their rules. For example, one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors were not allowed. But since reviewers could stay anonymous, some people wrote fake reviews. 
For instance, a writer named Lev Grossman was upset by bad reviews of his first book. He wrote some good reviews under a fake name to make his book look better. This worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed his fake reviews.
Authors could also comment on their own books. They could write messages to encourage readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even shared their email addresses for readers to contact them. However, Amazon did not always check if the comments really came from the authors.
Sometimes, readers wrote angry reviews. For example, when James McElroy's book about cheerleaders was published, some people mentioned in the book felt hurt and wrote many bad reviews. These reviews disappeared after a few days, but Amazon still liked that many people were writing reviews.
Most reviews on Amazon were serious. They helped other readers decide if a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that writing too many reviews was hard because you had to pretend to feel something about books you didn’t care about. This is why having everyone write reviews is a good thing.

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last two hundred years, people often think that artists must go against the art of their time. We like to say that art is special, new, and sometimes shocking. We feel proud to like artists whose work was not appreciated in the past. But when we see art today, we sometimes think it is too strange and not real art. The media often say this for us, and we agree because we expect art to be very different. We forget that today’s art still has old ideas and methods.
In the past, people asked artists to create art for specific reasons, and art was part of everyday life. Now, artists work alone, and we can get upset if they try to connect with us.
**Picture This**
I want to describe a situation and ask an important question. An artist picks a text from an art book. The text talks about different kinds of pictures and says there are many types of pictures. This sounds simple, but it is important. The artist then asks someone to make a canvas for him and to write the text on it in plain letters. My question is: is this finished piece a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London, there is a rule that artists should stick to one style if it sells well. Collectors want artists to keep making the same type of art. If an artist tries something new, people may not like it. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, can change styles and still be successful. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something new. He is moving from still life paintings to paintings about the London Underground. He finds the underground interesting and has created 40 paintings and drawings that show this hidden world.
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with some books. I say "escape" because the villagers joke that only a sick person would come to such a quiet place. I am here to heal myself. I am alone except for an old woman who comes from the village to clean my house. I feel neither happy nor sad; I am in a mix of memories. I talked about how art seems useless, but it can also bring comfort. Art helps us see the important parts of life. For artists, creating art helps us deal with the pain of everyday life. It allows us to fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why would we hurt each other?

**Family Business**
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I went to. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I got a prize for Latin and another prize for doing well in my exams. He talked a lot with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, but I already knew what he was thinking because he was quiet. My dad usually talks a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I replied, trying to act brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, and I knew he was going to confront me, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about lawyers and the law. "I just said that," I explained. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality. You can understand a lot of information quickly, you are good at talking, and you like performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."
"Anyway," he said, trying to stay calm, "I feel like you won't want to join the family business. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to do this."
The problem was that, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by what my family expected. I saw many jobs I could do, and I wanted to explore them. But I didn't want to upset my dad. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was his favorite - but I still found him intimidating.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you won't want to join us," my father said, and he often turned out to be right. "It's a pity because you have the skills - the brains, the courage, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father laughed. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business.
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and I took care of him because he didn't have a mother. I loved Maurice, and because the business was successful, we lived well - in a big house in London, went to nice schools, wore good clothes, and went to parties and shows. My father knew many interesting people.
"I tell you what," my father said. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford. Then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some money and help me."
"OK," I said, happy to avoid making big decisions right now, especially because my father would be upset if I disagreed with him. This was how he controlled us.
So, I helped out during my last term at school and during university breaks, but only a few times a year and with easier tasks. I became a smart student, had a small house, a nice car, and designer clothes, including a black dress for my final exams.
In my last term, my father came to see me and took me to a village for a meal. There were only a few weeks left until my exams. My teacher said I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I wanted to focus on studying.
My father told me that he needed me to do one last important job for the family business. He said it was the most important work they had ever done and that it would be worth my time.
"But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon, and I need to focus on that. It's really important, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."
I could see that my father didn't understand how important my exams were. He would think that if I said no, I was betraying him. As he explained the job, I saw how focused and determined he was. He was very good at his work, and I admired that in him. It made my own plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. They could only afford the house by being very careful with their money, and maybe they should not have bought it at all. At first, it seemed like a good idea. Simon had been doing well at work, and Lois had returned to her job after having twins. She even got a raise, making thirty-five thousand a year. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family. They needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found these things in a cheaper area of London, but Lois wanted to live in a nice place. 
Lois thought one of them should take public transport to save money, and Simon ended up being the one who had to do it. The crowded tube ride made him feel unhappy and jealous. He remembered his grandfather's house where he felt safe and cared for as a child. His grandmother always took care of the family and was proud of her husband, who was a lawyer. But that time was gone. Lois had made it clear that her job was just as important as Simon's. They needed both of their salaries to pay for the house and their lifestyle.
One day, a woman named Venetia came to their office in a bad mood. She was very angry about something. Simon wished he had left his room earlier to avoid her. He remembered her accusations. She said that a man named Brian Cartwright claimed Simon knew he had bribed jurors in a trial four years ago and did nothing about it. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty. He remembered feeling scared when he was a child and had done something wrong. 
When he looked into Venetia's eyes, he saw that she did not believe him. He wished he had said something different to defend himself. He felt that Venetia was being unfair and wondered why she was so angry. He was worried that if people heard these rumors, it could ruin his career.

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be alone. I wanted to be around people who did not care about broken houses or messy gardens. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you. The beautiful roses from next door remind me that gardens can be nice. Usually, I stay inside to forget about summer, but tonight I am watching the birds flying between the trees and roofs. I have cut some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms are a bit scratched. 
It is a small garden in London, where plants have to grow tall to survive. My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of her window. She is a writer, and I sometimes help her with her work because I am an English teacher. I have her latest story with me. "How is your writing going, Jaz?" I ask. She complains about how people always ask her about her work. 
Jaz offers to bring me a drink, but I don’t want her in the garden. It looks messy now. She comes down and sits in the chair while I put a cushion on the ground. She talks about how writers don’t have holidays like teachers do. I feel worried about the long summer ahead. 
"Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?" I ask Jaz. My heart races as I say this. "Of course," she replies, knowing she will be around. "Where will you stay?" she asks. "I’ll stay with my friend Ruby at the Rising Sun," I say, even though it is not true. 
Jaz asks about her story, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I have not read much. I tell her I like the title. I think red vans can be cruel because they bring gifts to other people. I decide to give her some advice. "Try writing about nice people," I say. She gets upset and tells me to get a life. 
I have my work and sometimes I go out and read on the tube. When we go back inside, my kitchen feels calm. But then I remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who used to wink at us and say, "I've had my moments." We all laughed.

**Heritage**
Heritage means the connection people have with their past. We often feel close to our personal heritage because we know about our grandparents and their lives. But we also want to learn about our wider history to understand our future. Heritage helps us feel secure about where we come from, which is important for our identity. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit our culture from past generations. Some parts of our national heritage may not be good, but it is still a part of us, and it feels good to belong to something bigger. Heritage teaches us many things and is important for our well-being. It affects our customs and culture. In the past, we learned about our history through stories from our ancestors. However, many of these stories have been lost because of changes in society. Now, we can learn about our past through places and buildings. It is very important to keep these connections to honor our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I once started writing a novel called *Waterland*. I did not know then that the Fens, a flat area in England, would be important in my story. People often ask me why I chose to write about the Fens since I am from London and do not know this area well. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and quiet, a good place for my story. But I learned that the Fens are not just flat and empty. They are very interesting and a bit strange. It is surprising that in the middle of England, there is a place that many people find unusual, especially when other areas have become part of England's culture. The Fens are both empty and full, both farmed and wild, and they seem open but are also mysterious. I have not visited some places in the Fens, but as a writer, I like to imagine things rather than just look for facts. The Fens are not just a place; they are also a way of thinking.
**Museums**
Museums should make their collections easy for everyone to see and understand. In the past, they just put items in display cases with long labels that were hard to read. Now, museums should be more creative and interesting to attract visitors. They should also reach out to the community. For example, some museums lend boxes of objects to teachers and even help elderly people who are losing their memory. Museums show real items from history, not copies. This is their strength and what makes them different from other places like theme parks or books. Museums that create exciting displays and programs will find that they can work with technology to make people want to see real history.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to keep things safe is not new, but changes in our towns happen very quickly now. This can make some people want to protect old buildings and encourage others to think about what towns are like today and in the future. People who have lived through big events, like wars, may want to preserve things more than others. Anything that shows stability is important to them. If we need to preserve things, planners should consider this. Change is not bad if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect changes in society, like our population and needs.

**Einstein**
If you ask people on the street to name a scientist, many will say Albert Einstein. His picture is used to sell many things, like computers and books. Most people do not know much about what Einstein did, except that he created some complicated ideas called 'relativity'. These ideas are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that do not match our everyday experiences.
Einstein was part of a big change in science. Scientists wanted to understand the universe better by studying how matter and natural forces work together. Einstein made important contributions by looking closely at basic ideas: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, people followed Isaac Newton's ideas, which said that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but can change.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, my sister Lydia and I did not like prize-winning books because we thought they were boring. Our mother did not like this and often showed her disapproval. But our father would give us small coins for every chapter we read to encourage us to read better books. He also gave us some special books as gifts, marking them with "This Book is NOT Literature" to make them sound less boring. Even though we thought most of his books were for boys, he helped us read some good stories and even a famous book of poems.
**Language**
Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the beginning of human language is a wonderful secret. This secret has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller said in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad. Early humans who faced dangerous animals made desperate noises, and some words we use today, like "malaria" (meaning "fever") and the Latin word "mors" (meaning "death"), come from these sounds.
Many people thought these ideas were silly, but now, studying how language started and changed is very important. Language likely began in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, people used speech to be friendly and to help in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not the main reason for language, which is different from what philosopher John Locke said, who thought language was mainly for sharing knowledge.

**Writing Reviews**
Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. They have deadlines and strict rules about how long they can be. When they are published, they are only in the newspaper for a short time, like a day or a week, maybe a month. Because of this, many people think that writing reviews is not very important. Some believe that people only write reviews because they need money. Others think it is because they cannot spend all their time writing a book.
However, writing reviews is a skilled job. It is different to write a short review of 600 to 800 words for a newspaper than to write a longer review of 6,000 to 8,000 words for a magazine. A reviewer must think about who will read their work. Some readers just want a quick summary, while others want a detailed review.
A good reviewer needs to know a lot about different topics and must write in a way that is easy for smart people to understand. Most reviewers also write other things, not just reviews. For example, the American writer John Updike does some reviewing while he writes his novels. He collects all his reviews into books, even if they are short.
Some people think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews will not last long. But if they believe their best writing is in reviews, they should be able to keep them. I feel this way about my own work. I mostly write academic books, which are serious and for professors. In English-speaking countries, it is common for the same people to write both reviews and academic work. 
In the past, some academics did not like professors who wrote reviews. They thought it was a waste of time. But now, there are many reviews, and almost anyone can write one. This is good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about. It is also good for professors because it helps them remember to write clearly for everyone, not just for other professors.
In conclusion, writing reviews is important, but it is usually a secondary job. You can only write good reviews if you are also doing something else well.

Ralph opened the door to his flat. When he walked into the dark hallway, he felt a quick moment of pride. Even after three years, he sometimes felt this way when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he was always excited to come back. He wondered what the flat had been doing while he was away. It felt like a warm welcome to him, a place where he could relax.
He thought he should worry about things like break-ins or leaks, but his flat always seemed to be waiting for him. It looked either clean or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as part of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings spilled out. He became frustrated that he could not change it.
Sometimes, letters would pile up by the door, and the answering machine would blink when he got home. He was thankful that his windows were not broken and that nothing bad had happened to his flat. From his small office on the third floor, Ralph often looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After leaving the busy office, he felt a little more like himself on the bus ride home. But once he was home, he realized he didn’t want to be alone anymore, even though he thought he did.
At his desk, he wanted to be alone with his things, but when he got home, he felt empty. He worried that his job was changing him and taking him away from who he really was. He would read or listen to music at night, but he started to wonder why he did these things. His thoughts became confused, and he felt lost.
There was a time when he felt stronger and believed in himself. He wanted to improve his life, but he just wanted to get by. He applied for jobs that his friends talked about, following them as they moved forward. He went to one job interview for a local newspaper. He was happy to have a nice chat with Neil, his future boss, and he didn’t think about what the job would really be like. Neil offered him the job right away, saying he was the only graduate who applied. Ralph took this as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**
I was about to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I was moving through ice-cream vans, many people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was going to the racecourse, but I pushed through the crowd to find a good spot. They had made a special area for the race. It was not like a big racecourse, but people were standing on both sides of the ground where the goats would run. They were trying to keep a few goats in order. This is not easy because goats can eat almost anything!

In the dim moonlight, we used our flashlight to see the cliffs, but the flashlight batteries were dying. We changed the batteries, but they did not work. We could not find a place to camp. A little later, Lesley saw a flickering light, and we felt hopeful. But the light was just the moon shining on the waves. **How to Be Presentation Perfect**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and important shareholders. How can I get better at this and feel more confident? You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company, but many leaders need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your passion and enthusiasm during the presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask your colleagues what tough questions the audience might ask. You should also create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone can relate to and then lead to your main point.

Some activities take time and cannot be rushed. For example, if you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you try to make mayonnaise too quickly, it will not work. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, it will get tighter. Our minds also work at different speeds. Some things we think about happen very fast, while others take a long time, like days or even years. 
We can get better at some tasks, like solving puzzles, but some things cannot be rushed. If we try to hurry, we might make mistakes. For example, saying "Think fast; we need results" can be unhelpful, just like trying to sleep for a short time when we need more rest. 
There are three main speeds of thinking. The first is very fast. Sometimes we need to react quickly without thinking. For example, if you fall off a bike, your body knows what to do before you think about it. This quick reaction is called our "wits." 
The second speed is thinking carefully. This is when we solve problems or make decisions. For example, a mechanic figuring out why a car won’t start is using this kind of thinking. We often call this "intellect." People who are good at this are called "clever" or "bright."
The third speed is slower and more relaxed. This is when we think about things in a calm way, like when we are daydreaming or enjoying nature. This slower thinking is also important. It helps us understand complex problems better. 
Recent studies show that taking time to think slowly can help us solve difficult problems. For example, if we are unsure about where to go on holiday, we might need to think slowly to understand all the options. 
In some situations, like managing a difficult team at work, it is better to sit and think rather than rush to find answers. This slower way of thinking is connected to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have known for a long time that slow thinking can be very valuable. Scientists are now studying how our minds can do important tasks when we give them time.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I have been welcomed warmly. I am in a friendly place with many people. There are about forty people here, including scientists, students, and weather experts. We all help each other. My French is okay for talking, but I cannot have fun conversations. I miss some small details, and my phrasebook does not help me at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt unsure of myself. I was a little scared of mealtimes. I did not know which table to sit at, and I felt nervous when I spoke. I still smile a lot or feel scared when people talk to me. I think I feel a bit sad because I am not as confident as I used to be when I could talk easily.

If I saw him at the opera with important people, he would not see me. Then, I became successful as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to be friendlier. He believed that people feel strong emotions from the film itself, no matter where they come from. If a film is made well, people from Japan and India should react the same way. Hitchcock was very smart and knew what he was doing. He wanted to make people scream with excitement. He focused only on the film and how it could affect the audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Many things have changed in astronomy in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts and books about astronomy. Telescopes were not very good, and there were few practical guides. Now, there are many types of telescopes and equipment available. Electronic calculators and computers have made it easier to create charts and analyze observations. This is a great time for amateur astronomy. 
However, some things have also gotten worse. Now, you may have to travel 80 km to find a dark sky, unlike 50 years ago when it was easier to see stars in cities. During the day, the sky is often filled with trails from airplanes, which can last for hours and make it hard to see the sun or stars at night.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices in life. People have many options for products and services. This can feel overwhelming. Technology makes things change quickly, and new products come out all the time. This can make people feel tired and disconnected from life. 
Having more choices can lead to more stress and less time. Because of this, many people are looking for "simplexity," which means finding simple things that make life meaningful. But it is not easy to simplify life when there are so many products and options available.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, my family stays for two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it is very important to us. We do not want anything to change this tradition. 
The guests at McAndrews Hotel are often old-fashioned and a bit different. I do not like the rude behavior of some shop assistants today. I also do not enjoy when waiters act too friendly. I know many of the other guests because we have been coming here since we were children. When I see them in the hotel, we usually just say hello and do not talk much. This respect for privacy is hard to find in hotels today.

**Othello**  
A great show of Shakespeare's play Othello is now in London. I want to say sorry for a bad review I wrote when the show started last spring. I said that Ray Fearon was too young for the main role, and I was wrong about his acting. I still believe that Othello and Desdemona should have a bigger age difference, but I take back my words about Mr. Fearon's amazing performance. The whole cast is wonderful. **Lake Vostok**  
In Antarctica, there is very little life. On the edges, you can see penguins, seals, and birds. But in the middle, there is a huge hidden lake called Lake Vostok, which is under almost 4 kilometers of ice. This lake has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are excited to explore this lake and find out what strange life might be there. For two years, researchers from around the world have been trying to learn the secrets of this lake. If they succeed, we will see many discoveries about Lake Vostok in the next few years.
**Scientists**  
Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. Some scientists are thinking about why they want to be scientists. They often say it is "because it's there." We know that they want to learn about everything, from tiny atoms to big black holes. But these scientists want to understand why we want to know these things. They wonder why science cannot explain our desire to learn. I think it is more important to know if what scientists do is right, rather than argue about why we want to know things. Science is a tool, and we should decide how and when to use it.

**Food**  
Food is very important in our lives. Many people who love cooking buy cookbooks. Sometimes, we think cooking is only for special occasions or fancy dishes. But that is not true! You can make a tasty soup by just putting chopped carrots, leeks, celery, and herbs in water. This is much better than buying soup in a packet or a can. Instead of buying a sweet chocolate dessert full of chemicals, you can make a delicious treat in just five minutes that everyone will enjoy. Cooking is also a way to show care and love. Sharing food is special, and that is why we celebrate important events like birthdays and anniversaries with meals. No one wants to have takeout for a wedding or a business meeting over canned soup!

As he took the elevator to his floor, he knew Mallory would arrive on time for their meeting. She was always very punctual and liked things to be neat. Miss Fogerty was walking quickly across the village green. She felt both excited and sad about something she had just seen. It is always thrilling to learn something new in a small community, but she was also worried about Dr. Bailey's health. He had been her doctor for many years and always cared for her when she was sick. She appreciated how he made her feel like he had time to listen to her problems. This is why everyone in the village loved him so much. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor to his patients, and they were very loyal to him.

**Joanna's Lessons**
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She plays music for many people. But she also writes books for young children who want to learn the piano. Joanna plays the piano very well. She can play many styles of music, like classical, jazz, and blues. 
At one concert for kids, a small boy asked her, "Can you play Match of the Day?" This surprised her, but she thought it was funny. She played it, and the boy was happy. Joanna cares a lot about how children learn to play the piano. She has written a book called *Joanna MacGregor's Piano World* to help them.
Even though she has a busy schedule, she wants to help children learn music. She believes that the first lessons are very important. Many people think only about the best musicians, but Joanna thinks everyone should be able to enjoy music. 
When she was younger, Joanna taught many children how to play the piano. She remembers how much fun it was to play different kinds of music with them. She wants all children to have the chance to learn the piano, just like they can learn to swim or speak a little French.
Some kids learn quickly, but others take more time. Some children stop learning because they feel too much pressure from their parents. Joanna worries that some parents want their children to be perfect instead of just enjoying music.
Joanna's books are colorful and fun. They have stories and music to make learning easier. She wants children to have fun while they learn. She believes it is important for kids to play around on the piano and try different sounds.
As children learn, they need to practice reading music. Joanna understands that this can be hard. She thinks practice is very important. She did not practice a lot until she went to music school, but now she loves it. 
Joanna says that whether you practice for a little or a long time, it is important to know what you want to do. She also suggests playing through a piece of music, even if you make mistakes, and mixing easy songs with harder ones.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said that "what is written without effort is usually read without pleasure." This means that good writing is hard to do. When I look at my old school essays, I see that I did not cross out many words. Today, I would change them many times. I think this is because writing by hand was hard work. Writing slowly helped me think better. When we write on a computer, it is easy to make mistakes. Many writers spend just as much time fixing their work on a computer as they did writing it by hand. 
Emails are different from handwritten letters. Many people now write love letters by email. This is good because at least they are writing. But words on a screen can feel flat. People often do not think carefully about what they write, and their messages can become confusing. Writing quickly on a computer can lose the care and style of handwriting.
**The CD**

I agreed and handed the disc to him carefully. "It’s amazing that they can fit seventy minutes of music on them," he said, turning on the music player. Lights turned on, and a small drawer opened. They think it will replace books soon. But big changes take a long time. Reading long texts on a screen is not enjoyable, so many people do not do it. Some people say that this new way of reading is good because it creates new stories. But many books have always been read in parts, like religious texts and dictionaries. The real problem is that computers do not help us read everything from start to finish.

"You don’t take sugar, do you?” shouted his secretary. She was not really asking; she was stating a fact because she had been making coffee for Lancelot for many months. Ian Cuthbert had received a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was a friend who Lancelot had made a mistake by asking to write a book. He closed the folder and pushed it aside. It seemed that Ian’s manuscript would never come. The synopsis was not as good as it should be, and it felt like Ian had lost his passion for the book.
Lancelot remembered a famous author who had published an incomplete book after his death. That author had been paid little by little for each chapter. But Ian had received a lot of money upfront, which was not how things should work. Lancelot remembered when Ian was a promising writer in Cambridge. His friends wanted to take over British theatre, and they did. But Ian seemed lazy compared to them. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous writers as if he had met them.
For some reason, Ian’s creative talent stayed hidden. While others became successful, Ian became harder to work with. He was supposed to edit a magazine about the arts, but it never got published. His contract with a fashion magazine was renewed three times, but he still did not produce anything. At meetings, he was rude and critical of others’ ideas. **England's Breakfast Revolution**
A good breakfast is very important, according to health experts. But in history, breakfast is a new idea in England. In medieval times, people did not often write about breakfast. Some travelers ate a meal at dawn before long journeys, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.
In the sixteenth century, breakfast became more common. Some writers say this happened because food was easier to get. However, there were also big changes in society. For example, more people had jobs with set hours. Many of these jobs started very early in the morning. So, eating breakfast became necessary for everyone, not just for rich people.

**Photography**  
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and experiences. They also think about social and cultural ideas. In this book, we will see how these things affect the style and meaning of a photograph. We will also look at how people see and react to these images. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they understand the photos in a certain way. But instead of just believing the photo, we can ask if it really shows what happened at that time. Does it show the photographer's opinion? Is the exact moment in the photo important, or does it represent something bigger in the world?
**More than a Game**  
For me, sports are more than just a game. The best athletes believe in themselves completely. To be the best, you need to focus and put everything else aside. Sports can be tough, and no one will do the work for you. You either succeed or fail. Sports have taught me discipline and determination, but they also show the importance of teamwork. My sport lets me shine as an individual, but it is also a team game, and I must balance both. This is like life – you can do well alone, but you must remember others are around you. **Tuning In**  
Some experiences stay in our memory very clearly. For me, one special moment happened many years ago in California. One night, I was awake listening to a mockingbird singing from a tree in my neighborhood. I don’t have trouble sleeping, but the beautiful singing kept me awake. As I listened to the bird's songs, I felt like I was in a special musical world. To understand the bird's music, I thought about jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an amazing live performance. I cheered and groaned as the bird sang different tunes through my open window, until I finally fell asleep.

People have always talked a lot about birds. They love them, fear them, and even worship them. But what does this say about us? 
In a greenhouse, a little brown bird called a wren is bumping against the glass. Is it trying to tell me something, or is it just stuck? Depending on how you see it, both could be true. 
Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, you can still see wrens in pictures and decorations in many British homes. Even if old beliefs about wrens are not as strong now, people still care about them. A place without wrens feels sad. 
People used to connect more with nature for their survival. They created stories and meanings about birds. These meanings can change over time. For example, the red kite bird was once seen as a helpful bird in London, taking food from children. But later, people thought of them as pests and they almost disappeared. Now, red kites are protected again and are important for conservation in Britain. 
Our connection with birds goes back to when humans first appeared. Early humans watched birds closely because they could warn them about danger or bad weather. Birds also connected them to their dreams. 
Birds are important to us because they represent freedom and beauty. Some people think our feelings about birds are not needed anymore, but they are still part of who we are. Losing this connection would be hard for us. 
In recent years, birds have shown us how the environment is changing. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because it means we are losing not just birds, but also part of our culture. Birds like the skylark and turtle dove have special meanings in love and magic. Many poems and stories mention these birds, and losing them makes us feel sad. 
However, we often ignore the loss of other birds that are not in stories or poems. Folklore, which includes stories and legends, is very important. These stories connect us to birds in a way that science cannot. They help us feel emotions that are hidden in our busy lives. 
Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel cannot be explained by science. Birds are fascinating in ways we do not fully understand. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a long history and holds a mystery that keeps us thinking.

**Maps**
A map shows how places and features on the earth are related to each other. This is done by showing distance and direction. In the past, people often talked about distance in time, like "it takes so many hours to walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring helped people understand how easy it was to travel, but it did not give exact distances.
Direction is also important, but for many travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" So, having the exact direction was not always very important. Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, do not show true directions.
In the past, important landmarks were shown on maps with signs that could be realistic or simple. The way maps were made changed depending on their purpose and location. To understand old maps, it is important to know how they were made.
The history of map-making, or cartography, is about making maps more accurate in showing distance and direction. Over time, cartographers used other sciences to help them. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, they started using compasses and tools to measure angles accurately.
As people explored the world, they wanted to make better maps. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere, which helped improve maps of large areas. The needs of map users also changed. Soldiers, especially after the invention of cannons, needed accurate maps to understand the land better. This led to the creation of contour maps.
Other people, like archaeologists and historians, also needed maps for their work. Today, cartographers make maps for many different uses, like showing geology, climate, and land use. This shows how important maps are in many sciences.
It is important to know that the development of maps has not always been steady. There have been times of slow progress and times of quick change. Sometimes old ideas stayed alongside new ones. Cartographers often had good ideas but had to wait for better tools to use them. Since it is easy to copy old maps, many map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas.
Because of this, we should not always trust maps as the best information. The many maps we have today show a lot of human effort and thought. They are valuable records for studying our past. This is what makes learning about historical cartography interesting and important.

**Tim Rice**
I went into a young man's living room. It was a nice place, very different from the messy rooms where his family spent time. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from a cheap seat to a better one. In this room, I saw the biggest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player I had ever met, and amazing things like wine glasses and furniture. The young man’s name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had a scholarship to study history at Magdalen College, Oxford, and he had nine months before starting school. He wanted to be a famous composer like Richard Rodgers.
I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for good reasons: women, money, and fame. But my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew’s were to him. When Andrew suggested I try to be a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was happy to try. He played me three of his songs on the piano, and I could tell he was very talented.
He needed a new lyricist, and I didn’t have much to show him except for a song I had written that a small pop group had recorded. We said we would meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I knew I had met someone special who would be very successful in musical theater.
The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, I felt less sure about my chance in show business with Andrew. I would still look for ads for groups needing a singer and write more simple songs. But I thought I would probably finish my exams and become a lawyer by twenty-five. My father thought I would stop liking pop music by twenty-one, and that worried me. I wanted to enjoy it for a while longer.
I decided to see Andrew again. It would be fun to go to a musical with him and write lyrics for musicals instead of pop songs. Andrew was interesting; he talked about good food and old buildings, and he liked the Leyton Orient football team. He had an idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man who started orphanages. I thought the story was good, but not very exciting. The hero seemed too perfect, and the idea reminded me too much of the musical "Oliver."
But Andrew believed in his music, and I wanted to help. I started working hard, especially on the funny songs. Andrew told me the story, played the music, and even gave me some titles. I skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first lyrics for the musical. That day, I didn’t know it, but I was starting a new career.

**Language**  
You and I are part of a special group of living things. We can share thoughts and feelings with each other using language. Language is very important in our lives. If you see two or more people together, they will probably be talking. When people are alone, they might talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I think of language as a natural skill. Just like spiders know how to make webs, people know how to talk. No one teaches spiders how to spin webs; they just do it.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather are made by the air around us. They have a big effect on animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet weather all year helps tropical jungles grow. These jungles have many different kinds of plants and animals. In cold and windy places, there are not many living things. The weather changes every day because of big air movements. The air moves because the Earth spins. The sun also helps to move the air.
**Coffee**  
As a bar-person, my job was to serve drinks, but I also had to make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I had several days of training to learn how to make coffee and clean the espresso machine. I learned how to make a good cappuccino. By the end of the week, I realized that making coffee was harder than it seemed. I thought I might have to go back to cleaning ashtrays. Luckily, my boss was patient. He told me, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often not do well with shows about art? Painting and sculpture are good subjects for TV because the camera can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. But there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. 
A good example is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to show British viewers a type of art that British galleries do not show. I thought the series would focus on famous artworks. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as a metals dealer and became known for taking risks. The metals market is not as controlled as other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this business. This adventurous culture fits well with a free global economy. 
But now, the free-trade experts who said the market would keep metal prices high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being taken from the ground, and the cost of raw materials is going down. If we think about inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to look into claims against a big company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. They stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island is unique and has something special to offer. To get around the islands, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to explore on your own. 
Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK**
You can build your own bamboo bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This workshop is run by two engineers, James Marr and Ian McMillan. You will get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and have a fun weekend building your bike.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bikes from bamboo. I went to see how it works. There is a lot of energy and fun in the workshop.
Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes. Some companies, like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire, have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. But many cyclists find bamboo bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost about $2,995 or £1,868. 
James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to create a business that everyone can enjoy. They wanted to share the fun of making something special and eco-friendly. Now, the Bamboo Bike Club is more about community than just business. James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. They run monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a good price.
On the first day of the course, James and Ian teach you how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. You will glue the bamboo tubes together to make the bike frame. They use alloy tubes for parts that need to be very strong, like the handlebars and wheel forks. 
James and Ian help everyone with their work. They check every cut and joint to make sure it is right. If you make a mistake, it is okay! You can just try again with another piece of bamboo. Each piece of bamboo is checked for quality, so you can choose how your bike will look: plain bamboo, black, or mottled.
On Sunday, you will spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You will wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike will be ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and a seat.
James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are very strong. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it. They use thicker bamboo and strong bindings to make sure the bikes last.
How do bamboo bikes look? They might not look as neat as metal bikes, but they are unique. James and Ian believe that the special look is part of the charm. I think bamboo bikes are great for relaxing rides, not for racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth ride.
I tried James's bike, and it was light and smooth to ride. James says the best part of the workshop is when you ride your bike. Bamboo bikes are fun to ride and cost less than £500.

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend worked as an editor at Random House in New York. One day, she found a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She thought the title was great and knew it would be very popular. She was right! Dr. Gray became very rich, and Dione started her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps men and women understand each other better. This book is part of a big self-help industry in America. Many people want to improve their lives, and this industry helps them. However, it also creates many new problems and supports the publishing world in New York.
In Britain, people see that there are many self-help books, but some are not very good. For every self-help book published, many others are not accepted because they are too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. Editors are always looking for the next big book. They care more about how popular a book will be than how well it is written. Dione says that if someone has a catchy title, it is a big step towards success. 
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an agreement between the writer and the reader that the truth will be told. But this agreement is often not kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too shameful or not important. Sometimes, they may change the truth to make their story better. They might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This can happen without any bad intentions.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
People who study detective stories say that these stories show the problems of society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. In a detective story, a crime represents a human desire, like greed. Solving the crime helps society return to normal. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal understand each other and are connected in a strange way. The detective is part of both worlds: he is too honest for criminals and too shady for the law. His job is complicated because he feels connected to both sides.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. We both felt out of place there. Gould said that writing in such a fancy place is hard. He believes that only scientists can write well about science because they understand it. If you do not know the science community, it is difficult to write about it.
Gould has a rule: never write down to the reader. He says you can use simpler words, but you must keep the main ideas clear. If readers feel that you are talking down to them, they will not enjoy your writing.

**Air-conditioning**  
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers, it is very cold inside. This summer has been very hot, so the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, it feels like the Arctic when it is quiet. This shows how we often use air-conditioning too much. It is now a big part of our work and play. Many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use sunlight and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas are simple but can help a lot and reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**  
It is interesting that more people are looking at sundials again. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches got better, sundials became just decorations in gardens. Now, people are taking them seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**  
I remember seeing china-painting at an art show a long time ago. Older women painted flowers on teacups very carefully. It was amazing to watch them. Their hands were steady, and the paint was perfect. I thought it would be hard to learn this skill. I wondered if beginners would be good at it. But when I went to a china-painting class, it was not scary at all. Everyone was there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint like the women I had seen before.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, a beautiful city, at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that other people in the group were students from the south coast learning Italian.
But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss in Switzerland, not Venice. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they heard older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane.
When they landed, a woman with glasses told them to stay together. The brochure did not say anything about an overnight stop, but when they arrived, Keith realized they were not going to Venice. It was close to midnight, and they were tired, so they did not question the beds they were given. 
The next morning, they found out they were supposed to stay in the hotel for their whole holiday. The receptionist smiled and said they could enjoy the lake and take a boat to Interlaken. Keith calmly told him there was a mistake. They were meant to be in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. The receptionist did not know that place.
Dawne said the man who booked their trip was bald, wore glasses, and had a moustache. She gave the name of the travel agency in London. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they had seen at Gatwick, came over. She said she was in charge. Dawne told her they were in the wrong hotel. 
Keith explained that they had followed the girl in the yellow-and-red uniform and ended up in the wrong group. Dawne added that they should have known something was wrong when they heard people talking about Darlington, not Dover. 
Mrs. Franks explained that there are many different holidays with the same yellow-and-red labels. She laughed and said if they followed others with the same labels, they might end up in a wildlife park, but that could never happen. 
Keith insisted they were not supposed to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks then walked away, leaving them confused. The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. Dawne whispered that Mrs. Franks seemed nice, but Keith was not listening. He thought about everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and getting on the plane.
An old man named Mr. Nottage spoke to them. He and his wife were happy and said they had the best sleep in years because of the fresh air by the lake. Dawne replied that was nice. 
Keith and Dawne left the hotel and did not say anything to each other. They found it funny that on their first holiday since their honeymoon, they were with a group of older people when they wanted to escape from that. Uncle had said the same thing when they tried to get him to come with them.

**He Was a People Person**
American business leaders are looking to Ernest Shackleton, a famous polar explorer, as a good example of management. Many people in Britain know who Shackleton was and what he did. However, Americans are just starting to learn about him. This year, the Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer" who was not well-known for most of the 20th century. Now, Americans are very interested in him. 
Books and stories about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being made. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and a film about Shackleton's life is in the works. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with great respect and learn lessons about leadership and communication from him. 
Shackleton is known for being determined and resourceful. He had a special sleeping bag and a stove made from animal fat. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for many years. His company helps with communication during business changes and crises. MacGregor says that even if a company handles a crisis well, it can still hurt itself by not communicating properly. He believes Shackleton is a good model for management because he was a strong leader and communicator. Shackleton always put the safety of his men first.
One important decision Shackleton made was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. He had to make this tough choice because they were running out of supplies and time. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While some managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take charge. 
In 1914, Shackleton's ship, the Endurance, got stuck in ice for nine months and was eventually crushed. When the ship sank, Shackleton told his men that they would be safe if they worked hard and trusted him. He always kept his men informed and asked for their opinions. Shackleton was flexible and ready to change plans if needed. 
MacGregor says that Shackleton believed an explorer needs to be optimistic, strong, and patient. He points out that in America, people often want quick solutions. For example, if you invest money and make a mistake, it is better to wait and see than to sell and lose a lot of money. Shackleton also led by example. When he saw a team member without gloves, he gave him his own, saying he would throw them overboard if he didn’t wear them. 
Caroline Alexander, who wrote a book about Shackleton's expedition, says that people today are looking for heroes. Shackleton shows that true heroism is rare now, and he represents the ideals that many people wish for today.

**Finding Food in Madagascar**
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is a primate, and it has a way of finding food that is similar to a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes in the wood and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to make holes and its long finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists have studied how aye-ayes find insects. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied three aye-ayes: two males named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might be.
Dr. Erickson made logs with small holes. Some holes had food inside, and some were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food. They did not need to see the holes to find the mealworms inside. They might have used their sense of smell or sound, but tests showed they did not need these either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked or when the mealworms were quiet.
So, how did the aye-ayes find the food? Dr. Erickson found that they could feel the empty spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and listens carefully. It seems to be able to hear the sound of the hollow wood and the movement of insects inside.
The aye-aye is interesting because it acts like both a woodpecker and a bat. It also has some behaviors like a squirrel. Its teeth keep growing, just like a squirrel's teeth. Recently, scientists saw an aye-aye in the wild eating nuts by gnawing through the shells and using its long finger to get the nut inside.

**Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**
Many of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like? We might have some old diaries or family stories, but they often do not tell us everything. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We want to write things down, but we often forget to do it. Sometimes we make videos instead of taking pictures, but videos are still not the same as real life.
Hannah Renier has a solution. She writes life stories for other people. She makes a book with at least 20,000 words and pictures if needed. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary people. Hannah got this idea when she talked to her family and saw that many stories from the past were being lost.
"When I started, I didn’t think it was very important," she says. "But then I met people who have interesting stories to tell. They want to share their lives for their children and for future generations, but they also enjoy it."
People feel safe to share their stories with Hannah. A 62-year-old man said, "I felt I could be honest. I talked about my divorce and the pain I still feel." He wrote his story for his family, but he hasn’t let his children read it yet. He thinks some parts might hurt them. He wants them to read it after he is gone.
Hannah has noticed that many people are affected by their childhood. "Many people repeat the same mistakes they made when they were young," she says. "They often marry people their parents liked or choose partners to rebel against their parents."
Many people still feel sad about things that happened with their parents many years ago. They try to impress parents who were never happy with them. Some people even want to say, "I can’t stand my mother."
Hannah listens to people’s stories without judging them. "I am not here to be nosy," she says. "People sometimes tell me things and then worry if I should include them. I usually do, but they can take things out later if they want."
Hannah’s books are not just for showing off. They help people remember their past. Today, life moves very fast, and we often forget our history. These books help people feel connected to their family history. 
Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Hannah uses these talks to write the life story, changing the order of events if needed. She can create everything for the book except the binding, which has gold lettering. People can choose the color and title of their book. 
Hannah’s books are well-made and cost nearly £3,000, with extra copies costing £25 each. She gets about 10 requests each week, but the price stops many people from buying. "I thought more people would want this," she says. "But the people I have worked with are often wealthy and like to read certain magazines."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over six hundred pieces in total. It is important to know that these sculptures are not real. They are copies made from the original sculptures, mostly made in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The Museum has a special gallery with good natural light. The plaster copies are useful because they allow people to see groups of sculptures that are now in different museums in Europe. You can see many famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has darkrooms for developing photos and a gallery for showing different photography works. We offer courses and workshops for everyone, including a Beginner's Course and special classes with guest photographers. Members can use the darkrooms. We also have a program for young photographers aged 12 to 16 to help them improve their skills. We sell photography books and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossils, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has the oldest geological collection in Britain, started by Dr. John Woodward. There are nearly 10,000 interesting specimens in old cabinets from the early 1700s. Adam Sedgwick was a professor of geology who helped grow the collection.
