The items are organized by age, so you can see how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery shows beautiful minerals and gems, with labels that explain what they are and how they are used today.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection has over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The university has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos all over Great Britain. These photographs show the landscape and how it has changed from ancient times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. You cannot borrow the photographs, but you can buy copies, which usually take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is one of the oldest and most unique tourist attractions in the area. Visitors can have fun making wall hangings by rubbing over one of the more than one hundred brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The centre makes resin copies to protect the original plates while allowing people to enjoy brass rubbing. These brass plates were used in Europe as memorials, but many were destroyed during revolutions. Most of the remaining plates are in Britain, and you can see many examples at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
A. **The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have enjoyed 35 years with small children. I loved feeding the baby this morning. For me, being a father is about love. I am very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This brings us close, especially now that they are older and I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have done it when I was angry, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the best father, but I always tried to be there for them. I wait for them to call me. If I ask them why they do not call, it makes them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I will not do it to my children.
B. **The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, about 25 years old. I found the responsibilities hard, but they also kept me young. As they became teenagers, they showed me new things like music and fashion. This helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young, like concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. But now, I can take them on holidays to nice places. They get along well with my friends and come to parties and work events without feeling scared. I think it is good that my job is interesting to them.
C. **The Politician**  
My first child was born just before I started my political career. My wife and I promised to spend time with our children, but my job takes a lot of time. I only go to meetings on weekends if my kids can come with me. This way, they can see what I do and do not feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed more politicians bringing their kids to work. Maybe we all want to include our children in our lives more.
D. **The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I had to think a lot about being a father. I tried hard to stay close to my children. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while, so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my kids like adults too soon. Kate said we were too relaxed with rules. I wish I had been stricter. I still worry about my older daughters just like I do about my youngest. In that way, you never stop being a parent.
E. **The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for kids when I turned 30. I met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new things?" Having my daughter, Betty, made me think about who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but when I see her smile, all my irritation goes away. A baby's smile is very powerful.

**THEATRE**
**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
This play by Marlowe is about a strong warrior. It is long, but the director Terry Hands makes it exciting. He cuts parts of the text to make it faster and more lively. Antony Sher plays the main character and does amazing things, like jumping from the balcony and sliding down a rope. He keeps the audience's attention with his powerful performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall is now in London after being shown in Manchester. The first part is tense as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second part, the story changes and shows the sad effects of illness. Michael Wall was a talented writer who died too young at 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is a new Irish playwright. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one talks about the problems in the fishing industry. It has strong characters, deep emotions, and some funny moments. The play can feel a bit slow at times, but it ends with a strong finish.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about a "perfect murder." Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play two crime writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar, but it has clever twists.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
**E. The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's funny play about tricksters from the 17th century. The show was first seen in Stratford and is now on the Barbican stage. Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce give great performances as the three con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**F. The Madras House**  
Peter James directs this comedy by Harley Granville Barker about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society. After a successful run at the Edinburgh Festival, it is now in London. The staging is stylish, the acting is great, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*
**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn tells a sweet version of Beauty and the Beast set in a London suburb. It has beautiful music by John Pattison and celebrates romantic love. This show is sure to be a hit!  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*
**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's funny play is not very good, but the actors Ron Cook and Anton Lesser give great performances. They play funny characters, even if the show itself is not very impressive.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important play by Granville Barker that is now touring. It tells the story of a lawyer who leaves a bad financial legacy to his son. It is a wonderful play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek**  
Emma and her friends are playing a game during the holidays. They are watching a strange bookshop when Emma sees her Uncle Jim. He tricks her and tries to make her not trust her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is locked in a dark cellar of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and that sometimes adults are not as safe as they should be. It is an important and interesting read.
**Backtrack**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together to find out what happened in a train accident in 1915 that killed eight people. They look at different documents like maps and personal stories to understand the accident. This book is clever and needs careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer**  
Mary Dyer feels different from her family. She loves her father's racing pigeons. When her father goes away for work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story teaches that there are many kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
In this story, a woman named Rose moves to a cottage with her two children to escape her unhappy life. They find a scary cat and strange things in the house. The locals do not like them, and their lives are in danger. By the end, the violence stops, but Rose is still worried about her son. This story is very exciting.
**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
Sam is a chubby and talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa. When Lisa's life becomes difficult, Sam helps her find balance. They both learn about family. The story is a bit slow in parts, but it has gentle humor and shows how the two teenagers grow closer. It can be interesting for both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium**  
Barry Faville writes a funny and interesting story set in New Zealand. Robbie works in the garden for an old man named Stanley. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is scared of him. When she discovers what is in his aquarium, the story becomes thrilling but still focuses on the characters and their relationships. It is unusual and engaging.
**Dodger**  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has problems with his family and school. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. Mick learns to deal with his low self-esteem through a school play and a caring teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a very emotional read, especially at the end.

**Science and Weightlessness**
Journalist Tom Mumford writes about students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The plane looked normal from the outside. The pilot said it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135, which is based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights on the walls. Most of the seats were taken out, except for a few at the back where the 13 students sat, looking nervous.
For a year, these students from Europe and America worked hard to join this special flight. The European Space Agency asked them to come up with creative experiments to do in weightlessness. The students with the best ideas got to go on this amazing flight, which felt like a big roller coaster.
For two hours, the plane flew up and down like a bird. The pilot turned off the engines at 3,000 meters, and the plane went higher for a moment before falling back down. During this time, everything inside the plane became weightless. The students felt like they were closer to the moon than to the Earth.
The plane took off smoothly, but things changed quickly when the pilot made the plane climb steeply. The engines roared, and the students felt heavy. Then, the engines stopped, and they floated in the air for 20 seconds. It felt like jumping on a trampoline. They floated around, and it was hard to know which way was up or down.
After 10 seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane up again. Gravity came back, and some students landed hard. They had 30 curves to go through, giving them 10 minutes of weightlessness for their experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released a device to help with this, and one student managed to turn it over.
Another team from Germany looked at how metal joins change without gravity, which is important for building space stations. A team from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films in microgravity. They think these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a yacht uses wind.
After two hours of flying, the students felt excited, not sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.
I had a strange time in my life when I did not have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is actually winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which was great because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was good for planting trees.
I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on farms, so planting trees sounded like a nice idea, and I was excited. My family also became excited as we went along. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the whole 70 acres together.
In New Zealand in 1968, it rained a lot during that winter. It is funny to think of it as a happy time because it rained almost every day we were planting. I don’t think I have ever been so wet and cold for so long. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready to plant again. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but the rain would be falling, and my clothes were still wet from the day before. My hands would struggle with slippery shoelaces. 
In that first year, I had a helper who was good at planting trees, which was helpful because I had never done it seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck and fill it with trees. When the bag is full, it is heavy, but when it gets lighter, it is easier to work. The hardest part was getting the lines straight for planting. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then you line up three poles to help you. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down and then come back.
I enjoy hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm and use fewer movements to dig the hole. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You learn to take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, put it in the ground, stamp it down, and move on. 
While planting, I had many thoughts about life and nature. A lot of my ideas about the natural world started during those days. I have been back to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is very satisfying because I planted them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me feel anxious. But everything worked out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.
I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months by myself. I wrote my first book there, *Seeing Green*. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees; and in the evenings, I did research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth.

**Taking Care of Badger Cubs**
One day, I was surprised when one of my helpers brought me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have a farm in Somerset where we take care of orphaned animals. I heard strange noises from the box, so I looked inside. I saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. They had soft fur and looked up at me with their milky eyes. I had never seen badger cubs before.
Most badger cubs are born between January and March and stay underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. These three cubs were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. Their mother was dead, but the cubs were alive. They were cold and crying. I took them to my kitchen to keep them warm. I named the two girls Primrose and Bluebell, and the boy Willow.
At first, I fed them with a syringe. I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to help them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. After a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around. They were happy with each other and a warm pad that acted like their mother.
Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was not as active, but he was still eating. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. It was important to feed him slowly, but I didn’t do that. I felt sad about losing him, but I continued to care for the other two cubs.
Then, a local farmer came to see me. He found another male cub that had been left by its mother. He brought the new cub, Willow II, to me. He was younger than Primrose and Bluebell. Feeding him was very hard. I had to move the bottle around to get him to drink. After a week, he learned to eat sausages, and soon he was eating other foods too.
By five months old, all the cubs were eating cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, nuts, cheese, and eggs. Badgers usually eat a lot of earthworms, but my badgers were doing well. The summer was hot, and it was hard for other badgers to find food.
By August, the cubs started to be active at night. We took walks in the orchard, and they loved to play. They would chase each other and have fun. I learned to avoid their playful bites, but Derek sometimes got caught and had colorful bruises.
One night, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food because they had to move to new areas. Badgers are very protective of their homes, so we put metal over the gate to keep them safe. The local newspaper took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help build a home for them.
With help from our son Daniel, we designed a new home for the badgers. It had tunnels and a special gate. Many local businesses helped us with materials. Finally, the badgers moved into their new home. I watched them settle in and soon saw them sleeping in their chambers.
Now, I don’t walk with them as often because they stay awake until midnight. Primrose has moved to another home, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before they run off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy.

**In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark is a researcher at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. But he also did important work by studying how compasses work. He used his sea trips on a warship called Paramore to find out about the "variations of the compass." These variations are now called "declination." Declination is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed this information to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans.
Halley was one of only two people in England paid to do scientific research at that time. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic. However, he had to stop the trip because of problems with his crew. Later, he went on another journey that took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a map called "New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans." This map helped sailors for many years until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing the route of the Paramore. He needs to raise £70,000 before he can start. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.
Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while he was at Halley Station in Antarctica. He read about Halley's life and said, "Halley led a remarkable life. He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics." Halley created a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.
Dr. Clark believes that recreating Halley's journey will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. He will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.
Dr. Clark explains, "It is common to measure the size of the magnetic field, but not the direction. You need to know true north to measure the direction." On this trip, they will use satellites to find true north. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the measurements. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his work will help fill in any gaps in the data.
Halley's journey was very important. It was the first scientific expedition at sea, and Halley was the first civilian to be a naval captain for this kind of work. 
Dr. Clark has the experience to make his trip successful. He spent two years in Antarctica and has worked at the British Geological Survey. He has already sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.
When asked if he is obsessed like Halley, Dr. Clark said, "I am ready to give up my life for eight months to do this. Some people might think I'm obsessed, but I want to have a good reason to sail across the Atlantic again. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**
Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show their beautiful feathers to the peahens. This behavior makes people think about a question that Charles Darwin wondered about: how can birds have such fancy feathers in a world where survival is tough? 
Darwin believed that animals change over time through evolution, not by special creation. He thought that the strongest animals survive and have babies. But he also thought that the peacock's tail was not useful for survival. So, he suggested another idea called "sexual selection." This means that female birds choose males based on their beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He believed that if peahens liked the males with the most beautiful tails, there must be a good reason for it. The tail might show something important about the male's ability to survive.
Now, 100 years later, scientists are still studying this. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people. Researchers, led by Marion Petrie, want to answer two main questions: Do peahens really choose the males with the most beautiful tails? And do these males have other qualities that help them survive?
The scientists watch the peacocks and peahens closely. They found that peahens do prefer the males with the most eye-spots on their tails. Males with more eye-spots attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these males are better in other ways.
William Hamilton from Oxford University thinks that male birds with beautiful feathers might be healthier and have fewer parasites. This idea has some support in other bird species, but the researchers have not yet tested this in the peacocks at Whipsnade.
This year, Dr. Petrie is studying the babies of attractive and unattractive males. She wants to see if the babies of the attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that females choose males for good reasons.
There is also an interesting idea from a mathematician named R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will have long tails, and her daughters will like long tails too. This could lead to more and more males with long tails over time. This idea shows that females might choose beauty for its own sake, just as Darwin thought.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe says the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He made this idea real with his own boat, called 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. 
In contrast, my boat is quiet and sits in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic for owning it. Maybe I am, but I don’t think so. My boat uses the best parts of old boat design, but it also uses modern technology to make it easier to build.
However, modern technology can sometimes keep sailors away from the real life at sea. Many sailors want to feel the sea and the wind, not just use machines. I don’t think sailors should go back to having a hard life, but I believe that some challenges, like dealing with sails, are part of sailing. 
A boat should feel like a boat, not a big house on the water. When I had my first boat, Hirta, I sailed around Britain for a TV show. The person I bought it from said it had comfort but no luxury. I learned he was right. Hirta had heavy sails and no modern comforts like running water, electricity, or a fridge, but she was easy and kind to sail.
On land, classic boats need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I knew I had to stop sailing Hirta. I looked for a younger boat but couldn’t find one, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. 'The Westerman' has never let me down. 
The designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, are good with computers, but Irens first drew the boat on a paper napkin. Then he made a model like boat builders did in the past. We worked together to improve the design. The final boat is perfect. 
'The Westerman' has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. It looks timeless, sails beautifully, and feels peaceful inside. This is because it was designed just for sailing, not for extra furniture. 
Made from special wood, it does not take in water. So, it has the good parts of a fiberglass boat but looks and feels like a real boat. This shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and sometimes it is good to learn from the past.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country hotels with spas are very popular now. Five journalists visited some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I went to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started to join classes like yoga and body conditioning. The teachers were very good. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They have many treatments, like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment made me feel like a new person. The staff were very friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to make some big changes this year, including a swimming pool. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a walk in the garden. I felt great when I left and I want to go back again. This is a perfect place for busy women. 
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
Shrubland Hall is a calm and relaxing place. When I arrived, I saw a big staircase and a nice library. Everyone gets a medical check-up when they arrive. They check your weight and blood pressure. I felt a bit strange being called a patient because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem and helped me with it in group and individual sessions. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry on the second day. My meals included grapefruit for breakfast, salads for lunch, and fruit and yogurt for dinner. If you don’t want to follow a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You can also have massages or water therapy on different days.
**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys Manor is not a health farm, but it is a nice old manor with cozy fires and a big lounge. If you want to lose weight, you might not enjoy the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and creamy desserts. The hotel has a gym and a pool to help you stay fit. There is also a spa, steam room, and treatment rooms. I got help for an old shoulder injury from a physiotherapist. Careys is comfortable and relaxing, and there is beautiful countryside to explore.
**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a beautiful country home and a five-star hotel. It treats guests very well. They offer health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, and horse riding. There are lovely walks and gardens around the estate. The restaurant, Waldo's, has amazing food. I enjoyed my meal, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. The next morning, I spent time in the gym before my next meal. I had a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options if you want them.
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
At Springs Hydro, the best and worst thing is the carrot cake. It is very delicious but has a lot of calories. The second best thing is the aromatherapy massage. I felt so relaxed that I fell asleep during the massage. The place is modern and well-organized, with many therapists and beauty rooms. There are many treatments available, like manicures and facials. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to friends and families. I would love to visit here every month.

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the last seven million years, humans and chimpanzees have changed very little. We are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very new. Our ability to create art and other things we think are special to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. 
Studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are also found in animals. For example, chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language with different sounds for different dangers, like 'leopard' or 'snake'. This means that besides art, there are not many clear differences between humans and animals.
But if our ability to create art comes from our genes, why did our ancestors not make art for almost seven million years? The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last long. We only have clear evidence of human art from about 35,000 years ago, like cave paintings and musical instruments.
Some people say that human art is different from animal art in three ways: 
1. Human art is not made for a purpose.
2. It is made for beauty and pleasure.
3. It is learned, not instinctive.
First, Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive like animal behaviors do. While some human art communicates ideas, it is not the same as passing on genes. Bird songs help birds find mates and protect their territory, which helps them survive.
Second, it seems that only humans create art for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during mating season, so they might not sing just for fun.
Third, human art is learned. Different human groups have their own art styles. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. People can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' song, even if they have never heard it before.
Human art changes quickly. For example, people can tell when a painting was made just by looking at it. In 1957, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy had an art show in London. Congo made many paintings and seemed to enjoy it. Their paintings were sold, which is something many human artists cannot do.
These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal behavior is not so clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not made for a specific purpose; they were created for the joy of painting. Some might argue that human art is different because it is meant to communicate, while the chimps did not care about sharing their art. However, some famous human art was also made just for the artist's own happiness.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on Earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed this desert and lived to tell his story.
In the past, stories for children were about brave explorers. These explorers had sunburnt skin and squinted their eyes to see far away. Today, we do not see such heroes in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Charles Blackmore led a group to cross the Taklamakan Desert. The name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of this amazing journey while sitting in his family home.
His team had four British people (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous for everyone.
The team set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He wanted to have fun and find out who he really was outside the Army. His wife, Tina, was worried he might not come back because no one had ever crossed that route before.
It took them 59 days to cross the desert, and Charles said the desert was very kind to them. But anyone who reads his story will wonder why he used the word "kind." The team faced many problems: they got sick, felt very hot and very cold, and lost some of their water. 
Charles said, "When we were very tired and the camels had not had water for seven days, we found some. We did not have the famous sandstorms of the Taklamakan. And we did not feel the freezing cold that could have stopped us." 
They had to fight against many challenges. The fine sand got into their wounds, and climbing the high dunes was hard for both the people and the camels. Charles said, "What pushed me to keep going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. We were completely alone in the sandhills."
He was scared about whether he could finish the trip. On the first day, he sat at the edge of the desert and thought it was so hot he could not breathe. He felt very scared.
After walking 1,000 kilometers, he and his team could not give up. They were very thin but strong. Charles said, "My legs were like pistons. I could walk over anything."
In the middle of his story, Charles described lying in the desert and looking at the full moon while thinking of his family. He wondered how hard it was for them. He said, "Inside me, I am trying to find peace. When I have doubts, I think of the desert and how we did it. I feel prouder of that trip than anything else I have done. But when I think of my family and our happiness, the desert does not compare."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? He said, "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We felt a strong purpose. Now, it is hard for me to be part of normal life."

Susan Harr is tired of technology. She decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it makes life easier. We think we need all these gadgets, but Susan is not so sure. 
One day, her word processor broke. She had to pay a lot of money to fix it. This made her think that gadgets can be more trouble than they are worth. She wonders if we really need technology to save time. Sometimes, it seems like we just use that time to buy more gadgets.
When her word processor started making strange noises, she put it outside. Now, she can take her time doing things by hand. She feels free and enjoys sewing. She used to be scared of electric sewing machines, but now she likes sewing by hand. 
Susan knows there are some gadgets that are helpful, like a washing machine. But she also found joy in not using some gadgets. For example, she returned her color TV and now watches a small black-and-white TV. This helps her spend more time walking her dog, reading, and talking with family.
Sewing by hand is relaxing for Susan. She can listen to the radio or talk with friends while she sews. She feels good sitting by the fire with a cup of tea. She used to think sewing by hand was hard work, but now she finds it enjoyable. 
Doing things by hand helps her slow down and enjoy life more. She also likes washing dishes by hand and daydreaming while she does it. Now, she looks around her house and wonders if she really needs all her gadgets, like the freezer or microwave. She thinks they might not be necessary and that she could save money by not using them.

'Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" He seems busy, and his workshop is full of furniture pieces and wood in many colors. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and is well-known for his work. He has many orders and does not need to advertise. People say that if you want a good cupboard, table, or bookcase, you should go to Hurst.
It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is harder to find one who makes high-quality furniture. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people just call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed with the quality of modern furniture. He does not like cheap, mass-produced furniture and wants to make perfect pieces. This desire for perfection helps him succeed.
Hurst is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned by asking questions and practicing. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some come back for more. He enjoys doing complete projects for their homes. However, he finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want.
Hurst is also kind and praises others when they deserve it. He says, "There are people far better than me." He does not like it when craftsmen take too long to make one piece or when students try to make their work look fashionable. He believes furniture should be useful, not just a statement.
Hurst is confident but also humble. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture." This shows his down-to-earth attitude towards his work.'

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. But, scientists do not agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main ideas.
The first idea is that sleep helps our bodies stay healthy. When we sleep, our bodies fix any damage from the day and get ready for the next day.
The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us understand and remember what we learned during the day. Without sleep, it would be hard to learn new things.
The third idea is about energy. This idea says we need sleep to recharge our energy. When we sleep, we get ready for the next day and have enough energy to do our activities.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, someone might love to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to the newspaper about many topics. Being eccentric shows our uniqueness.
Inside us, there is often a struggle between wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. It is like having two trains on the same track, pushing against each other. One train is called individualism (being yourself) and the other is conformity (fitting in). Most of the time, we want to fit in more than we want to be different. We want to be accepted and liked by others.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs and hold meetings to talk about what they enjoy or their problems. They want to be with others who understand them, even if others think their interests are strange. Being in a group can make us feel better.
We all feel a mix of wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. Even when we follow the crowd, we might not like it if someone says we are doing that. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," to show he is different. 
Anyone can choose to be more individualistic at any time. Many people succeed in their jobs by being themselves. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you feel what you are doing and go after it, you will surprise many people." But being different does not always mean being eccentric. 
For example, if a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, that is not eccentricity. But if they keep doing it until it becomes part of who they are, then they are eccentric. The key to being eccentric is being natural. Eccentrics do not try to be strange; they just are.
True eccentrics do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress others or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives happily, no matter what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four nature experts to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy for me to choose the author. I am an environmental journalist, and I have met many important people in this field. One of them is Barbara Ward. She is a small, frail woman, but she has done a lot for environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own strong ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand everything better. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think her most important book is "The Home of Man." This book talks about the fast growth of cities in the world and important themes she cared about. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of seagulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book explains very well, with words and pictures, how animals communicate. If you read "Signals for Survival" and then watch a group of seagulls, you will see how their busy activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a great scientist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with a talented wildlife artist, Eric Ennion, to create this book. Eric's paintings show how one gull can be aggressive and how another can be calm. This is the work of a true nature expert.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband but also to a great career in conservation. It made me love the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read this book. I had been there for two years and was feeling sad because of many problems. But when I opened "My Family and Other Animals," I felt happy again. The book shows animals and people together, creating a beautiful world worth saving. Some people say humans are bad because of what we have done to nature. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially to the 48 colorful bird pictures by Eric Ennion. These beautiful images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start drawing what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" had so much more. It included wonderful paintings, chapters about bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter about birds in music and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. It showed me that my feelings and creativity about nature are just as important as scientific knowledge. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

**Do Reviews Sell Books?**
We asked five British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in newspapers. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or displays in shops. Authors feel sad when there are no reviews. Publishers also feel bad about bad reviews, but they think any review is good because it gets people talking about the book. Sometimes, both good and bad reviews can help sell books because readers want to see for themselves. Publishers like reviews that match their own feelings about a book.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both want good book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed well. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help readers find out about books and authors. A good review from a trusted source can really help sell a book.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Without them, we would struggle. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we rely on reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are often more valuable than ads because they show the reader that the review is honest. Publishers say they want big reviews, but the real effect of reviews on sales is hard to understand. Good reviews can help a book and an author become popular, but they need help from other things like recommendations and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I am not sure how publishing and reviewing work together in Britain. In the United States, a single review can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews still sell very well. It is hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction books allow reviewers to talk more about the subject than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they help sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it did not sell well because people thought they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people listened. Now, sometimes an unexpected reviewer or a clever review can make people want to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith continues this craft in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates special designs for his customers. He says, "This way, I can make a unique gift." Many of his customers are women who want to buy special presents for their husbands. They look for gifts that show the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel, which is the most common design. It was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. He realized he could make many different designs. So, he decided to start a weathervane business.
Before this, Graham worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed their roles. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of their children and grow the business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic. I love designing."
Graham has made over 100 original designs. He pays attention to detail and always asks the customer to approve the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps some traditional designs because they are still popular. Graham believes people like handmade items because they are different.
He does not want to grow his business too much because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. He says, "I have found my place in the market. People enjoy unique items, and I feel good when I see a simple shape become something special."
For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing changes in the wind. Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want to add special touches to their homes. This has helped crafts like Graham's.
Graham is now very busy, sending weathervanes to customers all over the world. He has many buyers from America and Denmark. He explains that the price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. He shares his story about how he got inspired and became successful.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was not doing well. A film he had been working on called *Life and Limb* fell apart very quickly. He was sad and worried because he had not earned money for two years. He needed that film to help him with his bank problems. A smart person in his situation would have found a job. He could have gone back to working in television. But instead, he did something many people would think was crazy. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.
Nicholas had an idea for his story from a farrier he met while visiting a friend. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became very wild. The owners were worried until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These special people are called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Nicholas. He wanted to write a movie about it, but after his film project failed, he decided to write a book instead.
During the spring, he drove around the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about his life. He had tried for ten years to be a filmmaker, but now he was in debt and unsure how to support his family.
By the end of August, he returned home and had written the first half of the book. His bank manager was becoming very strict, and he needed to know if he should continue writing. He showed his work to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Nicholas could get $30,000 for the book. Nicholas needed more money to pay off his debts. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had two months of work left.
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of his book to seven publishers in the UK. Soon, his agent called to say that they had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Nicholas was shocked. His agent felt something good was going to happen.
A week later, after a lot of interest, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. These were record amounts for a first novel. Nicholas and his team could not believe it. They had not even sent the book to New York, but soon major film studios wanted to make a movie from it.
Nicholas was surprised when his agent said they could get $3 million for the movie rights. He and his team laughed in disbelief. That October night, four famous filmmakers called him one after the other, asking to pay $3 million for his unfinished book.
Nicholas shared this story while we drank coffee on his porch at home. He said he turned down an offer to write the movie script for *The Horse Whisperer*. He felt it was like a fairy tale and did not want to ruin it. Writing for movies is hard work, and he did not want to be just an employee. He wanted to stay involved but keep some distance.
The success of his novel also brought new interest in making *Life and Limb*, but now he was not sure if he wanted to do that. He said, "I think I would be foolish not to write another novel."

**Young Masters**
Bobby Fischer is trying to come back to chess, but he is not as young as before. Chess is now a game for younger players. After being away from chess for 20 years, Bobby Fischer is playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, and it was a great game. But he is now 49 years old, not in good shape, and not used to playing. Spassky is also older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Bobby Fischer helped make chess popular, and now there are many professional players. Today, the main goal for players is to win. In international chess, a player needs to be strong mentally and physically. The game is very intense. Players have a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time. If they do not, they lose the game. Now, games can last longer, and players often do not take breaks. This makes it harder for older players.
In the last 30 years, every new world champion has been younger than the last. Most of the top ten players in the world are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Many players prepare before their matches. Computers help players study many games and find weaknesses in their opponents. In one recent match, players had teams of helpers looking for mistakes in each other’s games. The start of a chess game is very important, and being well-prepared can decide the winner.
Today, there are more great chess players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Playing chess is hard work. A game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. If they lose concentration, they can lose the game. The chess clock adds to the pressure. At the end of a game, players often rush to make their moves in a “time scramble.” They have only a few seconds to move, and it can be very stressful.
For top players, losing is very painful. Winning feels great, but one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to compete again the next day. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. World championship matches are even harder. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov had to stop after several months because both players were too tired. Karpov lost a lot of weight during the match.
Can Bobby Fischer succeed again? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long break from chess surprising. If he is back for the money, he will earn a lot. No matter what happens in his match with Spassky, they will both make millions of dollars. But if Fischer believes he can still be the best player, he might be very disappointed in the end.

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso is a man in his early 30s. He has written three plays that many people like. Now, he is turning his first play, called *Peaches*, into a movie script. He says, "It is a low budget, but I don’t know how low. It will not be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented, but the surprising thing is that before he wrote *Peaches*, he had never been to a play or read one. He says, "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed. It is set in a car. I probably wouldn’t do that now because I know it is hard to do." He left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He realized he wanted to write for actors. He wanted people to hear his writing because of its rhythm and rhyme. He says, "I was finally with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed learning."
**B** Simon Pegg is 28 years old and has worked hard in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is now writing a comedy series for television and has just finished a tough tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard. Even in Bristol, he practiced his comedy in clubs. He remembers, "University was very theoretical. I realized I didn’t want to be a serious actor; I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn’t. If you have courage and good material, it is great to make people laugh." He has worked with the comedy group Funny Business, but his best work has been with Steve Coogan. Simon says, "He saw my show, and I was a big fan of his. He could see I was copying him."
**C** Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous when he danced on TV in the show *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. People liked his performance, and now he can choose what work he wants to do. He says, "It has been a great chance for me. I can pick and choose what I do, which is what I always wanted." Ciaran has only just finished school, but he has been acting for a long time. His mother encouraged him to act, and he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He laughs and says, "I used acting to avoid doing homework. But then I decided I wanted to be serious about it because I loved it." Now, he is waiting for more praise, but he thinks about fame and says, "When you are 18, you think you will love the photos and interviews, but you realize it is not why you act. It is about getting respect for good work."
**D** Neil Taylor is 25 years old and is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They have just signed a deal to make three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very popular when their single, *Chimera*, comes out soon. Neil says, "The record company has different ideas about success than I do. They want a big hit, but I just want two people to buy it." Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for many years. He says, "It is funny how things happen. I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections in the music industry." This meeting was very important for him. He says, "There were times when I was very sad, and I was in some bad bands. But I hope it will all be worth it."
**E** Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has won many awards for his poetry. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been giving readings for six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. He says, "It is a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I could not write as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but later did not like school. He decided not to go to university but later got bored with a job at a theatre and changed his mind. After university, he published his first book, a children's book, in 1992. He says, "My parents did not think I would be a writer; they thought I would just read because that is all I did as a child." Now, with his poetry being praised, he is brave to write novels. He explains, "Poetry has a structure, but a novel can be any length. There are more chances to write bad words. My main goal is to not just write a lot without caring about quality."

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student. She thinks she looks good in jeans, but she rarely wears them because she does not want to meet the wrong people. Isabel wants to find the right man, but she worries that her knees are not nice enough. Still, she has hope, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a fun and lively way, using chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."
B. This story is about a local radio station in America. It is told from the view of a smart child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT Radio, which was started by two men, Roy and Ray, to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays music and has different people talking. The author uses humor and simple writing to take readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old stores and classic cars.
C. In this story, a second husband talks to his wife's first husband. Richard Vaisey, a professor, falls in love with a Russian poet. The poet writes bad poetry, which makes Richard feel guilty. She also wants his help for her brother, who is in prison. The author tells this story in a funny and clever way, making it enjoyable to read.
D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends, two women and two men, are connected for 25 years. At the start of the story, James Hudson, a rich American, is starting a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. This is important, but so is the fact that a woman they both loved was killed years ago. The story has murder, love, and jealousy, and the writing is good. It is a long book where you can really get to know the characters.
E. This story is written by a great American author. It is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he takes care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming a strange bachelor. The story shows the strong bond he forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and funny book that balances sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers talk about international volunteer work.
A. It is hard to say that volunteer work helps a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If this money went directly to a local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can give. This is especially true for gap years, where volunteers often do not need special skills or experience. Many studies ask if young people volunteer to help others or if they want to improve their own careers. However, these projects can help people learn to act kindly towards those who have less.
B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better. It can also help solve problems and create connections between people from different countries. When this happens, both the volunteers and the communities they help can benefit. But if only rich people can volunteer, it may help them in their careers but not help the communities that need it most. Volunteers may use their experiences to get ahead in life.
C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to feel good about themselves without really helping. It can also be a way to give real help to communities. At its best, volunteering can help both the volunteers and the communities. It can also make people more aware of the problems of poverty and injustice in the world.
D. Volunteer tourism fits with the idea of helping others. This idea can seem good, especially when people do not trust big governments or businesses. However, it can also ignore the need for real change in poor communities. While volunteering is often a good thing, when it is sold as a way to help develop communities, it can make people forget about the real issues of poverty and inequality in the world.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need an alarm to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one?
A group of us, including the inventor Tom Granger and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios. One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. But who really needs two alarms? This model costs about the same as another one we tested. It has a cassette player, so you can listen to your own music and wake up to a quiet morning. We all liked the radio quality, but it is very big, like a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "I need space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn’t work."
This model was voted the best. Paul Bridges loved it, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 4:00 PM. I liked the digital display with nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can hit it easily when you are still half asleep. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, and I ended up pressing them too much, which made it hard to understand the instruction booklet.
The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. But setting it up was tricky. Tom Granger thought another model with a built-in lamp was poorly made. He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work. The light was hard to adjust, and you couldn’t read by it.
Paul Bridges found the lamp funny but agreed that tuning the radio was difficult. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm, which made me want to throw it across the room. Still, this model is very popular with young people because it looks bright and fun. Tom Granger said, "I would choose this one because it stands out." This model was the easiest to set up without reading the instructions. But the alarm could go off 10 minutes early or late, which Paul Bridges thought was silly. He said this model was "very annoying" and "useless."
The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easier to set up. He said, "With modern buttons, you are never sure if you pressed them right." We all agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. You can find hedgehogs in many parts of the world, but they are not in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are in danger. Their spines point outwards to protect them. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has.
Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling into a ball. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They like to sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. 
All hedgehogs can hibernate, which means they can sleep for a long time in winter. But not all hedgehogs do this. Some will stay awake all year if the weather is good.

**Great Sportswomen Winning Awards**
It is hard to be good at any sport, even for men, but women have to work even harder. Training and competitions take a lot of time, so they must make sacrifices. Despite this, they are proving people wrong and breaking records. Here are some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.
A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love skiing! It feels great to jump in the air and land safely, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel well or the weather is bad, but I keep going. I train for ten months each year, so I don’t have much time for friends. There are six men and three women on the British team, and we all compete together."
B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and I won! I was surprised because I had never cycled before. Now, I earn good money as a professional cyclist. I train for at least four hours every day, plus I do some stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."
C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because not many schools have rowing teams. Most girls start when they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. We often have new coaches, so it can be confusing. But I enjoy it and like being fit, plus I have fun with my teammates."
D. **Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I didn’t know how big it was! Walking across Australia was very painful. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters on my feet. But I set a record! Some people think women are less likely to succeed, so it is harder to get sponsors."
E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men think they are better drivers. When I do well, they ignore me. Being a woman in racing can be tough. Men often want to beat me, and I have had many accidents. It is hard to earn money, and I spend what I make on racing. More women are starting to race now, which is great!"
F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 AM three days a week to swim. I need to sleep more on other days. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Sometimes I feel very tired! Racing is exciting, but it can be stressful. Men and women usually compete together, but the news often talks more about the men. The prize money for women is not as good, but we are working to change that."

**The Day I Met Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso. He was 78 years old and saw Picasso while he was eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes. Even from far away, Picasso was easy to recognize. 
At that time, I was an 18-year-old student. I was traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money, so I found a job painting boats. But I spent a lot of time drawing. I was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.
Picasso was known to stay away from people and work in the hills. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife and friends. I was nervous, but I asked him for his signature. To my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name on my paper and then drew some lines on it. The lines might have looked like clouds or waves in the sea.
I thanked him and tried to talk to him. Picasso did not speak much English, and I did not speak much French. An American woman at the table helped us talk. She called him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. But I told Picasso that I loved art and admired his work.
After a while, I went back to my boat and showed my friend the signature. He asked, "Is that all?" He told me to go back and talk to Picasso again. So, I took my sketchbook and returned to Picasso's table. I didn’t ask if I could draw his portrait because I was afraid he would say no. Instead, I just started to draw.
When Picasso saw me drawing, he smiled and made funny faces to distract me. He rolled his eyes and stuck out his tongue. It was hard to draw him, but I felt like he wanted to see how determined I was. After a few minutes, he stopped making faces and let me draw him quietly.
I noticed how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He looked much younger than 84 years old. His dark eyes were very bright and full of life. Even though he was with friends, he seemed to be in his own world, quietly thinking.
The American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing. I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, so I showed him my sketch. He nodded and then said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he drew a face in just a few seconds. His drawing was very different from mine. He made my eye look like it was on my nose and drew my smile with one quick line.
I looked like a character from one of his fun drawings. I thanked Picasso and asked him to sign my drawing. The American woman said he said I already had his signature. So, he didn’t want to give me another one. 
I think back to that day and feel very lucky. Meeting Picasso and having his attention meant a lot to me.

**Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that shops use to make you spend more money.
**A. Freshness First**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that makes the smell of fresh bread fill the store. The colors in the store, like green, can make you think of fresh food. But most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen food and cleaning products, is not fresh.
**B. Smart Placement**  
Where products are placed in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out where shoppers look for items the most. They put popular products in these places. Items at eye level are more likely to be bought. Special offers in big bins can also attract shoppers. Sometimes, stores place items that go well together, like ice cream and dessert toppings, near each other.
**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place basic items like bread, tea, and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers have to walk past other tempting products. Stores may also put popular items far away, hoping that loyal customers will look for them and see other products on the way.
**D. Less is More**  
Some chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, Next stores show fewer clothes on the shelves, making them seem special. Even though they sell many clothes, their store design makes them look unique.
**E. Total Costs**  
Shoppers often care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items to attract customers. They sometimes sell basic items at a loss to bring people in, which is called "loss leaders." They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in large amounts.
**F. Price Tags Matter**  
In chain stores, shoppers usually buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This also helps reduce theft because staff must ring up sales to give change.
**G. Lighting**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so shoppers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh fruits and vegetables look better.
**H. Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the paths through the store, and another shows sales areas. This helps shoppers move through the store, but some may not want to explore the sales areas.
**I. In-Store Ads**  
When you enter a supermarket, you often see big pictures of delicious food. In some places, supermarkets are trying out "video trolleys" that show ads while you shop. These trolleys aim to catch the attention of shoppers and can increase sales by about 30%.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington is a famous mountaineer. He is 58 years old and is best known for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also made new climbing paths in Britain and the Alps. Chris has written many books, like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way."
Robin Knox-Johnston is 53 years old. He started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his boat called Sunhaili. He also set a record for sailing from New York to England in just 10 days.
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland. They wrote a book about their trip called "Sea, Ice and Rock." In 1979, Chris was working on "Quest for Adventure." He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to go sailing. Chris could teach Robin some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris about sailing. This was Chris's first time on a yacht.
They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin went to the shore to practice climbing. The climb was hard, but Chris was impressed with how steady Robin was. When they reached a big drop, Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to do it. Robin wanted to climb down using ropes like on his boat, but Chris wanted him to use his legs. Robin did it safely, but Chris felt a bit worried.
During this trip, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they go on a bigger trip to Greenland together. Robin was a good leader. He asked everyone for their opinions before making decisions. Chris found sailing boring and hard. He liked being on land more than being at sea. Robin, however, loved sailing and fixing things on the boat.
When they reached Greenland, Chris had to lead the climbing expedition. He felt nervous about keeping Robin safe. Climbing the highest mountain in Greenland, called the Cathedral, was very hard. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours. On the way down, they were very tired and almost fell asleep on steep slopes. Robin trusted Chris and followed him. When it became too difficult, they decided to turn back. Robin was also worried about their boat and if it would be okay.
The only time they had a problem was on the way home. They took turns watching the boat. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am, but Robin did not wake him. Robin thought he could handle it alone. Chris felt that Robin did not trust him, and he told him so. Robin quickly reassured Chris that he was wrong to think that.
They enjoyed their trip to Skye, but they really got to know each other during the Greenland expedition. Chris learned that Robin was a kind and sensitive person, even if he seemed tough on the outside.

**A Simple History of the Apple**
Apples have been around for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of the old types of apples.
**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples since ancient times. In Britain, they threw away apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, people left apple parts near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these places, ancient people stored wild apples for winter. These apples were small and different from the apples we eat today.
**Learning from the Normans (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. Some apples, like the dessert apple called Decio, came from the Romans. But many Roman apples did not grow well in Britain. British monks started to grow new types of apples.
**Popular Apples in the Middle Ages (1200)**  
In the 1200s, many apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a common dessert apple. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. But bad weather and diseases made it hard to grow apples, so people started to import them. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent a man to France to learn more about growing apples. This man brought back many new apple types.
**Apples in New Lands (1750)**  
By the 1600s, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. A man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees in North America and became famous for it.
**New Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new type of apple from a dead tree. He named it 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and said it was 'Delicious'. This apple became very popular.
