Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She worked hard on her family’s farm and discovered a small tree growing from old fruit. She took care of it, and soon it produced green apples that became famous.
**Modern Apples (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. However, most apples come from just a few types that are chosen for their looks and how well they travel, not for their taste. Many old apple types are disappearing. In the UK, some gardeners keep old apples alive, but in the US, many types are lost forever. People want more variety in apples. We should all help to keep different types of apples safe for everyone.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide is a travel company that offers exciting trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique places and interesting activities. Our brochure has over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
We travel in small groups, usually with about 16 people. This makes it easier to learn about the places we visit. You will have a chance to meet local people and experience their culture. It is a fun experience for everyone.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport on our trips. You might travel by bus, train, boat, or even on foot. Each trip is different and shows you the local area in a special way.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who like to try new things. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for anyone who is healthy, fit, and open to new experiences. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. About half are couples, and the rest are solo travelers.
**Activities and Interests**
Every trip with Explore Worldwide is unique. We have divided our adventures into 8 categories based on activities and interests. Each category highlights special experiences you can have on the trip. 
**Cultural/Adventure Trips**
Many of our trips focus on culture. You can visit places with rich history, like Egypt, Jordan, Greece, and India. Some trips include short walks to see less-known sites.
**Wildlife and Nature**
Our wildlife safaris take you to amazing parks to see animals in their natural homes. In Africa, you can even walk outside your vehicle to explore. You might track gorillas in Zaire or canoe on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some have hotels.
**Meeting Local People**
A special part of our trips is meeting local tribes and ethnic groups. You can learn about their cultures and ways of life. We travel in small groups to help promote understanding and respect between different cultures.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Some trips include easy walks in beautiful countryside. You can stay in hotels or local homes. These trips are available in places like Spain, Greece, and Thailand. Your main luggage is carried by others, so you only need a small bag for the day.
**Major Treks**
For strong walkers, we offer challenging treks in high mountains. You might stay with local people or camp in beautiful areas like the Himalayas or the Alps. We provide support, so you don’t have to carry heavy bags.
**Wilderness Adventures**
Exploring remote areas is an exciting experience. You can visit places like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These trips offer a chance for real adventure.
**Sailing and River Journeys**
We also have relaxing trips on boats. You can sail in Egypt or travel between islands in Greece and Thailand. Our river trips can be short or long, and you don’t need any experience. Safety training is provided, and you can enjoy the beautiful scenery.
Explore Worldwide offers many ways to travel and discover the world. Join us for an unforgettable adventure!

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners in his country. He visits a training camp in Kenya, which is ten miles south of the equator. There is a mountain path that starts from a quiet road in Nairobi. This path leads to Mount Kenya, the highest mountain in Kenya. The place is called Nanyuk, and it has been Richard's training base for three years. 
On his fourth trip to Kenya, Richard decided to train with Kenyan runners. He ran in his first race in Kenya, where the air has less oxygen. He stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for competitions. Richard was invited by the national team coach after he finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race.
Training at high altitude helps runners because it makes more red blood cells, which helps carry oxygen. Many Kenyan runners have been successful because of this. Richard's first race in Africa was in Nairobi. It was the first international cross-country race in Africa. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan. He felt he ran well, but he knew that Kenyan runners are not just successful because of the altitude. They have a simple and relaxed way of running and enjoy competing.
Richard learned how Kenyan runners train at their camp. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. The athletes live with regular students in simple rooms. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the afternoon. They start their day at six in the morning. The coach tells them to run easy because they have a hard day ahead. They run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers.
Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they drive to a stream to wash off in the evening.
By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are so successful. It is not just because of their genes or the altitude. He thought that the simple life in the mountains, hard training, and their love for running are important reasons for Kenya's success in long-distance running.

The Problems of Advertising**
Many people know that advertising is not doing well. This is not just because of the economy. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the economy got bad. The problems with advertising are serious and happen all over the world. 
Advertising has not changed with the economy. Advertisers think about big groups of people and big media, but now there are many brands and types of media. Because of this, the groups of people they want to reach are smaller. Even big brands should try to reach smaller groups, but they usually do not.
Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands. You might buy a few brands that you see in ads, but you will not buy many different brands in a year. You might only buy about 400 different brands in a year, even though there are many more brands advertised.
For example, there are about 32,500 brands and services that are advertised. But most people only buy a small number of them. This means that a lot of advertising is not effective. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. Most people find that they only buy about 1 out of every 16 brands they see in ads.
Many people think they are different and that they do not pay attention to ads. But the truth is, most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. There is always waste in advertising because not everyone will buy the products they see. 
Even though advertising can be expensive, it can still work. Advertisers need to reach many people to find the few who will buy their products. They cannot know in advance who will respond to their ads. 
With better targeting, advertisers can reach more people who will respond, but they can never know for sure who will buy. This is different from selling face-to-face, where a salesperson can talk to each person directly. 
If an advertiser can get one million new customers, that is a good result. For many products, getting just 2% of the population to buy is a big success. To make advertising work better, it needs to be more focused on the right people.

Charles Clover visits a very eco-friendly home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This town has some interesting places. One is Southwell Minster, a little-known old cathedral. It has special carvings of 'green' men made by craftsmen in the 1200s. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 
The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking. They recycle their waste into compost for their garden. They also heat their home using heat from their appliances and their own bodies, along with their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the old buildings in the town and was approved by planners.
When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, it is very quiet inside. The house is well-insulated with special windows, so you cannot hear anything. Inside, it is calm and peaceful. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens special windows to let in fresh air. They have made sure there are no drafts, even for their cats.
The Vales teach architecture at Nottingham University and have cared about the environment for a long time. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called The Autonomous House. They wanted to build a house that does not produce carbon dioxide. They also decided to not use mains water. They created special toilets and have rainwater tanks in the cellar. They use copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean, which they filter before using. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they think strong detergents are bad for the environment.
Robert says they want to show that it is possible to build a house that is good for the environment without living in darkness. The only old-fashioned part of the house is the hall, which has a fireplace and a staircase that goes up to the top. The Vales do not pay for water, and last winter, they used only nine units of electricity a day, which costs about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use.
Soon, they will add solar panels to generate more electricity. The house will still use some electricity from the mains for cooking and appliances, but it will make extra electricity. One day, they hope to charge an electric car with it. The only heating is a small wood stove in the hall, which they only use when it is very cold. 
When Charles visited in February, Robert said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature was 18C, which is lower than usual, but Robert said it felt comfortable because there were no drafts. He explained that people in the past were comfortable at lower temperatures because of their warm clothing. 
The house is simple and easy to maintain. Most materials were bought from local shops and installed by local workers, making it cheap to build. It cost the same as low-cost rental housing. Because of this, big building companies do not like this idea.

'The Camera Never Lies
Arthur Conan Doyle was the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories. He thought he was a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies in a garden. He believed these photos were proof that fairies really existed. He published the photos with an article, saying fairies are wonderful creatures.
In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked very nice, but the trick was simple. This goes against a common idea that cameras always show the truth. 
Today, we can use computer programs to change our digital photos. It is a myth that photography has always been completely honest. From the beginning, when cameras started taking pictures, the reality was changed.'

**Blacksmiths**
For a long time, iron has been very important to people, and blacksmiths, who work with iron, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The lovely metalwork in French and Belgian buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths.
However, by the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain because heavy industry did not need them anymore. Modern architects often did not use beautiful ironwork like handrails. In the last 10 years, there has been a small comeback for blacksmiths because more people are interested in decorative buildings and new styles of interior design. Still, much of the work looks similar, with many companies calling their products "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find many trendy stores selling rusty candlesticks with extra pieces.
Fortunately, there are new events to support blacksmiths. The first event is an exhibition of ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). It opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We might be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently now." Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal. They can now bend, twist, and weld metal more easily. Dawson says, "These artists can now use metal to show their creativity."
About 250 pieces of work are in the show, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the artists, but some will be kept by the Association to help promote good ironwork. Dawson has made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says, "My style comes from letting steel bend and shape when it is hot. It’s like drawing with metal."
Many artists love working with iron. Unlike other metals, iron is hard and strong. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It’s magical because it is soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard again." Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles that look like they belong in scary castles. One design looks like a ball and chain, and another looks like a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever." Iron has given people a lot of beauty and a sense of safety. It is likely that iron will be used for decoration for many years to come, as long as we do not have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Stopped Smoking**
I thought my friends would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She asked, "What do you mean? If it was easy, why didn’t you stop before?" I found it hard to explain how I went from smoking a lot every day to not smoking at all in just a few hours. 
Two months and three weeks ago, I went to a stop-smoking session. I did not plan to stop smoking, and I did not really want to. I felt pressure from people who do not like smoking, and I still feel that way. I also have low blood pressure and a healthy family. I did not feel sick or cough like some of my friends who try to be very healthy.
On that Thursday afternoon, I went to the session in Birmingham to write an article about people trying to quit smoking. I said, "I will not try to stop. I am here to write, not to quit." I thought this was a good reason. I enjoyed smoking and it made me happy.
During the session, we could smoke as much as we wanted. The room was full of smoke, and we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I did not want to. The messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. The idea of not being a smoker began to feel good. I felt strong and powerful. 
Stopping smoking was not very hard. The desire for nicotine went away after a few minutes and only lasted for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was not a problem at all. I was surprised that the hardest part was doing things at home on weekend mornings. I realized that smoking helped me not feel bored. 
I do miss smoking a little, but not too much. Now, I have to deal with new experiences as a non-smoker, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a break at the theater. These are moments when I would have smoked before.

Dorothy Hodgkin is an important British woman scientist. She won the Nobel Prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. For four years, I have asked my friends if they know about her. If they do, they pass my test. 
Dorothy Hodgkin is special because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. If someone in literature won a Nobel Prize, everyone would know their name. Dorothy died in 1994, and she was a very interesting person. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like better education for women and the growth of science around the world.
When I started to learn more about her, I wanted to read biographies of other scientists. A friend told me about a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a friend of Dorothy. He was also a famous scientist and won Nobel Prizes for chemistry and peace. I went to a bookshop, but I could not find any books about him. I was surprised that people did not find him interesting, even though he was very important.
Some scientists think that biographies are not interesting. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, said that the lives of scientists are often boring. If scientists think this way, it is not surprising that publishers and bookshops feel the same. Many scientists do not want to share their personal lives, which makes it hard for people to connect with them. 
However, some scientists are now showing their personalities. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on TV, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars. These activities help people see scientists as real people, not just researchers.
The way we write about scientists is also changing. In the past, biographies were often boring and focused only on their work. But now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show that scientists can have interesting lives outside of their work. 
Dorothy Hodgkin worked hard in science. She discovered the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1964. She also helped find the structure of insulin in 1969. She had three children and a husband who was often away for work. Her personal life is important, and we can learn from how she balanced everything.
Dorothy loved science, and this was the most important part of her life. It can be hard to explain scientific ideas to people because they may not know enough about science. But understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language. 
It is sad that many educated people do not know about great scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists.

**Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**
Margaret Wilkins has a special ability. She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers need her help because their wells have dried up. Margaret and her husband have a well-drilling business. They use machines like drilling rigs, but Margaret only needs her hazel stick to find water. They are very successful, with a success rate of over 90%.
This ability to find water is called dowsing. Some people think it is a special skill, while others think it is a natural ability. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers say they can feel or smell water when they are above it.
Recently, many farmers have needed Margaret's help because of dry weather. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, "We see customers only once in a lifetime because wells last a long time." Some customers have holiday homes far from water pipes, and others are building golf courses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She must be careful to avoid any waste getting into the water. The water she finds is usually clean, but she has to be careful because some areas have minerals like iron.
To find water, Margaret first looks at a map of the area. She uses a pendulum, which is a weight on a string. She holds it over the map, and it swings when she is above water. After that, she walks in the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill.
Margaret holds the stick with both hands. If water is below, the stick rises. It is very important to drill exactly where the stick points. If they are not sure, she and her husband will keep looking until they agree on the spot.
Margaret's ability is not just a local tradition. Many people are interested in how she finds water. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special way of understanding her surroundings. Thanks to her skill, she and her family can continue their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**
Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something new! We helped four people do this. Here are their stories.
**A. Amanda's Story**
Amanda is 23 years old and has two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. 
Amanda had never been in a place like this before. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from her hometown, and she felt nervous. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was even harder! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. Other waitresses made it look easy, but Amanda dropped the drinks on the floor. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said it was okay. 
When the restaurant opened, there was already a line of customers. Amanda worried about remembering their orders, but the computer helped her. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. She often had to say "Pardon?" when customers spoke to her, which made her feel shy. By the end of her shift, she was very tired and wanted to relax her feet. One waitress told her it was a "quiet" day, and Amanda was surprised how tiring waitressing was. She thought it was an easy job, but it was not! She realized she could not handle the busy Saturday nights. She was happy to go back to her children because being a mother felt easier after her day as a waitress.
**B. Cindy's Story**
Cindy is 30 years old and swapped lives with Amanda. She was nervous about being a mother for a day but also excited. She knew Amanda's daughters were playful, but she thought she could manage. 
When Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls ready for the day. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have some quiet time. But she was wrong! Amanda reminded her to clean the house and do the laundry. 
After picking up Katie, Cindy went shopping and then took her home for lunch. When Sophie came home from school, things got wild! The girls jumped on the couch and screamed loudly. Cindy tried to stay calm, thinking they would tire out, but they didn’t! She finally got them to bed at 8 pm, but then they kept asking for water to come downstairs and watch TV. 
Cindy learned that taking care of two small children is very tiring. She had no time for herself and felt a lot of responsibility. But she enjoyed the day, too.
**C. Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary is 42 years old and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a teacher. 
On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, but today she could sleep until 7 am. She was nervous about looking different at school. At assembly, she saw about 400 students and hoped she blended in. 
In class, the children worked in groups, which was different from when she was in school. She helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired but only had five minutes to eat. There was a lot to do before the next classes. 
She attended a meeting and helped with sports trials. After lunch, she had a reading lesson and then a French lesson, where the kids wanted to practice with her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and she was very tired. Speaking in front of the class was hard for her. Even though teachers have more holidays, she prefers farming.
**D. Hilary's Story**
Hilary is 30 years old and went to White House Farm at 8:30 am. She found out that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! 
Rosemary's farm has many animals, including cows and sheep. Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling containers with milk and making ice-cream. It was hard not to eat the treats! 
At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped one that had fallen. If a sheep is not helped quickly, it can die. After feeding the calves, she started milking the cows, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this every day, twice a day! 
Hilary felt lonely and missed the children because animals do not talk back. She learned that farming is hard work. It seems nice, but it is very different in reality. The pay is not steady, and it is hard to take time off.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas. It is interesting that many musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a special trumpet player from southern Sweden. He is 30 years old and is known around the world. He plays old music and new music. When you see him, he looks young and friendly, just like the sound of his trumpet. 
Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London. He also had a TV show about his work, filmed in London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo. When he was eight years old, his father, who did not play music, gave him a trumpet for Christmas. His father wanted to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved the trumpet and started to play it all the time. 
His mother found a trumpet player from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra to give him lessons. This teacher, Bo Nilsson, saw that Hakan had a natural talent. Hakan is thankful for having such a good teacher. Bo loved the trumpet and always looked for new ways to play it. 
Hakan explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is not perfect. Each trumpet is a little different. He learned to accept these imperfections and work with them. From a young age, people could recognize Hakan's unique sound. Unlike another famous trumpet player, John Wallace, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter, Maurice Andre, and bought all his records. 
Hakan's parents supported his dream to be a trumpet player. When he was 15, they decided he should study in Paris instead of America. In Paris, he studied with Pierre Thibaud, who told him that playing in an orchestra was not for him. Hakan knew he played better than many other young players. 
At 17, he entered a competition in Paris. He only prepared for the first round but made it to the second round. He knew most of the pieces for that round too. In the final round, he faced a difficult piece. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing and realized that people listened to him. 
Hakan is realistic about his talent. He does not want to explain how he connects with people through music because he believes it might ruin the magic of it. He thinks music has the power to move people.

**New In Paperback**
A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in a made-up country called Efica. It is a special tale about power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and shows the author's unique ideas. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a confident woman with a good job and a husband who is an architect. She usually would not meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her old father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys do not want to talk about what happened. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, cannot explain why he did it. Joe gets better physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son, and taking care of him becomes her main focus. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, and from this, they start an unusual friendship. The author is good at showing how people react when their lives change suddenly. He also shows how mothers feel they can never do enough for their children.
C. This book, which was nominated for the Booker Prize, tells the story of a lonely island in the Scottish Orkney Islands and its people over a long time. The story includes important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears for a while but comes back after the Second World War, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.
D. After his big success, the author has written a sequel that has the same gentle humor and sharp observations about family life. Fifteen years after her daughter died, Aurora Greenway is now in her seventies and has a lively friend named Rosie Sunlap. Aurora still has her charming and kind personality, and Rosie helps her with her relationships. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is now important. The author skillfully shows the sadness that can be found in everyday life.
E. Six very different people come together because of millionaire Logan Urquhart. They sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person learns about themselves during their journey. Their experiences at sea change them. The author uses strong images to express ideas about memory and awareness, making readers think deeply.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs. They share what they like, what they don’t like, and what a normal day is like for them.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and get to work by 8 am. I start surgery at 8:30 am. I do surgeries all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take about three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to do surgery can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed while I operate, but I worry about the next day. Brain surgery is very important for patients, and when it goes well, it feels great. From 10 am to 1 pm, I meet with patients to explain their surgeries. I like talking to them, but I have to be quick sometimes. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I carry my beeper. When I am on holiday, I think about my patients for the first few days."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work. I arrive at 9:15 am. On Monday at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to talk about our work and any problems. I work with a team of four people. My job is mostly about managing projects. I spend three to four weeks designing and developing ideas for clients. After that, I show my ideas to the clients. If they like them, we plan the budget and I hire photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to make sure everything is done on time. I have to talk to many people, and it can be stressful. I usually have lunch at 1 pm for an hour. I like it when clients like my designs, but it’s disappointing when they don’t. I get home around 7:30 pm or later."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7 am most days, but sometimes I get up at 4:30 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. I have to be careful about my diet because I sit a lot during my job. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. I need to know good restaurants and shops for my passengers. Most of my jobs are booked in advance, so I can plan my routes. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I take care of gardens we designed. We work in private gardens and spend about an hour and a half at each place. At 11 am, we go to a cafe for breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I work from home in the office too. If someone wants a new garden, I meet them in the evening. I like using old materials to make gardens look special. It’s hard to relax at night because I can hear the phone for work. I sleep well because my job is very physical."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the work site by 8:30 am. I help build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. I check that the workers are doing their jobs correctly and safely. I talk to the workers and solve problems. The workers start at 6 am, so I first find out what happened since I left the night before. I usually have lunch for half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm. I often eat while I work. I need to keep a good relationship with the workers because we check their work. I leave the site around 6 pm and I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I help customers who use our credit cards. I work on a program called Membership Rewards in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and work with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and then check my emails. I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan our advertising. I have many meetings, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different places in Europe once or twice a week. I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am. I check the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone rings a lot after 10:30 am with calls from producers and others. I have meetings to discuss projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know it is important for the artists, so I try to give good feedback. After signing a band, we work on their first album. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work by 7:00 pm and often go to concerts in the evening. I sometimes get home around 1:00 am.
**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving at 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule for the day. I enjoy showing customers our furniture and helping them buy it. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000. I work with restorers to fix the furniture we buy. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette to stay updated and visit museums to compare furniture. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and it takes me about an hour to relax.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I leave home at 6:00 am for my early shift. I start work at 7:00 am and take control of aircraft movements. I work in a team with other controllers. In winter, we manage about 1,000 flights a day. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new rules. This job is stressful, and I take sick days if I feel unwell. I want to become a watch manager or general manager of the airport in the future.
**E. Shop Manager**  
If I work early, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the electronic sales system and make sure someone is at the cash register. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy helping them, but it can be hard when they expect me to find many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, I meet with publishers to discuss new books. I need to make sure new titles arrive on time. I finish my early shift at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work late and close the shop.
**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work by 8:45 am. I contact reporters to learn about my area. I assess financial risks for companies in other countries. I provide three services: a newsflash, a security forecast, and a travel information guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. I have deadlines to meet, so I work quickly. I travel to Africa three times a year for reports. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**
A. **What makes a good leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps them change for the better. Being a leader is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says that leadership is about making things happen with people who are excited and interested. A good leader should speak clearly and confidently. They should say "I believe" instead of "I think."
B. John van Maurik, who teaches a course on leadership, says that many people can be great leaders if they see their own talents and use them. We all have the ability to be leaders; we just need the right situation to grow. It is easy to see famous leaders like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, but it can be harder to see leadership in our own jobs. However, being a good leader is very important for good management.
C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they do it? The best boss motivated you and supported you. The worst boss made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first boss led well; the second one managed badly.
D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new ideas. Micheal Shea, who wrote about leadership, says a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a sad company into a happy one.
E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some tips:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to do it. Find what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired, use that energy to take action.  
- Start thinking of yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is important.  
- Sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking the lead yourself. See how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better.
F. Leadership does not just happen. It grows when you take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, organize well, and give praise.  
- Don’t think everyone will like your way of leading right away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and available to important people.  
- Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your help is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**
**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a tense movie about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team remind us of tough heroes in older movies. The special effects are very good, but the dialogue and characters are not strong. The story feels like a simple B-movie.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on a book about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is different from Terrence Malick's version, which is more poetic. Director Andrew Marton made a more traditional war movie that focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Marton's film has some good moments, especially when the soldier dreams of his wife.
**C. On Guard**  
This fun movie is based on a book from 1875. It is better than many other musketeer films. The villain, played by Fabrice Luchini, is a sneaky politician causing trouble. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, and Daniel Auteuil plays a moody character who is also a swordsman. The film is full of clichés, but it is entertaining.
**D. Character**  
This film is set in Rotterdam at the turn of the century. The detailed costumes and sets make it look like a museum. Jan Decleir plays a harsh bailiff named Dreverhaven, who is cruel to his tenants. The story focuses on his bad relationship with his son, but the film spends too much time on details instead of the dark story.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released film shows the skill of director Leone. The sound is very clear, making every noise stand out. The story is harsh, and the music by Morricone makes it exciting. The three main characters, the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), all act in selfish ways in the post-Civil War West.
**F. The Longest Day**  
This war movie features many international stars and has four directors and 23,000 extras. The early parts of the film, where soldiers wait for news about an invasion, are slow. While the movie is impressive in size, it is better to watch on a big screen. Watching it on video does not give the same experience.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is a very interesting story. The main character is a lawyer who is trying to start a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife when she is accused of killing her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the ending is surprising. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. The main character, Sigismondo, helps rich people in Italy during the Renaissance. He gets involved in politics and a murder case, but we believe he will find out who is guilty. The story is complicated and a bit long, but it is still very good.
**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. The main character, Leah Hunter, is a tax inspector. She starts to investigate when a strange man dies near her. Leah is brave and smart, and she does not let anyone stop her, even if some people do not like her. She is a great character.
**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk to get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and there is more thinking than usual. It is always good entertainment from Parker.
**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn solving a case about an attack and robbery at a famous actress's daughter’s house. The author writes in a simple way and shows interesting human behavior, making this a fun mystery.
**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but most of the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. It has romance, money, and violence, making it a gripping suspense novel.
**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw shows actor Philip Fletcher in a new role as a target. A funny group of characters comes together to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels this is not the right path for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains well, but this time it is not as good as his other works.
**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is the best book by Lawrence Gough in a while. Canadian police are looking for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the smart but troubled robber, making it better than an average detective novel.

I might be too old for this, but here I go! Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age want to travel. This summer, he quit his job, rented out his flat, and decided to travel in South East Asia for a year. Some people might think he is lucky, but he feels nervous. He has traveled before. After university, he spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When he came back, he wanted to travel again. But then he fell in love, started a career, and got used to earning money. He realized he was not happy just working for money. When he quit his job, he felt like he was in control of his life again. 
Many of his friends are now married with children. They do not want to change places with him, but they envy his freedom. Tim is not in a relationship and does not have big career goals. He feels he should enjoy his freedom, especially for his friends. But he is nervous. He has to make many plans. He worries about having someone else live in his home and how to rent it out. He also needs to decide where to go. He is a big procrastinator and is already behind on his plans. He thought about enjoying the summer in England and waiting for the football season to start.
Tim is also worried about leaving his comfortable life. He wonders if he can still backpack. Will he fit in with younger backpackers? He finds that more people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel and escape their daily lives. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that many people are realizing they can have adventures if they are brave and organized.
Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says he is ready to give up job security for this trip. He knows he might return to the same job, but he thinks it is a risk worth taking. He even threw his calculator into the river when he left his job!
Matt, who just left the Army, says traveling helped him change his life. He needed to break away from the strict way of doing things in the military. There are many reasons why people travel at this age. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says more people work on short-term contracts, so they have nothing to lose when their contract ends. Some big companies even allow employees to take breaks and come back later.
Dan Hiscocks, who runs a company about travelers, says many people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. If they are not happy, they know they can change things. Traveling gives them a chance to think about what they want in life. 
Jennifer Cox believes that wanting to travel is not a sign of not wanting to grow up. It shows that people are better educated and want a balanced life. Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher, is going to Central America for a year. He does not think he is running away; he wants to find new things for himself. But he is also nervous about leaving his comfortable routine.
I feel the same way as Ben. I am not sure I would travel if I had not found my boss so difficult to work with. Jennifer Cox says that often something happens, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to travel. 
Even though it took a push for me to start, I am excited about the next year. No matter what happens, I will be happy that I took this chance. I think many older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**
Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist. She felt lost because of new technology. In this story, she shares how she changed her home into a good place to work.
The Christmas before last, I turned 37. I realized I needed to get back to my journalism career. I felt like my skills were old-fashioned, stuck in the 1980s. Back then, I used a typewriter, and now everyone uses computers. I was worried that no one would want me in a newsroom because I didn’t know how to use a computer. Many job ads asked for experience in desktop publishing, which I didn’t have. I thought it would be easier to learn nuclear physics than to use a computer. I was not good with technology; even calculators confused me, and I didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.
I knew I had to change quickly. I thought leaving home before my kids would be hard. But then, I entered a competition in a local newspaper and won a computer package! We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world of computers and learned words like Internet and surfing. We started chatting online with people from different countries. My kids stopped watching TV, and I made a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home and still take my kids to school. My children were already good with computers from school, but I was nervous. I thought I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. I was wrong! I learned the basic skills I needed. It was logical and easy. Every day, I learned a little more.
Now, I write articles for a magazine, about two each month. I feel proud because I have the best of both worlds. The computer has helped me a lot. Before, my desk was always messy, and I lost important papers. Now, I am more organized. I use spreadsheets to keep track of money, and I save time with ready-made invoices and letterheads. As a journalist, the Internet helps me find information and talk to other writers from around the world.
But working from home has some downsides. I can feel lonely without seeing people. There are also distractions at home, like chores, and my kids sometimes argue about who gets to use the computer. Many people in my neighborhood have bought computers, not just for learning but also for fun and entertainment. 
A report called PC Usage in UK Homes says that most home computer users are 38 years old and well-educated. Many own personal computers and have printers and modems. I feel like I am doing well with my computer skills. One day, I might even send an article to a newspaper in Melbourne or publish my own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless!

**The Tartan Museum**
The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has modern buildings that look like cheese wedges. The outside of the museum is very big and easy to see. It has a tall yellow tower and a garden hanging from the roof. 
Last winter, people had different opinions about the museum's design. Some people thought it was beautiful, while others were not so sure. Now, the inside of the museum is almost ready to open. 
The museum tells many stories about Scotland's history. It has important objects, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots. The museum wants to show these treasures without too much national pride. 
Dr. David Clarke is in charge of the exhibitions. He wants the museum to be fun and easy to understand for everyone, not just experts. He believes that the museum should show the truth about the past. 
Visitors will see many interesting objects, but the museum also uses panels and computers to explain the stories. There are about 30 computers in the museum. 
When you enter the museum, you will notice the different spaces. The galleries connect to each other, and the walls look like big stone blocks. Light comes in through special windows, making it bright inside. 
There is also a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of kids aged 9 to 12 from all over Scotland. They wanted to have fun activities, and now there is a special area for children to explore. 
On the top floor, there is a gallery that changes every three years. It shows objects that are important to Scotland in the 20th century. People suggested items like electric guitars, televisions, and toys. 
Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. The museum's modern design is impressive inside, but some people wonder if it is in the right place.

The Future of Newspapers**
The change from print newspapers to online news is happening slowly. Some people are scared of this change, but it is a normal part of moving from one thing to another. Many people think that print newspapers will eventually disappear because fewer people are buying them. For example, sales of newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have dropped by 8% to 10% in the last year. At the same time, more people are visiting their websites.
However, not everything is clear. A recent survey showed that the total number of newspapers sold around the world actually went up by 1.1% last year. In some places, like Asia, sales increased a lot. Also, magazines about news and current events saw a 5.4% increase in sales. This shows that while some types of print media are struggling, others are doing well.
E-books are becoming very popular, and many people are buying e-readers like Kindle. But when bookstores looked at their sales of physical books, they found that sales only dropped by 0.4%. This means that people are still buying both e-books and physical books.
Many people think that young people are not reading newspapers anymore, but this is not true. The latest survey shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read the main newspapers in the UK. Different countries have different trends. For example, in Britain, newspaper sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop is only 7%. In France, it is just 3.1%.
In the past, experts thought that online advertising would help newspapers make money. But now, online ads are actually going down. Many newspapers in the US have started charging for online access. The best way to get people to pay for online news is to offer both a print copy and online access together. This means that print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions.
However, keeping both print and online versions is hard and expensive for newspapers. Print newspapers still have a strong presence, but it is harder for them to be noticed online.

**Photographing People**
People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is usually better than one without. But taking good photos of people can be hard. The photographer must pay attention to how people move, their gestures, and their expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.
**A. Grouping People**  
When taking pictures of groups, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. You can have some people sitting or kneeling in front so you can see all their faces.
**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting they find a comfortable position, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is clear you are. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel shy. You may need to guide them. A picture can be less interesting if the person is looking away.
**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo looks better if the person seems to look at the viewer. Ask them to look into the camera lens. They do not have to smile. If they look away, remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural. Candid shots can be very interesting, and the person's expression is important.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. A laughing child can make us smile, while a sad face can make us feel sad. Look for common expressions like smiles, frowns, or thumbs-up. They are a quick way to show feelings.
**G. Situation Interest**  
A picture can be more interesting if the background tells us something about the person. Make sure the background does not take attention away from the person. A wide-angle lens can help make the person look bigger compared to the background.
**H. Interaction**  
Good pictures often happen when people are talking, laughing, or working together. Look for moments of connection, like eye contact or a handshake. These moments can show emotions and reactions.
**I. People and Places**  
Many pictures of people are taken on trips. To show people with a nice background, step back to include the whole scene. Ask people to stand close to the camera but not block the view of the background. A higher camera position can help with this. A good picture shows both the people and the place equally.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want a clear photo of someone you met on holiday, ask them to pose in front of a nice background. Family pictures can be boring if everyone is just posing. Candid photos of events are often more lively and can bring back memories better than posed ones.

**Under Sarah's Spell**
Sarah Janson is an artist who creates trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings look real but are actually tricks for the eyes. Joanna Watt interviews her.
Not many artists do not sign their work unless someone asks them to. Sarah Janson is one of these artists. She does not think the artist is important; she believes the work is what matters. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This makes the interview a bit difficult. She says, "I just don't like to shout about myself," and she gets nervous when asked to take a photo.
After 30 minutes, Sarah feels more comfortable. The interview becomes fun and interesting. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she was not happy with illustration. She started working with a decorator named Jim Smart, who asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting. After that, she knew this was her path. She left to work on her own, not knowing exactly what would happen, but feeling it was the right choice.
Sarah's skills in observing details helped her become a good trompe-l'oeil artist. She says, "People often ask me where they can learn trompe-l'oeil. But no one can teach you. Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation." She believes she is still learning. She is honest about her weaknesses, saying, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." She also struggles with math. When she had a big job to paint a ceiling, she got confused with the measurements and thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?"
Sarah often talks about herself in the third person. After finishing a big project, she thinks, "Well, I didn't do it, she did." Her trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special and different from others. She has many important clients and creates art inspired by buildings. For example, she painted a dining room that looks like a beautiful Venetian building and a hallway that seems to lead to two more rooms.
With trompe-l'oeil art, once you understand the trick, you might lose interest. Sarah knows this and says, "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and engage your imagination." She believes that her art should also be personal to her clients. "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born," she says. Some clients know exactly what they want, while others do not. She listens to them and tries to understand their ideas.
Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working. Sarah is thankful for her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, which is why she is always busy. Even though she does not like to talk about her talent, she says, "I really don't like to shout about myself. Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout."
It is true that you might get bored with things that are too loud, but you could never get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves to be better known, and I am happy to share it with others.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
Daniel Goleman talks about the important "people skills" we need to succeed at work.
A. The rules for work are changing. Now, we are judged not only by how smart we are or how well we know our jobs, but also by how we manage ourselves and work with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired and who does not. It helps to show who will do very well at their job and who may not. These new rules are important for our future jobs. They are different from what we learned in school. Doing well on tests is not as important anymore. Now, we need to have good social skills and personal qualities, like being proactive, understanding others, being flexible, and convincing people. These skills are called emotional intelligence.
B. Today, many jobs do not offer security, and we need to have skills that we can use in different jobs. Personal qualities are becoming more important at work. For a long time, people talked about these qualities using different names, like "character" or "soft skills." Now, we call them emotional intelligence. This means being aware of our own feelings and the feelings of others, and using these feelings to help us think and act. In our work, emotional intelligence includes: knowing ourselves, controlling our feelings, being motivated, understanding others, and having good social skills. Some people think emotional intelligence just means being nice, but sometimes it means being honest, even if it is uncomfortable. It is not about showing all our feelings, but about managing them so we can work well together.
C. More companies are realizing that emotional intelligence is very important for good management. The more complicated the job, the more we need emotional intelligence. If someone lacks these skills, it can make it hard for them to use their knowledge and skills. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and requires teamwork, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s workplaces, where teamwork and good customer service are important, emotional intelligence is essential for doing well in any job.
D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people get better at managing their feelings and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us in our jobs, especially now when jobs are not always stable. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but if we ignore the human side of work, everything else may not work as well.

'Should the media make money from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones make it easy to take pictures of news events. Social media has changed how people share these photos. Now, some journalists use social media to find images of fast-moving events. But some reporters have used pictures from users without asking for permission. There are rules that say images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or if there is strong public interest. However, people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event. This means user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. To keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure that people are paid for their work and that they always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**
Acupuncture is a treatment that is over two thousand years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to help with many health problems, but doctors in the West often use it to treat pain. Some general practitioners (GPs), midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for pain relief.
**What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**
Traditional Chinese medicine believes that good health is when the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. They think that energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians connected to different organs. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, a person may feel weak or sick. 
When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check your pulse, look at your tongue, and ask about your health, feelings, and habits. They use very thin needles that go into the skin. They may also use heat from herbs or apply pressure to points on the meridians to help the flow of Qi.
**Acupuncture Points**
The points where needles are placed are connected to the meridians and may not be near the area that hurts. People often feel a mild ache or tingling when the needle is moved. This shows that the needle has reached the Qi. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians.
**How Does Acupuncture Work?**
Even though Western doctors do not fully accept traditional Chinese medicine, many believe that acupuncture can help with pain. They think it may work by blocking pain signals or by releasing natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.
**What Pain Can Acupuncture Help?**
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments do not work. It can help with back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain and pain in terminally ill patients.
**Modern Use of Acupuncture**
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. This helped some doctors outside China see that acupuncture is more than just a mental trick. In China today, acupuncture is used in many surgeries, and it can help reduce pain. Some people recover from surgery faster with acupuncture.
**Is Acupuncture Always Effective?**
It is hard to study acupuncture, but some trials show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with chronic pain. Acupuncturists say that it usually takes six to seven visits to feel real relief, but some people may feel better after just two or three visits.
**A Different Way to Look at Pain**
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They spend time understanding the person’s health and what might be causing the pain. They ask questions about how the pain feels and what makes it worse, like cold or heat. This helps them decide how to treat the pain.
**Choosing an Acupuncturist**
Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific methods. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using their methods can lead to better healing. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist, and they should refer you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems calm and confident, but she is actually shy. Her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, is a detective who is a bit like her. She likes to write alone and needs privacy to do it well.
P.D. James has written 12 popular detective novels that many people read around the world. She admires her friend Ruth Rendell, who writes under the name Barbara Vine. P.D. James enjoys books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also likes some male authors like Graham Greene.
She became successful later in life. P.D. James was 42 when her first book, Cover Her Face, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there, who was a student. Life was not easy for her. Her husband, Connor, was very sick after serving in the war. P.D. James had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped take care of the girls during tough times.
While working for the National Health Service, she used her strong organizational skills. She also worked for 11 years at the Home Office, where she learned a lot about crime. She saw many dead bodies but was not interested in death itself. Instead, she loved writing detective stories because they allowed her to create interesting plots.
P.D. James did not want to write about her own sad experiences. She thought writing detective stories was a good way to learn how to be a serious writer. She believes that solving a crime in a story brings order to chaos and shows that life is important, even if it is difficult.

**The Pen is Stronger than the Psychoanalyst**
The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you want a job, you may need to show a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. 
Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Some researchers say it can help find certain health problems, like heart disease and cancer, and can show emotional issues. Many big companies now use handwriting analysis to help choose candidates for important jobs. 
However, many doctors and psychiatrists are not sure about the value of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if a person should focus on arts or sciences, and if they are honest or not."
Ms. Marne believes graphology can help find possible criminal behavior. She says, "Criminals often have messy handwriting. Many come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional problems. This can show in childish handwriting or by writing letters many times." 
She can tell if people are honest or if they might manipulate others. For example, young male offenders often have tall letters, which means they dream big. Graphologists can also see if someone is under a lot of stress or has violent tendencies. Handwriting can even help predict if someone might think about suicide. 
Ms. Marne explains that heart and lung problems can also show in handwriting. "You cannot make a diagnosis from one sample unless it is very shaky. But if handwriting changes over time, it could mean something serious is happening." 
She also says that handwriting can show other psychological traits. For example, people who write with letters connected by threads may be clever but not honest. Those who write mostly in capital letters may be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity, while unique handwriting shows confidence and creativity. 
Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study to analyze handwriting well, along with understanding and intuition. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a proper science. She thinks it is more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can show a person's history and emotional problems without asking them questions.
However, many psychiatrists do not agree with her. They say handwriting is just a result of education and the way people are taught to write, and it does not mean anything more.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**
A new survey says that fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
**Office A: Advertising Agency**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple. It has no central heating and no mechanical ventilation. The windows open to the street. The workers are part of a small team and seem happy. They change the office temperature by opening doors or using electric heaters, like they do at home. This may help them feel comfortable.
  
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture does not match and some chairs are old and broken. This can cause bad posture. However, the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations. This variety helps them avoid tiredness and boredom.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff like the different types of work and the size of the office. It is small enough to know what others are doing but big enough to work alone. The office looks nice and fun.
**Office B: News Service**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable. The air quality is good, and there is a No Smoking policy.
- **Ergonomist:** The company has good chairs and lighting. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. The walls are plain and dull.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls have only a few planners and a poster. Most workers have been there for over five years and get along well. The office could be better if desks were arranged to share information easily.
**Office C: Bank**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has mixed feelings from workers. It feels like being in a glass box. The air is not stale, even with smokers around.
- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and not inspiring. The desks are okay, but some chairs are not good for computer work. The computer setup is not modern.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff help each other and use technology well. There are many awards on display. The office is busy but has a serious look.
**Office D: Newspaper**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many problems. The air conditioning does not work well, and the temperature changes a lot. The space is messy, and there is a lot of dust.
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is not good for a modern office. Many chairs are old and do not help workers who are shorter.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office is dirty, with old chairs and carpets. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning. There were not many conversations when we visited; people seemed stressed. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**
Chewing gum is popular in America. People chew about 12 million sticks of it every day. It is a simple food and must follow rules from the American Food and Drug Administration.
Today, most chewing gum is made with synthetic materials. These materials help keep the flavor and make the gum soft. But a long time ago, people chewed different types of gum. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used mastic gum to clean their teeth and make their breath smell good.
In America, colonists learned to chew resin from spruce trees from the Native Americans. In the early 1800s, they sold spruce gum in the eastern United States. Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s when people discovered chicle, a substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, and it created a big industry.
However, it is hard to grow sapodilla trees. Today, many gum makers use synthetic materials instead. The few people who still gather chicle, called chicleros, have a tough life. They walk for miles in very humid conditions to collect the sap. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. The chicleros climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp. There, they boil it until it becomes sticky and forms bricks.
Life in the camp is not easy. The workers eat a simple diet and drink local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico.
As chewing gum sales have increased, companies have started using synthetic materials to save money. Gum makers also find new ways to sell their products. They say chewing gum can help you relax, give you energy, and reduce tooth decay. Chewing gum can help produce saliva, which protects your teeth.
Today, many new flavors of gum are made, mostly with artificial ingredients. However, some flavors still use natural ingredients. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the most popular chewing gums.

**REMOTE HOTELS**
A. **INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The village is known for its craftsmen. The hotel has a calm and peaceful atmosphere with Indian decorations. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests to their home. The hotel has basic facilities, like hot water from a bucket, but this makes it special.
B. **NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing. After climbing a glacier, I walked down and was surprised to see the hotel in beautiful countryside. It is very high up and very wild. After a long climb, it was amazing to find such luxury, with a man playing music on the piano.
C. **MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in the south-west of Mauritius. The road to the hotel goes along the coast with empty beaches. The hotel is big and offers free water sports, but you can find peace on the nine-kilometre private beach. If you swim a little, you can hardly see the hotel because of the palm trees. In the evening, when everyone leaves, you can relax on the beach and feel far away from everything.
D. **ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a beautiful view of the Caribbean Sea. It is quiet and high up, with open rooms looking out at the Pitons. The hotel has a colonial style with wooden furniture and four-poster beds.
E. **TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada, one of the Princes Islands. It is a great place to escape the noise of Istanbul. The islands are only an hour away by boat. There are no cars, just horse-drawn carriages. The hotel is made of wood, painted white with red domes. It is a little old but still charming.
F. **FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, there is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. It has a moat with swans and 20 different rooms, some with four-poster beds. There are special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner with complimentary champagne.
G. **KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Nairobi. It is popular with travelers who are resting after a safari. Guests often decide to stay longer because of the beautiful gardens and good food.
