The hotel has many trees and buildings on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great place to watch the sunset while enjoying a drink and a nice dinner.
H. **ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
Hotel Splendido has welcomed many famous people, like movie stars. It used to be a monastery and is now a beautiful hotel. The hotel is still very nice, with simple but delicious food and beautiful decorations.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. At the Globe Hotel, things are not going well. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue and Christopher. Sue thinks this is very bad service. 
The Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the best hotels. But when Sue arrives, she sees that the entrance is not nice. There is a door with a buzzer and a long, empty hallway. Sue is not happy with this.
When Sue checks in, the receptionist says they have no record of her booking. There are 15 rooms, but 12 are empty. Sue looks at a room on the top floor, but it is stuffy and has a big hole in the wall. 
Sue remembers when she started inspecting hotels. People called her "The Woman in Black," but she did not wear black and did not think she was tough. The next morning, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who looks scared when he sees her. He apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. 
Sue suggests that he should fix the plumbing and tell the staff to be more careful with guests. Robin takes notes and seems worried. He has only worked at the Globe for five months. 
Sue also praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, for their good work. The dinner was good enough to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating. Robin asks how to get three rosettes, and Sue says they should not serve bad desserts.
Sue's job is to tell hotels what is wrong. Sometimes, people complain about her. She remembers a woman who said she got her son fired because he served her pie with his fingers. 
Sue must write a report about her visit. The hotels pay for her to help them improve. It is good for Robin to hear that Sue will not take away the Globe's red stars. But another inspector will come back in two months to check if the problems are fixed. Robin smiles, but he does not look very happy about it.

**Climbing the Seven Summits**
Doug Scott is a mountaineer who writes about climbing the highest mountains on each continent, called the Seven Summits. He started this adventure later in life and will tell us about each mountain in the order he climbed them.
**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave close to the top of Mt. Everest. They talked about sleeping bags, which Doug thought was strange because they were alone. He started talking to his feet because they were cold. Doug remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes to frostbite. They were not just worried about surviving but also about how well they could survive. Doug felt calm and confident with Dougal. He found a good rhythm and continued climbing to the summit.
**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food. They realized how hard their climb would be. They followed a route from 1967 but then chose a new path to the summit. They carried everything on their backs. After three days, Doug's sleeping bag was wet. They camped on a windy ridge and felt tired. The air pressure made it feel like they were higher than they really were. Finally, they reached the summit and felt happy.
**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. Instead, they got a free ride to Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest mountain. They got lost in the jungle and had trouble finding water. On the second day, they found arrows on trees that led them to a rock pool. They tried to climb a steep wall but had to turn back because of falling rocks and ice. They chose a safer route to the summit.
**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil who invited them to join his group. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. The Polish Glacier was icy and windy. They decided to take a different route to avoid the glacier. They walked with many other climbers to the summit. The wind was strong, and they camped outside before going back to base camp. There, they met climbers who wanted to climb the Seven Summits too.
**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif was possible if he guided enough people to pay for the trip. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. The sun was always shining, and it was very quiet. On December 7, they started climbing to the summit. Despite strong winds and very cold temperatures, they all reached the top in 8 hours. However, they could not see much because of a storm.
**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team met in St Petersburg. They went to Elbrus and had to pay a fee to their guide. After a few days, they took a cable car up the mountain. They walked to a refuge and then climbed. They thought they reached the summit but found there was more to climb. They returned to the refuge and then went down the mountain.
**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On this expedition, Doug wanted to climb and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about dangers from bandits but decided to go anyway. On May 12, they started climbing. The weather got better, and two team members went ahead. Doug and another climber were slower because they were filming. They reached the summit by 11 am. Doug felt proud to complete his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives today. It affects our clothes, home decoration, and accessories. Jo Foley shares some fashion trends for this year.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says people should choose simpler styles instead of traditional, stiff dresses. Ned has been drawing wedding dresses since he was a boy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress. He also designs long evening dresses in new colors and fabrics. For those who like classic styles, he has a navy-blue summer suit that many English women wore in the 20th century. But he makes it look fresh and new.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but did not study jewellery. She started designing rings when she could not find one she liked. In 1990, she became a designer. Now, many famous people want her jewellery. She uses large semi-precious stones in gold to make beautiful necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by the 18th century. Recently, she started using diamonds because she wanted to create something special.
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Lily Grimson has been in the fashion business for four years. She has only taken a short course in art and design, but two of her bags were chosen for a big design exhibition. All of her bags are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is not just a bag; it is stylish and made from high-quality materials like calfskin and silk. 
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
Peter Little has been a hairdresser for over 20 years. Many famous people have had their hair styled by him. He believes women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. He wants his clients to look good without looking like they just came from a salon. His services are expensive, costing £250 for the first visit, and there is a long waiting list. He has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools for people to use at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works as a flower consultant for supermarkets and restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and used to be a teacher. Ten years ago, she decided to do something different. Her modern flower arrangements have won many awards, and she has started her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. Penny believes flower arrangements should be simple and strong, with not too many leaves. For wedding bouquets, she says all the flowers should be the same type.

**The Merrion Hotel: Luxury and Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both guests and staff.
Peter MacCann is the General Manager. He wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but it will save money in the future. MacCann is happy with how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests complain about room temperature. The Merrion Hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature from 14°C to 25°C.
The hotel is popular with business guests. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the guests will be business travelers. To help them, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel is ready for new improvements. They have extra cables for future technology. The televisions are rented, so they can get new ones easily. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and cozy bedrooms. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has made a new kitchen and improved the restaurant. The hotel benefits from having a great place to eat without financial risks.
With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The big garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden has many of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. There are two long flower beds along a path that goes from one side of the garden to the other. The colors and shapes of the flowers are very nice. The previous owners of the garden loved to garden and left many plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny would say some of Susan's ideas were not good, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint individual plants in detail instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. She says, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I take one flower out and paint it. This might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build up the painting." Sometimes it can take a couple of years to finish a painting.
Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips and poppies bloom. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. She also finds beauty in how flowers change over time. For example, with tulips, "You bring them in and put them in water. After a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they change all the time."
Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She was fascinated by wildflowers that grew in difficult places, like cracks in rocks.
Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they grow well in her garden. She lets the garden grow freely, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they do not break anything. Susan is busy preparing for two art exhibitions, so she has hired an extra gardener. Even though she needs to paint, she knows that to stay connected to her flowers, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**No Title**
Many trees in Brackham were knocked down in the big storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This change made the town look very different, and some people were not happy about it. 
One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police. But during the storm, he was very sick with bronchitis. He had a headache and felt tight in his chest. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he thought he was too important for the police and did not go. This made him forget things and made him angry.
Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. Soon, he got medicine and went home to Molly, who sent him to bed. 
On Thursday morning, Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen during the night. Pelham was too sick to understand. Later, when he felt better on Saturday, he saw that without the walnut tree, the living room looked very different. 
The Pelhams had a big house with a nice garden. They liked their home, but now the storm changed how it looked. Before, the walnut tree made the living room feel cozy and hid the old furniture. Now, without the tree, the room was too bright, and the old furniture looked bad. 
Also, the view from the window was not nice anymore. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.
“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said to Molly. But she seemed happy. “I’ve been saying this since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

**Living in the Valley**
We lived in our valley for sixteen months when we first saw the dangers in the hills around us. It was a year when storms came early, even before winter started. Until then, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. 
Then, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. The snow almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. In the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we felt only some strong gusts of wind; the trees moved, but their branches stayed strong. 
We knew we had to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really scare us. The river, called the Ryburn, was what worried us the most. It usually flowed gently, but we remembered what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams built many years ago. 
Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds gather over the hills. These clouds looked dangerous and warned us of what was coming. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow melted as more rain fell from the clouds, and the reservoir in the hills was filling up quickly. 
Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a small Niagara Falls, as water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river looked wild as the water flowed down quickly. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream was deeper than we had ever seen, rushing angrily at its banks. 
For three days, we hoped the river would stay below its edge. Luckily, the dam held, and the water began to go down. Many times in the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually everything is fine. The water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only a little overflow sometimes. 
Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel safe in our home.

Mark Adams is a film critic. He has worked for a newspaper called The Front Page for ten years. Writing about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before that, he wrote reviews for other newspapers and magazines, and he did some work for the radio. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who hired him. Tom was not a journalist, so he did not choose his staff very carefully.
Tom wanted a team of critics to write about different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have lunch together every week to talk about what to cover. Mark felt very lucky to be part of a new newspaper. He thought it was strange that a new paper could start in a busy market. He even felt like a millionaire was helping him by giving him a job. The first time he saw someone reading his review in the newspaper, he felt shy.
Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. They did not meet as planned, and they ended up talking on the phone. People liked to read reviews from critics who focused on one subject, so Mark chose to write about films. Without Tom's help, Mark would not have the job he has now, where he writes a long piece about one film each week. He likes this way of working. He did not want to be a standard film critic who reviews every new film. That would make him bored quickly.
Mark thinks that people choose films based on stars, ads, or the director. People usually stick to the types of films they like. For example, someone who does not like westerns is unlikely to watch one just because of a review. Mark does not think a film review is a guide for buying tickets. He does not feel he has to be "right" about a movie. He does not believe there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. His job is to share his opinion, not to judge films.

**Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun."**
**Teenager with a love for endurance sports**
**WANTED:** A training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. You should love running long distances (15km), swimming in cold water, and cycling long distances (100km). You must be able to do all three sports without resting.
The triathlon is becoming a very popular Olympic sport. Many people watch athletes swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km without stopping. It looks hard, but why do these athletes do it? 
Melanie Sears is a 17-year-old girl who is very good at sports and school. She has not learned the usual phrases that athletes say about personal satisfaction and challenges. She says, "You swim 1500m, then you run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Then you feel cold. After cycling 40km, you have to run 10km, which is hard when you are tired. But it is great fun, and it is worth it in the end."
Melanie started her first triathlon when she was 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior there. It felt easy, and I waved at my friends while I was racing." She then entered the National Championships. She swam fast and ran fast, but she did not win. "I was following a man, and we got lost. We ended up cycling 20km too far. I cried while running." But she did not give up. "Sometimes I want to stop because it hurts, but I am afraid that if I stop once, I will want to stop again."
Steve Trew, the coach, admires her determination. "I tested her fitness, and she worked so hard that she fell off the running machine and hit a wall. Most people stop when they are tired, but she kept going."
This year, Melanie was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but I was slower at cycling. That’s why I am training hard." She is trying to convince her parents to buy a special bike for £2,000 for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships. 
But training takes time. "I don’t have a social life," she says. "I am not a party person. After swimming for two hours on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to the other girls on my team." What do they talk about? "Not boys or clothes. We talk about our times in races."
Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," where you swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to try even harder events than the triathlon. "The problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says.

**The Collectors**
Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why many people enjoy this hobby. Many adults like to collect items. It is a fun and exciting world. But if you want to collect something, remember: you should love the item. 
People have collected things for a long time. In the past, early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful.
I have collected many things in my life, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. When I was six years old, I went to a school in a cold place in England. My parents took me to a local museum full of interesting objects. I loved looking at these items. 
Many adults also enjoy collecting. Some people collect because it is the only thing they can control in their lives. For me, I just enjoy it. 
One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many strange and beautiful items. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had over 4,000 paintings. But you do not need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember when I convinced another collector to give me a special tulip. I planted it, but one year it disappeared because someone stole it.
I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I searched all over the USA for them. Sadly, my collection was lost in a fire. The next day, I saw the remains of my dolls and furniture. I was very sad.
I find it interesting how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet can be very valuable. As more people want small items, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you kept the original boxes. I wish I had kept mine!

**My Line of Work**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and tell people about it. I read about the exhibition topic and talk to important people to find out the main ideas. I decide what objects and pictures to show. I also plan activities like workshops and theatre to help visitors understand the exhibition. I work with engineers and electricians to make sure everything is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people.
**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
I start my day at 7:30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, learning the best routes to take. I help when there are disagreements, like if a right turn is allowed at a junction. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route, but I tell them they must find another way if the road is closed. This helps them think better.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I mostly work by the sea. I work with schools and run courses for people who manage the coast and make decisions about the sea. I take them out on a boat to show them the life under the water. This helps them understand better than just using a computer. I love my job because conservation is my hobby, but I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money to do everything I want.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is very varied. I make sure our publishing program meets what people want and keep about 300 books in stock. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about things like international boundaries, and I must respond carefully. I talk about future projects and sales with my co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, I have too much administration work, which takes time away from more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**No Title**
We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple, the Malseeds, bought the house and made some changes, but they did it carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. One evening, he said, "How about this?" and read the details. 
The summer before, we went to a hotel that friends recommended, but it was not good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe were in the same school, which is why we call Strafe by his last name like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We think it is a funny coincidence.
"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are coming because she is usually waiting in the big hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. She called our rooms by names: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little things like that. Her husband takes care of repairs and painting.
"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he came into the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I could tell the others felt that our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again.
Arthur led us to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and going back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we did not play long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others going down the cliff path to the beach.
In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sand to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because we had done it many times before. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. This is her second year working in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is not a long-term job, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a career. She meets many interesting people every week.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she thinks is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. On good days, she can ski until 4:30 p.m.
After skiing, Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep because it is not good for her. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She does not like coming back to a messy kitchen in the morning. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. Good guests can make her week better, but some weeks are not as good.
Sarah lives in a chalet with her friends. They usually go out at 11 p.m. to have fun. They start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe Dick's T-Bar at the end of the night. But she does not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day.
On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. She clears the breakfast, strips the beds, and gets everything ready for new guests. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., she finishes cleaning and prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests are confused and have many questions.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. She takes them to the ski shop and gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she has a drink after dinner, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. Seymour was surprised that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research about the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class who visited the factory years ago. Seymour remembered showing them how he made gloves, especially the special table where the workers shaped and pressed each glove using hot brass hands. Marie called them "pancake hands" because they looked strange.
Rita asked Seymour, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" Seymour explained, "They come to the tannery. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us. My grandfather, father, and I worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" Rita said, "Not yet." Seymour encouraged her to visit a tannery if she wanted to write about leather. He said, "It's an old industry. There are ancient tools found in Turkey that are 6,000 years old. The first clothes were made from animal skins that were tanned by smoking."
Seymour told Rita that his father was a leather expert and that she should talk to him. "He can talk for two days about gloves. Glovemen love their work," he said. Then he asked, "Have you ever seen anything being made?" Rita replied, "I can't say I have." She added, "I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." Seymour laughed. He liked her spirit and eagerness to learn. 
Rita was much shorter than Marie, but she reminded Seymour of her. He remembered how Marie would come home from school, full of what she learned. "I have an idea," he said. "We will show you the whole process. Come on! We will make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Tough Job?**
Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.
**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she travels a lot. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. But there is one small problem: she does not like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt very closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings, and making travel plans. Raquel did not apply for this job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance and took a secretarial course at night classes. Five years later, she became a personal assistant.
**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which means he carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because he loves golf. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee and a part of the winnings. Most caddies earn between £25,000 and £35,000, but they spend a lot on travel and hotels. David was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. "You do more than just carry bags. You give advice and try to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his skills in accounting were recognized, and he now works as a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from each day's play, which are important for TV commentators and golf magazines.
**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food at fancy restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "If people can pay, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His friend, who was an editor, offered him a food column because Martin is a good cook. At that time, he worked in advertising and it helped him earn extra money. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant I would earn less money, but it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and tries to stay healthy by cycling to the nearest tube station.
**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. "Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It is not easy; I have to work hard for them," he says. "I usually write in the mornings. I do not wake up very early. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old typewriter, not a laptop." He receives 50 to 100 letters a week, which he enjoys. He tries to answer them all, but now he has some help with this.

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it, there were big piles of soft sawdust. One afternoon, Michael and his friends climbed up to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge and looked at the lake. 
Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down!" He jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. He called them cowards to make them jump. They looked scared at first, but one by one, they jumped down and laughed when they landed.
After a while, one friend said, "Let’s go back up and jump again." They were not very excited, but they climbed back to the roof. They jumped off quickly until only Michael was left. The others were down below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike! What’s wrong?"
Michael wanted to jump, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, feeling nervous. He tried to count to ten and take a deep breath, but he couldn’t jump. His friends started to laugh at him because he was taking too long. They shouted, "You’re a coward! Are you going to stay up there all night?" When he didn’t move, they began to walk away.
Michael felt sad and alone. He looked at the ground for a long time. The sun was setting, getting bigger and bigger in the sky. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped down into the sawdust. He lay there for a long time, and the yard was quiet because the workers had gone home.
After a while, he got up and walked home, feeling ashamed. He was late for dinner, and his stepmother said, "You should be able to get home on time. If you can’t, maybe you should stay in tonight." She was a kind woman, but Michael didn’t really hear her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy in your job? Do you want to change but don’t know how? Kitty Doherty has some good advice. Many people who want to change their job go to a careers adviser. 
First, you will write a short history about yourself. Then, you will take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will get a summary of the results and suggestions for different careers. You may also learn about any training you might need.
I tried Career Analysts, a big organization that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school. I was with about ten other people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I reminded myself that it was not about passing or failing. The tests were hard to understand. They included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes.
After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He used my test results and our conversation to write a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was a bit sad to learn that I did not do well in the science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse! However, it was good to hear that I made the right choice in journalism.
Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts for help. She said, "Losing my job was a chance to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some results surprised her. "I didn’t know I was good at design. But I had to think about the cost of training in design," she said. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she decided to use her current skills and work in a job that suited her better. Now, she is a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have found this job without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she really wanted to do. She has sent many friends there, and they are all happy with the service.
Some people feel they really needed help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services and made important decisions. After working at a bank for six years, she thought her job was boring and wanted a new challenge. She didn’t know what to do, so she went to the adviser with an open mind. The tests showed she was interested in sciences. She had four meetings with the adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped her remember what she said. After the fourth meeting, she decided to study geology and start a degree later this year. She thinks the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the money. Now, she is much happier.
However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, a sales representative, said, "I didn’t know where to go in my career. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. I got many new ideas, but I didn’t like them because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself." She felt that if she had told a friend the same things, they would have given her similar advice.

**Fun at the Dentist's?**
If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a nice blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Half of the people only visit the dentist when they are in pain. They are scared." To help with this, he wants to make the office a place where people feel safe. That is why he does not wear a white coat. Many people think a white coat means pain. Jerome believes that dental visits should be relaxing and enjoyable.
This is surprising for many people who think dental visits are painful or very serious. Jerome says, "If people feel relaxed and happy, they will forget their bad experiences." One of his new ideas is to use virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental office in Britain to use them, and they are very popular." Patients wear the headsets during their check-up. They sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while Jerome checks their teeth. Then, the headset shows them a special view of their mouth.
Most patients like this part of their visit. The office also smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like oranges. Jerome wants people to feel that this is not a normal dentist's office. The usual dentist smell can make people feel scared. I thought the nice smell in the office was very pleasant.
Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, but he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation ideas are important, but giving good treatment is the most important thing. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a little strange at first, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about new dental methods. He says, "When you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for you too." He wants to change the serious way of British dentistry. 
At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers a cup of tea, asks what video he wants to watch, and leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a beautiful salon than a regular dentist's office.

**Bitter Water Becomes Popular**
Chocolate comes from South America and is now a big business around the world. In Britain, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is about eight percent of all chocolate sales. People eat more chocolate at Christmas than at any other time.
The cacao plant, which is used to make chocolate, was first grown by the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South America, Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is big like a melon and has 20 to 40 seeds inside. When these seeds are dried, they become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, these are often called cocoa beans. This name is a mistake from the 17th century when they were also called cacoa and cocao beans.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language. They added spices to this drink for special occasions. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took a long time for this recipe to reach Europe.
In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in big cities in Europe where people could drink chocolate. Until the last century, people made chocolate drinks from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, a man named CJ van Houten from the Netherlands made chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. 
The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate and sugar to make a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk to make milk chocolate. 
At first, French companies sold most of the chocolate in Britain. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract customers with a French name. Then, Cadbury created the Dairy Milk bar in 1905. They advertised it as healthy because it had milk from the English countryside. This helped it compete with fancy French chocolates.
Now, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies are trying new ideas to attract customers. They are making chocolate bars into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to get more buyers.
However, cacao farmers are still struggling because cocoa bean prices fell in the late 1980s. Many small farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old and is very good at his art. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy making beautiful objects from shells. 
As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring at all. He is very interesting and his creations are beautiful. He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I don’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them." Peter never planned to sell his work. About five years ago, some friends told him he should have an exhibition so more people could see his art. They helped him talk to a gallery owner in London. At his first exhibition, 70% of his pieces were sold.
His second exhibition just opened. The prices for his work are very high, around £2,000 for some decorations. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he does not set the prices. He believes his work is unique, and the gallery owner told him that one day, people will want his pieces because he will stop making them.
Peter wishes he had started this art earlier in his life. He thinks he could have made even more wonderful things. Now, he feels he cannot do as much because he is older. However, his work is very different from the common shell items you find in seaside shops. He has a creative mind and makes boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of very realistic flowers.
Peter has his own way of working and uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens." His work is very detailed and colorful.
Peter travels to many places to find beautiful tiny shells. He has been to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He lies on the beach to look for shells. He only collects dead shells and does not take shells with living creatures in them. He explains that many people walk on the beach and break shells, and the sea also breaks them. He believes it is okay to collect shells that are no longer home to any creatures. 
Peter’s argument about collecting shells is strong, especially when you see how beautiful his work is.

**The Schoolgirl Model**
Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model who travels to many beautiful places and appears on magazine covers. When she is not modeling, she studies for her school exams. 
One day, a reporter named Jane Laidlaw is waiting to meet Kira. The receptionist at the modeling agency tells Jane that Kira will be late. Jane worries about this. She thinks about all the bad things she has heard about models, like they can be difficult or vain. She wonders if Kira will come at all.
When Kira arrives, she is smiling and relaxed. She is with her mother. Kira is not wearing fancy clothes; she has on a simple black dress and trainers. She seems friendly and nice. Kira explains that all models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work. Her mother looks proud of her.
Kira became a model by chance. Her older sister suggested she enter a modeling competition. Kira did not want to, but her sister sent in some photos anyway. When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. This made her feel confident, and she won the competition easily. After that, a modeling agency in London offered her work.
Now, Kira has to manage her life as a model and a student. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard to understand because she is not a selfish person. She says, "I have become more confident, but I am still the same person."
Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job. Kira cannot always make plans with her friends because she does not know her schedule. However, her friends are understanding and do not complain.
Kira has the looks and support to have a great career. Not many people can say that before finishing school. At the end of the interview, Jane asks Kira what she would like to do if she were not a model. Kira thinks for a moment and says, "I would like to do what you are doing."

**Father and Son Search for Gold**
Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son from Canada. They have traveled from the cold north of Canada to hot Africa to find gold. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain could have a lot of gold, about 10,000 ounces. After ten years of digging, they believe they are very close to finding a lot of gold worth five million dollars.
Terence, who is 68 years old and from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold. We just need to dig a little more to find it all." The father and son have worked hard to find gold. They started their search after Terence read about gold in an area called the "Dolgellau gold belt" near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. 
They read old mining books and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth. Then, they chose a good place to dig. They cleared away plants and found small pieces of gold in the rocks. For ten years, they got permission to work on the land, took samples of the earth, and removed old cars and trash. They dug out a lot of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter deep hole.
Now, they need more money. They have spent their savings on this project. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig deeper where the gold is. Chris Madden said, "Right now, it looks difficult, but we have some people we can ask for help."
As news about their digging spread, many people in the area became interested. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and the people there are hopeful. Peter Woolven, who manages the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, it could bring more visitors here. But I hope many people do not come and damage the hillside."
The gold industry in Wales has become much smaller since the late 1880s when many people worked in many mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen, closed a month ago. Now, more individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. He is 70 years old and said, "Searching for gold is very exciting. It feels like an adventure to find hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and does research about marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemicals in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. 
When she is not teaching, Rachel goes into a small steel vehicle to explore underwater. This vehicle is the size of a small car. It can dive three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is very little space. Rachel can touch the two pilots who are with her. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. 
A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and then three hours to come back up. If there is a problem and they need to get to the surface quickly, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out, which goes quickly to the surface. Rachel says, "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a very nice trip."
Rachel remembers her first dive. She got into the vehicle on a ship with an instructor. He explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would feel in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There, they found many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. 
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers," which are underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of these volcanoes and looks like black smoke. It comes out very fast and is very hot, at 350 degrees.
Rachel felt scared the first time she dived with an American team. They were using equipment when suddenly there was a loud explosion. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was amazing!
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the window of the vehicle and sees the volcanoes, she feels wonder. She thinks, "I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has seen this." Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her PhD. When she finally saw them, it was an incredible feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. I was very tired. I could not understand any more train times, money, or languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. 
All I had to do was buy one train ticket. Because I was under twenty-five years old, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is very different from sleeping in a bed. The train rocks you to sleep. 
Carrying all my things in a backpack made me travel simply. I learned to throw away things I did not need, like old socks and finished books. This way of traveling is part of the Inter-Rail spirit. You can forget about rules and just enjoy the trip. 
With this ticket, young people can travel to many countries in one day. On my first trip, my friends and I did not know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to see more countries. The extra travel did not cost us anything. 
We were not only interested in culture. This was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Rail travelers. We made our own plans and only saw the most interesting sights. We wanted to do something different. I was proud that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. 
We just wanted to enjoy our time together. We shared the train floor, food, water, money, and music with other travelers. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place you only knew by name. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. 
You can only understand Europe by seeing it. Watching the changing landscapes and different lifestyles gives you a real picture of the continent. Everyone knows about Europe, but it is not the same until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. 
The train trip may not show you new things in the world, but it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps people see this, even if it does not happen right away.

It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your luggage is missing. You may have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a different place with a different weather and have to wear clothes that are not right for that place.
Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes. It is hard for any airline to promise that your checked luggage will be on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.
Here is how it works: Airlines ask passengers to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for the bags to be checked and loaded onto the plane. There is also a minimum time needed to change from one flight to another. This time is often longer to help with moving the bags. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause delays. These delays can make it hard for the baggage system to work properly. 
Human mistakes can also happen, like if the label on your bag gets lost. This can be a bigger problem at large airports, called 'hubs', because many bags are processed there. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, and nine million of them were changing planes. British Airways had two million passengers changing planes at Heathrow.
Even busy airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have problems. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers quickly change planes to go to Latin America.
To avoid losing your luggage, try to book direct flights when you can and check in early. If you have to change planes, try to use the same airline for all your flights. It is also a good idea to allow more time for connecting flights by taking an earlier flight. Make sure to label your luggage with your home address and your holiday address, and include your flight numbers.
If your luggage is still missing after all this, you should talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a report about your missing bag. You need to do this before you leave the airport.

**The Kingfisher**
Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. This is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees grow over the stream, giving some shade to the shallow water. The main colors around are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and looks like a flash of light. It is there for a moment, and then it is gone, but you remember it because it is so special.
Charlie James loved kingfishers when he was young. He feels very strongly about this little bird, but he cannot say exactly why. In Greek myths, the kingfisher is a bird that was once a moon goddess. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, while its bottom was burned by the sun. This story has some truth. Kingfishers do not have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, their feathers reflect light in a way that makes them look blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or green depending on the light.
Many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. They are shy birds, but you can watch them easily from a hiding place. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back in just a few minutes and sat very close to him. But it took him four more years to take his first good picture. 
Charlie spent a lot of time by a stream where kingfishers lived. However, school took away some of his time with the birds. He missed classes and called himself an "academic failure." But people noticed his interest in kingfishers. At 16, he got a job as an advisor for a nature magazine. Later, he worked as an assistant to the editor and then became a freelance wildlife cameraman.
Now, Charlie wants to make a special kingfisher film. He wants it to have no words, just beautiful images. He likes to take pictures of the kingfisher's wings. He thinks about the colors of the bird that he has loved for many years. His photographs show some of his feelings, but he knows there is much more to his love for the kingfisher than what his work can show.

**Conducting an Orchestra**
Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. When an assistant could not come, she took their place. Later, she helped with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. I was not nervous. I like standing in front of an orchestra," she said. Anne is from America and works with a famous opera company in London that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries. She has received help from the British Arts Council and has worked with Abbado on many projects.
**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting good opportunities. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. He is thankful for the timing of his win. "If I had won earlier, I would have been forgotten," he said. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he is worried about being known only for the competition. "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned," he said. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra are inviting him back, which is good for his career.
**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera and enjoys the long practice time for opera productions. "The music needs four weeks of focus," she said. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was important for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from bigger people, which is different," she explained. She likes the complexity of opera because there are many arguments and different personalities among the singers.
**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He says conducting surprised him but he finds it very interesting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival for the first time. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like," he said. He tries his best to get the performance he wants. He has learned from all his experiences in music and performing. Now, he is open to doing different things to find out what he enjoys.
**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed him and told his agent about him. Soon, Wayne was conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was hard. He had to manage some musicians who were too relaxed and reading newspapers during the show. "I was strict with them. I always gave a clear beat and tried to get the best result," he said. He believes many musicians do not need much advice from a conductor. "I am not afraid to say what I want. If people see you are worried, it gets worse," he added. Wayne has not studied conducting formally, but he is determined and knows what he likes.

**Variations on a Theme**
If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many in Britain. We asked five families to try some of the best parks.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island would be boring. But we were surprised! The park is good for younger children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for little kids, which was very popular. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, we wanted to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. The only problem was that the park could be more exciting, and the scenery was not great. But the staff were very helpful, and the park was clean and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we did not know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it! He enjoyed the Mountain Train and liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We spent six hours there and were happy there were places to rest. The park looked nice, and the staff were friendly. There was something for everyone, even adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had a great trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and even though the girls were scared, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. For younger kids, Toy Land is very fun. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were happy they were too small for it! The park is so well made that waiting for rides is not boring. It was very clean, and the staff were great. One staff member even helped me with one of the girls when I could not sit with both of them.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We got to the park at one o'clock and were sad that it closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am a bit scared of rides, but I had fun too. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I would not go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they loved it at their age.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we felt that was true. The tallest roller-coaster in Europe, the Rocket, is very exciting. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was worse! There are many main rides, and the older kids went on them several times. Sarah was too small for some rides, but she liked the Long Slide. The staff were nice to younger children, but some were not very friendly. You need a whole day to enjoy Fantasy World. We could not tell the kids we were going home early!

**Running a Business in the Countryside**
Five women share their stories about starting a business in the countryside.
A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. "My customers are my friends," she says. Christine moved from London to the countryside when her children were small. She wanted to work from home. She had experience with computers, so her husband suggested she start a computer design business. At first, it was hard and she needed a lot of money. She was careful with her spending and talked to the bank manager when she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evening if she wants. Her business is small, and customers usually come to pick up their work.
B. **Maggy Sasanow** designs greeting cards from her home. "I enjoy being independent," she says. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no jobs in the countryside. So, she started her own business and makes 50 different greeting cards to sell to museums. She works in a big room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She does not advertise; her business grows by word of mouth. People send her work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Working alone means she misses sharing ideas with others, but she thinks there are more good things than bad.
C. **Delia Turner** makes curtains. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing. In two years, her income went from £24,000 to £80,000. She had six full-time workers, but she had to let them go when the economy got worse. This was hard because it is not easy to find jobs in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and works with women who also work from home. She has to lower her prices sometimes and look for new opportunities.
D. **Tessa Strickland** runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago to save money and because she loves the country. She likes being able to work when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at strange hours. The hard part is staying focused and closing the office door. She publishes children's books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. At first, she felt lonely because all her work experience was in London.
E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cake business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and has six employees, some of whom work part-time. She started her business ten years ago at home. She is interested in health, so she began making fruit cakes with good quality ingredients. Friends and family asked for cakes, and soon she was sending them all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made. Now, she has a baker and a cake decorator. She does not bake anymore because she manages the business. Her biggest challenge has been managing the money, as she did not have a lot to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is very special. The sons are musicians and composers, and their dad makes musical instruments. 
John and Hetty Watkins are teachers from South Wales. They wanted to buy a cello for their son, Paul, who is ten years old. But the cello was very expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one." He found a school nearby that teaches how to make instruments. He took evening classes for three years.
After making some violins, John made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says, "It turned out really well. Dad made me another cello later, and I used it until a few months ago." John has now stopped teaching to make instruments full-time. He makes about twelve violins each year. He even sold one to a famous American musician named Jaime Laredo.
Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul remembers, "I played the piano as soon as I could reach the keys." Later, he wanted to play the cello. His dad played the viola and wanted Paul to play the violin. Paul tried it for six weeks but did not like it. He liked the cellist in his dad's group and asked for lessons.
Huw, now 22, says, "My parents were supportive. I wanted to do well like Paul, but I did not feel pushed." Huw is now a pianist and composer.
Paul has done very well with the cello his dad made. He won a big music competition and became the main cellist for the BBC Symphony Orchestra when he was just 20 years old. He played his dad's cello until last year. Now, he has a very old cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music.
Paul will soon play on television with his new cello. He will perform Elgar's Cello Concerto. He says, "I will play it my way." But he cannot watch himself on TV because he will be playing at the Cheltenham Festival that night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will perform in London at the same time.
John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' music events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**
The National Trust is a group that wants to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust.
Gareth says that a National Trust Warden needs common sense. "You must be good with people," he explains. "You talk to farmers, visitors, and builders every day." Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. Many people wanted to be the warden, but Gareth got the job because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he did not have formal training.
Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand the farmers' problems. He says, "I can talk to farmers as equals, and they cannot trick me!" His farming background also helps him do the physical work, like building fences and planting trees.
Since working with the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature. He remembers picking flowers and collecting butterflies when he was young. Now, he sees that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following government rules.
At first, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted things done their way. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. Gareth says, "We are close to working together."
Gareth's job includes conservation, allowing people to visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. He wants to finish jobs quickly and without problems. He enjoys seeing projects completed, but he also spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.
Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to people, but some visitors can be difficult. "Some people come in, ask for everything, and leave as if they own the place. It can be annoying!" he says. But he believes that common sense is important.
If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But be ready to wait a long time for a job on the Lleyn Peninsula!

**The Netball Captain**
In this article about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slowinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra is very busy because the World Championships are next month. She teaches at a local school and then trains in a supermarket car park.
I asked Kendra if people look at her when she trains. She said, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t see much else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s it."
Kendra said, "My life is all about being my best for the Championships. I have a strict schedule to be very fit." This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries joining. She is happy to have support from home. "It is special," she said. "We want to make netball better in this country. There will be more pressure because people expect us to play well."
Their first game is against Barbados right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but she knows they are a strong team. The England team is ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra says the Championships will be hard. "You must push yourself every day. There is no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, you only have one chance."
Kendra has played netball for fifteen years, and the game has become faster and tougher. "You train hard to win," she said. "But after the game, we are all friends."
Netball is also using more science to test fitness. Kendra believes it is important to think and train like top players. As captain, she wants to have a strong mind and help her team. "I support and encourage them," she said.
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. When she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**
What should you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents might not see their child's needs until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most regular schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but children who are good at music need special support that regular schools may not provide. 
In Britain, there are five specialist music schools. These schools help children aged 7 to 18 who have musical talent. The schools create a friendly place where these children can learn from professional musicians. Students spend a lot of time on music, like taking lessons, playing in orchestras, and practicing. They also have some regular school subjects like English, math, and science, but the focus is on music.
The specialist music schools are independent, which means they are not run by the government. The classes are small, so teachers can give more attention to each student. Most students live at the school, which means they eat and sleep there. This helps them be with other children who love music too.
However, there are some problems. The schools are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for students who live there. The schools try to help families with scholarships, which are financial aids. Also, not all parents want to send their young children to live at school. The directors of these schools worry about admitting very young children because the environment is strict and serious. They want to help children grow up to be well-rounded people.
Sometimes, being in a music school can be stressful. A child’s musical talent might fade as they grow older, and the pressure to succeed can be hard. The schools watch each student closely and offer help when needed. Many former students say they learned a lot from the music teaching, but some wish they had more academic subjects. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more than just music.
Because of this, it might be better to wait until a child is older to decide on a specialist music school. Children who are good at both music and academics can do well in regular schools with good music programs. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges, which offer great teaching and opportunities to play in groups. However, this option may not be possible for families who live far from big cities like London.

**An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The big garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden has many of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. There are two long flower beds along the path that goes from one side of the garden to the other. The colors and shapes of the flowers are beautiful. The previous owners of the house were good gardeners and left many plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint individual flowers instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of flowers, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio.
