She says, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I take one flower out and paint it. This might take a few days." Sometimes, it can take a couple of years to finish a painting.
Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips and poppies bloom. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." She also finds beauty in how flowers change over time. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look amazing. At first, they may seem boring, but they become more interesting as they open up.
Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks.
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they grow well in her garden. She lets her garden grow freely, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they do not break anything. Susan is busy preparing for two art exhibitions, so she has hired another gardener. Even though she needs to paint, she knows that to stay connected to her flowers, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex, England. This is her second year working in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a regular job. She meets many interesting people every week.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she thinks is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. On good days, she can ski until 4:30 p.m.
After skiing, Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep because it is not good to sleep before work. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She does not like coming back to a messy kitchen in the morning. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. Good guests can make her week better, but some weeks are not as good.
Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. But on Saturday nights, she does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.
On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for the guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. She clears the breakfast, strips the beds, and gets everything ready for the new guests. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., when cleaning is done, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests are confused and have many questions.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. She takes them to the ski shop and gets a ride back to the chalet. Then it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she talks with friends, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my clothes for Marie Claire was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, but here I was rushing around. Some people on the fashion team looked stressed, but my job is not very stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I like seeing how magazines work, but I enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."
Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I wore leather boots and dark blue trousers to the zoo. They gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. When I petted an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I was very dirty, but I had a great day. When I stop working in fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."
Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She worked with the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes do not see daylight at work. It was hard work, but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I did not think gardening would be so hard. I enjoy gardening, but I will not stop being a nurse."
Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on the TV show Ground Force. He worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out medicine. I thought I would feel faint, but I was okay. The nurses are friendly, and it felt very different from my usual job with men. I think my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but I felt good about helping."
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different. People looked at me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety, which I knew from my training. When the passengers got on the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren who would not sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I do not exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I saw that some trainers did not eat very healthily, but they all drink a lot of water. I would not change my job for this, but it made me want to join a gym and be healthier."

**On the Rails**
Five famous people share their favorite memories of train journeys with Andrew Morgan.
**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to go back as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes along the coast that goes to Italy. It shows you beautiful views of the sea. It does not matter what the weather is like or what time of year it is; it is always lovely. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and houses in France. You feel like you are looking into the homes of rich and famous people. The people on the train are always lively because there are many tourists and locals, all enjoying the beautiful journey.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which goes across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was too young and troublesome. I had to stay with my aunt. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still had not traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first big train station I ever saw, and its big glass roof amazed me.
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am thankful for one train in particular: the Blue Train. It took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was lovely as we traveled through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after our wedding.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were writing articles about a trip around the world and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not reliable; we were just told a day to travel. The driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train went through beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream, like traveling on the moon.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people have favorite memories of trains from when they were children, but I do not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It was not until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that had a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old train line that volunteers took care of. That is where my love for steam trains started. When we were not filming, we took every chance to ride the train. When I went back last year, everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

How to Get Your Story Published**
Do you want to publish your story? Margaret Stubbs can help you. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or a book. Who should I send it to?" 
First, you need to learn about publishers and improve your writing skills. To sell your writing, you must know about the writing world. No matter what you write, you should understand the market you want to reach. 
One good way to learn is by reading a lot. Go to your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading different things will help you see what publishers want. Remember, new magazines and books come out all the time, so keep your knowledge up to date. 
If you want to write short love stories, find magazines that publish them. Get recent copies and read them. Learn what kind of stories they like and who their readers are. The readers want different things, and the editor wants to meet their needs.
Sometimes, new writers send their stories to me and say, "This was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" I never want to discourage anyone, but it is often true that their work is not ready to be published. Many new writers are too quick to send their work out before they are ready. 
If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. Most successful writers have worked in publishing or journalism for many years before they succeed. 
When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while you wait for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more stories. Each one will be better, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. This will help you feel more confident. 
Do not throw away your stories; try to make them better. In the beginning, it is best not to show your work to others. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before they succeeded. 
Do everything you can to improve as a writer. Look for a creative writing course near you. If you can’t find one, join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and confidence from other writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.

**No Title**
On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were many more people than I thought. The station did not feel clean and nice like usual. Older couples with matching bags filled the benches, and many college students had their bags on the floor.
A man with grey hair was walking around and talking to different people. He looked rich: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft coat. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going north, but to New York. He thanked her and moved on.
Next, he asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going to Wilmington. He kept walking to a couple with matching bags. I was curious about what he was doing. I was going to Philadelphia too, but I understood why he didn’t ask me. He looked at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area.
He looked stressed. He asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia. She was about thirty-five years old and looked like a school teacher. She said she was going to Philadelphia. The man asked her for a favor. I stood a little away and pretended to look at my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could see that the woman was getting nervous. The man said, “It’s not too difficult, I promise!”
They announced my train, and people started moving to Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man was talking to the woman. He said, “My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning and went home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn’t know what to do.”
The woman felt sorry for him. I thought it was better to stay quiet and see what he would say next. He continued, “I told her to stay at the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport.” I thought it was strange. If it was so important, why didn’t he go himself?
The woman asked, “Why don’t you go yourself?” He replied, “I can’t leave my wife alone. She is in a wheelchair.” I thought this was not a good excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a padded envelope, not a regular one. It was the size of a small book. I thought, “Watch out, lady!”

**Gary and Me**
John Moore is the owner of a restaurant. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant.
When John found out about the restaurant, he went to see it. It was in bad shape, but it was perfect for him. Running the restaurant reminded him of his childhood. His mother worked in a factory, and John felt sad when he was left alone. He wanted to have time for family. John's wife took care of the children and helped with the money while he ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. They talked to the customers from a young age, which was good for them.
Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into the bath like it was a swimming pool and hurt himself. As he grew older, he did small jobs to earn pocket money. By ten, he worked in the kitchen every weekend and had a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and woke up early. John liked seeing Gary help in the family business.
Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the adult cooks and sometimes was in charge. He could make over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would work in catering because he had talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.
Recently, Gary started playing the drums and has his own band. John worries about what will happen to Gary's cooking if the music becomes successful. He advised Gary to focus on one thing to be successful. John told him that if he wanted to achieve something, he should do it by age 30.
At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he finished his work very quickly and even helped other students. John is very proud of Gary's success with his TV cooking show. He always tells Gary that to get what you want, you must work hard because no one gives you anything. John believes Gary has taken his advice to heart. He thinks that if Gary remembers even a little of what he has said, it is a good thing.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**
Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is to know someone. If you have a friend who knows someone leaving a flat, that can help. But if you are new in Dublin, like Jo, you don’t have any contacts. Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. Dublin felt very big and unknown to her. She took the train to work there without thinking too much about it. Everyone at her school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to go to bigger places and have better lives. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.
Jo’s mother thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel. It was run by nuns, so her mother thought she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because many hostels are cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked in a hotel, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. But Jo didn’t know they were talking about her. She answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, “Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.” It was close to her job at the post office and seemed perfect. Jo hoped it would be nice and that the people would like her. 
There was no long line for this flat because it was not just a flat for rent; they needed a third girl to share. The ad said “own television,” which made Jo think it might be too fancy for her. The house looked normal, a red-brick building with a basement. The flat was upstairs. As Jo climbed the stairs, a girl with a college scarf came down. She looked unhappy and said, “This place is terrible. The girls are awful.”
Jo asked what happened. The girl said, “That girl who just left was so snobby. She just looked around and acted like she was better than us.” Jo continued up the stairs. 
“Hi, I’m Nessa,” said the girl with a colorful shirt. “We are having tea. Want to join us?” She had two mugs with her name and another mug that said “Other.” “We can put your name on a mug if you stay with us,” Nessa said kindly. 
Jo was happy to meet them and hoped she would find a good place to live.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**
People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside places, movies, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about the problems dolphins face.
Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart animals, they can feel human emotions, and they make us think of freedom in the ocean. We see this love for dolphins in TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest with Darwin. However, these happy images hide the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas.
The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals would be protected by laws and cared for in special areas. Sadly, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a big wildlife disaster.
There are forty different types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common are striped dolphins, common dolphins, bottlenose dolphins, and smaller harbour porpoises. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the sea. We see them in small groups, and we do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were often found in places like the Thames River in Britain. Now, they can only be found in a few areas, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that are left show signs of stress.
It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are going down. Overfishing is taking away a lot of fish from the sea, which also affects dolphins and porpoises. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are caught in one area, they may not have enough time to find food somewhere else. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that can trap dolphins. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on beaches in France and Cornwall. Marks on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.
Dolphins can also store harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in dolphins. Female dolphins produce milk that can contain these poisons, which can harm their babies. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s milk.
Another big problem for dolphins is noise from humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise travels much better than in the air. This noise can disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you feel balanced, especially when life feels busy and stressful. Many articles talk about fitness because it is really good for you. 
There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to. Exercise helps your muscles and changes your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit better. It can also help prevent injuries. Exercise can improve areas like your thighs, stomach, and arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood flow.
Exercise can also help with feelings of sadness and tiredness. It can help you sleep better and reduce stress. It can even help with some health problems. 
If you are not convinced yet, remember that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. But be careful! If you train too hard or lift too much weight, you can get hurt. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are not sure what is best for you.
Good posture is very important. It affects how you look and feel. If you slouch, try to imagine a balloon pulling you up. This can help you stand tall and breathe better. Good posture also makes your body look slimmer.
Stretching is also important. It helps you move better and prevents injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will feel more flexible and fit. 
A good exercise routine should include warming up, stretching, a workout, and cooling down.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for many months? They are looking for the perfect shot of wildlife. In East Africa, it is hard to find them because they are often in the jungles and plains. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained a lot for six months. This has caused some problems for them. 
Newman said they had to buy a special piece of equipment. This helps Amanda pull him out when their vehicle gets stuck in the mud. Together, they have made some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their famous film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, looking for another shy animal, the jackal.
Traveling film-makers have been filming wildlife around the world since TV started. I talked to Newman at a safari lodge, where he was meeting other people. He said, "We do argue sometimes, but we get over it quickly." They do not see one another as the leader. They both understand animals in the same way.
When they travel, they set up their tents each night. But now, they are staying in one place. They wake up at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before to keep it warm. They eat pre-packed meals that they heat up. Newman said, "We can be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be stressful."
It can be tough living in the wild, but they love being close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would go off alone and then come back to greet her family. She even greeted their car as part of her routine.
Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. Since then, they spend four months in one place to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they start, they must submit a script for approval.
Newman said, "Amanda and I have a good working relationship because we share the same ideas. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals. We want to touch people's hearts. If we can make people feel something, that is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**
In this article about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra was busy with her usual day before the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. Suzie asked her if people looked at her strangely while she trained. Kendra replied, "I focus on my movements and don’t notice much else."
Kendra said, "My life is all about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries joining. Kendra feels special to have support from home. She wants to improve the reputation of netball in England. There will be more pressure because the home crowd will expect them to play well. Their first game is against Barbados right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said they usually win against them, but it will still be exciting to play.
The England team is ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the Championships will be hard. "You must push yourself every day. There is no rest between games. You only have one chance to win," she explained. In the fifteen years she has played, netball has become faster and tougher. Kendra said, "You train hard to win, but after the game, we are all friends."
Netball is also using more science to test fitness. Kendra believes it is important to think and train like top players. As captain, she wants to have a strong mind and help her team. She has planned her netball career carefully and decided that this competition will be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on this big event. When she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might cry because her loyal fans will support her.

**In Hot Water**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and does research about marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemicals in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. 
When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater and is the size of a small car. It can dive three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel says, "I can touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move. We must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside." A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.
If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out, like a ping-pong ball in a bath. It goes quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice journey.
Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She got in with an instructor on a ship. He explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There, they found many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was leaving some equipment to study a project that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves. She teaches so she can do her research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out very fast and is very hot, at 350 degrees.
The only time Rachel felt scared was when she dived with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was an explosion. There was a loud bang, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, they were very relieved to be alive.
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels amazed. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has seen this." Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her Ph.D. When she finally saw them, it was an incredible feeling.

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people make opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume, and our words.
Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to get her degree. When she graduated, she felt very confident. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. That morning, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she didn’t want to be late. She believed it was important to be on time. Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone does not take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who care about how they look are more likely to care about their jobs. People think what is inside is important, but in an interview, you should try to look your best."
Many people forget how important it is to have a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a big accounting firm. When her boss retired, she applied for the job but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not look like an office manager. He suggested she improve her clothes before applying again. She was shocked because she thought she did a good job and that her clothes should not matter.
How we move and use our hands can also affect what the interviewer thinks. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message comes from our words, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our words and our facial expressions send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to our body language. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion. Her interview went very well, and she was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss saw how excited she was and offered her a lower salary than she wanted. She thinks she could have gotten more money if she had controlled her excitement.
Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can tell you what the company does. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This shows you care about the company.
Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long paragraphs. Successful communicators use short sentences and clear points."

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. Matt felt that working there became boring and not fun anymore. He did not plan to leave his job yet, but he lost it suddenly. He did not get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. His big chance came when he met the head chef of a local hotel. He started selling meat to the hotel, and now he also sells it by mail order. Matt is happy to be out of the office, but he still works a lot, about 80 to 90 hours a week.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Ron was different because he did not want to go back to his old job. Most people his age need to work for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they did not know anyone. They left their friends, but they still keep in touch, and many friends visit them.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She enjoyed being a lawyer and made good money, but she worked very long hours. Katherine did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she left. Many people thought she would get bored, but she has not. She has deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier and less stressed now. However, she misses talking to her colleagues. She loves being responsible for her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her fault.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance when he was 22. He liked the excitement but did not find it rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he decided to travel for a year. During that time, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. Paul knew he needed training to change careers, so he took massage courses. Then he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets about his choice. Now he feels in control of his life and is very happy.

**Dedicated to Their Sports**
Four young sports stars talk about their lives.
**A Darius (runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My best moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Sadly, not many people heard about it, and I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there with good training facilities and nightlife. But I have to be disciplined. If my friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but hard work is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics - that would be amazing.
**B Gabriel (surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are in the morning, so I have to skip late-night parties. I don’t mind too much, but I love sleeping in, and I have to give that up too. But it is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job presenting a surfing show on TV. Now, I am a bit of a celebrity.
**C Dieter (yacht racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate our wins in a big way. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we don’t look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months each year, so it is nice to come back and hang out with my friends. You can’t always focus on sports; it is not healthy. I am known in sailing, but not many people recognize me on the street. I don’t want to be a celebrity. I get nice letters from fans who want signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.
**D Tomas (tennis player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and hear the crowd cheer for me. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many fans around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping. But it has some problems too. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports; you need to be serious and professional. I focus on my game now and will think about other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t buy everything, and when I say yes, I feel bad for giving them unhealthy food. But I also feel bad when I say no all the time. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices. I can’t win."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big place for this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things. Parents worry about how bad sugar is for teeth, but children are influenced by fun and emotional ads.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel they are competing with ads and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow ads to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. Even if they don’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is what they want."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks about food with her children, but she feels unhappy about how she handles their requests. "My son listens to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels. I’ve talked so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have less conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We don’t buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am happy, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce problems between parents and children by moving sweets away from checkout areas or by having play areas for children. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could bring in more customers.

**The Merrion Hotel: Luxury and Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both guests and staff.
Peter MacCann is the General Manager. He wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but it will save money in the future. MacCann is happy with how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature from 14°C to 25°C.
The hotel is popular with business guests. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the guests will be business travelers. To help them, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel is ready for new improvements. They have added extra cables for future technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced easily. DVD recorders can also be updated when needed. 
Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and cozy bedrooms. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has designed a new kitchen and improved the restaurant. The hotel now has better parking than before. This partnership is good for both the chef and the hotel.
With great technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women how they get their energy in life.
A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get energy from excitement. I like challenges and learning new things. Right now, I am learning flamenco dancing, which is fun and gives me energy. If I am bored, I feel tired. Doing something useful, even a little, makes me feel good."
B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. Work is not a problem for me. When I am tired, I need sleep to feel better. I try to sleep enough. Exercise helps me feel energetic, but sometimes it is hard to find the energy to do it. I do yoga once a week and some workouts at home. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."
C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat very healthy, but I have a lot of enthusiasm and a positive attitude. I believe we should enjoy life. I like to achieve goals and have fun. I love my job and being around young people. I enjoy taking photos and writing fun song lyrics when I travel."
D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in being positive. I enjoy working with kids because they are full of energy. Smiling at people can make you feel good. I try to eat healthy and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a strict exercise plan. I get energy from playing with kids."
E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "I love making gardens from empty land. I once turned a concrete area into a garden. It was better than any workout. I also get energy from knowing people want to read my writing. I like exploring nature, even if it’s private land. It feels fun and childlike."
F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I think it’s important to care about what you do. I like to take risks and stay motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do makes me tired. I used to be on many committees, but I didn’t like the time they took. You have limited energy, so use it for what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For rich people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. 
In the early 1900s, skating was seen as stylish. But in 1924, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie changed this. She made skating more athletic and popular. Today, skating combines art and sport. It is both beautiful and hard work.
For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can go faster as you get better. Your body position helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and lean a little forward. Relaxing is very important when skating. 
To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It is not too hard! If you keep practicing, you can make bigger movements as you get better.
Learning how to fall is one of the first things a skater should know. Even professional skaters fall. To fall safely, stay relaxed. This helps reduce the pain when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.
Once you can skate confidently, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn the basics, turns, jumps, and spins.
Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To skate well, you should practice exercises regularly. It can be dangerous to skate if your body is stiff. Warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also makes your heart and lungs stronger and helps your body stay fit. When combined with swimming or jogging, skating is great for your health.

**Trills and Bills**
Seeing a talented child win a medal can make you very happy. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about their lives.
A. **Annika Reeder**, 15 years old, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "Right now, I work very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take training one day at a time. When I am very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes you stiff."
B. **Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great talent from a young age. I have seen some parents push their children, but it doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy. You have to want to do it yourself. People say we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me. Now she has met people from all over the world and is very confident."
C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten years old. She has won the British National Championship. "It’s good that my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love show-jumping. Even without my parents, I would still do it because I am very determined. I am happy when they are proud of me, but I do it for myself. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. **Sarah's mother** says, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, she loved it. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is always happy on a horse and knows what to do. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."
E. **Jane McShane**, 10 years old, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are very friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about being proud; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."
F. **Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. I am happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is special. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is the tallest man in Britain at 228 cm.
Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are getting healthier because we are eating better food now. Professor Chris Stringer says we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago.
In the past, our ancestors ate many different foods. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Now, most of the world's land is used for farming, and we mainly eat just three plants: wheat, rice, and maize. This limited diet has made many people unhealthy.
In Ohio, scientists found that when they started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sick and underweight farmers. They had more tooth problems and diseases. Corn, which was thought to be good, actually caused health problems. However, farming spread because it could feed many more people than hunting could.
Today, many people are still not getting enough good food, but in Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are getting better. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good change, but it also brings problems. Beds have not gotten longer since 1860, and there is less space for legs on planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often.
People wonder how tall we can get. Some scientists think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. But there is a twist. While some people are getting taller because of better food, as a group, humans might actually be getting shorter. A long time ago, during the ice age, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we are getting thinner and shorter. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might get even shorter.

**Studio Audiences**
What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of making television, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?"
Some people think that studio audiences are not important. They say that even people who work in TV do not respect them. I thought studio audiences were just made up of silly people who want to be on TV for a moment. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. TV shows try to attract different types of people for different programs.
Many people who watch TV at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for a long time in a studio just to watch what they can see at home? One reason is that people hope to be on TV for a second. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She said, "I came for a chance to be on TV."
Another reason is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket." Many of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when you see them. This is true for some shows, but not all. One studio manager said, "We believe a good show does not need these signs."
Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors. I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were far from where I sat, so I ended up watching the show on a monitor.
Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch TV, but that is not what matters. For most people in the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**
**Bruce**  
I do not like wild landscapes. I like places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in my diary. This was my first try at travel writing, which I later became known for.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive than regular tickets. The view is not amazing. The train goes over Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding a chair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closely and find something new.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. Some brave surfers come, but most visitors just enjoy the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into beautiful valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple place with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a wide-open moorland, perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is a quiet and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**
We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She was very excited because she found a pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank to keep animals for a short time. 
I got home late. I quickly put a pot on the stove to boil. Suddenly, I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their bedroom. There was a problem with our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca. Bianca was a Mother's Day gift for me. 
Domino was running around the room with the mouse in his mouth. He wanted to escape with his catch. I jumped into the room but tripped and fell on the floor. Then I saw the snake. It had escaped from the table and was now on the floor. 
The snake was moving while the cat, mouse, and kids were jumping around, making a lot of noise. The dog was barking too. The pot in the kitchen boiled over, and I ran to turn it off. When I came back, I grabbed Domino by the tail and saved the mouse from him. 
I looked at the snake to see how to catch it. It was hard to catch. I sat on the floor and tried to calm the snake down. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body. I carefully lifted the snake and walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to let it go near a tree. 
When I finally let go of the snake, it surprised me by climbing over my shoulders. It felt like a warm, colorful shawl. My four children and I stood together with the snake. My oldest son, DJ, said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not." 
I asked the children to help me encourage the snake to move. Slowly, it started to go away. It climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake left, my three-year-old son, Clay, said, "Wow, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**
In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is becoming rare. But for me, getting a letter is special. I love the excitement of seeing a letter in the mail, finding out who it is from, and reading what it says.
I have been writing letters for a long time. It started when I wrote little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for gifts at Christmas and birthdays. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.
When I was 18, I moved to London to study to be a doctor. I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. My father sometimes wrote long, funny letters, which I loved. Most of the letters were about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.
I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we wrote to each other. Writing letters helped our relationships. I found it easier to say what I felt in writing than in talking.
I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a lot of news! I love getting letters from other countries, too. I have a friend in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. I also write to a lady in France. We started talking in a restaurant, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her because she doesn’t speak English. She has visited us, and we have stayed at her home.
This summer, my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that we kept in touch for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about us!
I am happy that my children are also writing letters. Like my mother, I make them write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, too, thanks to my penfriend.
I really hope that letter writing does not become a lost art!

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many ancient pictures carved into rocks in France are being damaged. There are about 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego, in the French Alps. Scientists are worried that these drawings will not last for future generations. The mountain has drawings that are 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. 
More and more tourists are visiting the site, but some are ruining the pictures with graffiti. Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think these pictures will always be here. But if the damage continues, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and damaging them. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. 
When tourists cannot take a good photo, they rub the drawings to make them look clearer. The weather already polishes the drawings, but some people scratch their own names or drawings into the rocks with sharp sticks. 
Experts have different ideas about how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the best way is to make the mountain a "no-go" area. This would mean only guided tours could visit. He believes this is necessary to save the site and allow research to continue. 
But Clottes disagrees. He thinks this plan is too strict and will upset local people. He says the site has been a historic monument for many years, and we should do our best to protect it. 
David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He believes it is important for people to see it, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage. He says they might need to charge a fee to help pay for guards, as there is not enough money from the government. 
Annie Echassoux, who has studied the site, is worried that as it becomes easier to reach, more damage will happen. She thinks the best solution is to block off some areas and have guides. She believes money must be found to protect this historic site, or we will lose the drawings for future generations.

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t buy everything, and if I say yes, I feel bad for buying them junk food. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices. I can’t win."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big place for this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things. Parents worry about how bad sugar is for teeth, but children are influenced by fun and emotional ads.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel they are competing with ads and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow ads to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. Even if they don’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is what they want."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks about food with her children, but she feels unhappy about how she handles their requests. "My son listens to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels. I’ve talked so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have less conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We don’t buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am happy, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce problems between parents and children by moving sweets away from checkout areas or by having play areas for children. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could bring in more customers.

**Going Up the Wall**
Climbers used to go to the mountains to climb. Now, people can climb indoors or outdoors. The crowd is excited. High on the climbing wall, the French climber Francois Lombard is hanging upside down by two fingers. He is in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall.
In the past, climbers practiced on cliffs. They climbed in places with good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and made climbing less boring.
Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls. These walls were made with special bricks that climbers could hold on to. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in the mid-1960s at Leeds University. He put natural rock in concrete to create a climbing wall.
In the 1970s, many climbing walls were built in sports halls, but they had problems. The walls were straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers got bored of the same routes.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that looked like the shapes on cliffs. This material could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to make climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so they could build overhanging walls easily. This new system gave climbers many different holds to use.

**So You Want to Be an Actor**
If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they might say it is a risky job. Acting can be risky because there are many actors but not enough jobs for all of them. When you decide to be an actor, some friends may think you are making a bad choice, but others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. 
Becoming an actor is a personal choice. You are responsible for your own dreams. There are no easy ways to become an actor. You do not have to take tests, and finishing your training does not mean you will get a job. Success depends on luck and talent. 
There is a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding. Many people want to know what talent is. Talent is a natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person’s courage and belief in what they do. 
Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to perform. 
When you ask successful actors how they did it, they might not have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills, but they also know that their success can change. Disappointment is a big problem for actors. 
Last month, you might have been without a job, selling clothes or working in a restaurant. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often do not talk about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to deal with the stress of competition and the fear of being rejected. 
No one likes to be rejected. This fear is there from the moment you start trying to get acting jobs. You are saying you are ready and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care about your acting, others will not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**
We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.
A. If you ask people about a famous TV cook and writer, many will say Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world. She loves exciting food and knows what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is called "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is very important for modern cooks. It has easy and expert advice on cooking, with many great recipes that are not boring. It has been updated and is the best book to answer the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which one would it be?"
B. Raymond Blanc became a famous chef in just 15 years. He is the owner of a well-known French restaurant in Britain. Now, he has a book to go with his first TV show called "Blanc Mange." Raymond wants to help everyone cook better by showing how and why ingredients work together. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. His book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It is a practical book that explains why some dishes can go wrong and teaches some basic food science. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that means the best in French cooking. For 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained many students. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have released a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook." This book has 100 of the school's best recipes. The recipes are classic but still fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also changed some recipes to be healthier. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then has sections for Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have shared their famous recipes and secrets in this book.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, does not agree. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes you can make tasty food in the same time it takes to get a pizza. He has already written two successful books about this. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and friendly way, with over 200 recipes from around the world. Just because he likes fast food does not mean he does not love good food. If you think fast food cannot be great, try his recipes: they are delicious!
