**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He did not plan to leave his job yet, but he lost it suddenly. He did not get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. He met the head chef of a local hotel, which is one of the best in the country. By selling meat to them, more people learned about him. Now, he also sells meat online. He is happy to be out of the office, but he still works long hours, like before.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Ron told the counselor he did not want to go back to his old job, which surprised the counselor. Most people in their forties need to work for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they did not know anyone. They left their friends, but they still keep in touch, and many friends visit them.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats for private clients in her flat in London. She enjoyed being a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but she worked very long hours. She did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she left. Many people thought she would get bored, but she has not. She has deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier and less stressed now. However, she misses talking to her colleagues. She loves being responsible for her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her fault. When she worked for a company, she cared, but now she cares even more because her name is on the products.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur in London. He started working in finance when he was 22. He liked the excitement but did not find it rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he decided to travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. He knew he needed training to change careers, so he took massage courses. Then, he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets. He feels more in control of his life now and is very happy.

**A Winning Game**
Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are using their childhood game to make money. They live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are playing a game called pichenotte, which their grandfather brought from Canada. The family played this game every weekend and had a lot of fun.
When the family moved to New Mexico, they kept playing pichenotte. Their grandfather made the game board from old wooden boxes. When visitors came, they were curious because no one in the southern USA knew this game.
Three years ago, Dave made a new pichenotte board because the old one was damaged. His family and friends liked it. One night, the brothers took the new board to a sports bar. At first, people thought it was silly, but soon they wanted to play too!
Dave learned that pichenotte has roots in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. The game changed over time and became popular in Canada as pichenotte.
Pichenotte can be played by two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces, called 'pucks'. They flick the pucks across a round board with their fingers. If a puck goes into a small hole, it is worth 20 points. There are also rings worth 15, 10, and 5 points, and eight small posts that make the game harder. A game usually lasts about two minutes.
Seeing how much people liked the game, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. Many people came to buy them, and soon there were pichenotte championships with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup'. The brothers started making boards full-time in their garage. They have made over 450 boards, which are strong and weigh 12 kg. Each board costs $595 and can be bought from their website.
There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows about the game yet, but the brothers hope to make it big. For now, they enjoy playing pichenotte and working on their business.

WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE
When you enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a flat piece of land covered in weeds. For a long time, people thought it was useless. One man, with the help of his wife, worked very hard to change this land into the beautiful place you see today. 
Many tons of soil and clay were moved to make the village. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was done by hand. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. Hundreds of trees and bushes were planted. These plants were chosen carefully because they needed to survive near the sea and strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims had the idea for the Model Village. He made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from stone, concrete, special wood, and plastic to last in all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn about the materials, but soon he became an expert too. 
You will see that all the models are made to the same scale and have many small details. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high quality. The methods used here have been used in other model villages in England and even in some college courses.
All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, which is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest part of the village.
Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models. If you touch them, it can take us a long time to fix them. You can take photos from the paths only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.
To make your visit more fun, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us make the village more interesting. We also want to know if any models need to be fixed.
We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about the Model Village!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the rules that newspaper editors should follow. Sometimes, pop stars take pictures with paparazzi, but this is not common. Usually, it hurts people in the public eye when their private moments are shown on the front page. Very few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to help with these problems. Most of the time, these pictures are not important for the public. For example, how does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help anyone? The actress has complained about such pictures before. Since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take action. It is surprising that the PCC did not start an investigation. 
The PCC should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action against these bad stories? This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers would report this, and it would be on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected and might not be able to hide and take pictures of celebrities anymore.
If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be some problems. How would they decide to start an investigation? Should they talk to the person affected and encourage them to complain? If the person does not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Celebrities might expect the PCC to help them, and they could be upset if it does not happen. The PCC would have a very big job. How could they watch all the newspapers in Britain, including local ones and magazines? 
There is also the problem of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want to go through an investigation? Many people just want to forget about it and move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story that they do not want to become public. In this case, the PCC could seem like the enemy.
One British comedian had problems with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then, and he did not complain later when a photographer took pictures of him and his family on holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would make fun of him and say he was angry, even though they thought it was just a joke. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many college graduates get advice when they start their first job. This article talks about what to think about when you want to find a second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while looking for a permanent one or those who leave a job they do not like after a few weeks. Instead, we will help those who want to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and know what you want to do.
What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to focus on a specific area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you choose, be careful when picking your second job. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, this job should help you grow and give you more responsibilities.
If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.
Juliette Davidson worked for a year after college for three lawyers. It was a good first job because they were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance to move up in that job. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has grown." From the start, her boss wanted to help her develop. Her job title is the same, but her tasks have changed. She now does most of the letters and budgets and answers questions from important people and those wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her special projects and events to organize.

**Confident People: What’s Their Secret?**
Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but many say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy. I thought I would always be shy. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter’s school. I was nervous, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very scared, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that confidence is about believing in yourself. If work is too much, I don’t feel guilty if I leave some tasks for the next day. When I face something hard, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I talk to myself to push those fears away.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to look confident because it is important in my job on TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations. We feel better when we talk to friendly people. My mother once told me that everyone is too busy worrying about themselves to notice me. I remember this advice. I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.
**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work. I have built my confidence over the years. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and people like me, but not everyone does. That’s okay. You need to like yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped me feel better about myself. It is good to set small goals so you can see your progress.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary. I often sat in meetings and did not agree with what was said, but I was too scared to speak. Eventually, I found the courage to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public before and I was very nervous. I told myself that many people speak in public every day, so I could too. I also wrote down some notes to help me. I think everyone feels a little nervous when speaking in public. The secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional. If the line breaks, the finder keeps it. I have many more." He showed me a pile of beautiful kites at his feet. All the kites were 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival.
In the middle of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A line of excited competitors held the lines of their kites and waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys were in the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person had four different kites to show. The kites were judged on how they looked, how well they flew, and how stable they were in the air. 
"Flying kites is not so hard," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Come to my house, and I will show you how to make a kite." I got five invitations that day, and I decided to go to his house. 
At his home, I drank cold tea with milk and ate fish crackers in a big, nice room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help him fix his kite, but I could not. Instead, I drove to the southern part of the state, heading towards Kuala Lumpur, into the mountains with thick rainforests. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was there to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." 
Before I started walking, I should have known that most of the path was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I met Baba, who took care of a kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects under my thin mattress. At night, it was very dark, and I heard many sounds. A waterfall was loud nearby, and many creatures were moving around. 
In the morning, I saw a great view of five green mountain ranges. In the afternoon, it rained. First, there was wind, then lightning hit the trees. I got very wet. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car getting washed away and if I would drown if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the hill. 
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" They were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I will remember it more for the kindness of the people.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which one you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. Melanie, 22, dancer  
"I love shopping! I can't stop spending money! When I have money, I go shopping and feel happy. My boyfriend is the same, so we go shopping together a lot. We are both addicted to shopping!"
B. Brenda, 40, office manager  
"I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I take my son and daughter shopping for clothes, but we all like different things. I don’t spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less."
C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager  
"I only shop for what I need. I don’t like shopping and only go when I have to. When I go, I know what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired."
D. Anita, 35, TV producer  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time. I do have some clothes I bought that I don’t wear, so maybe I make mistakes when I shop."
E. Lizzie, 41, secretary  
"I really don’t like shopping. I can never find what I want, and the shops are too noisy. I am lucky because I get most of my clothes for free. I go food shopping once a week and do it quickly."
F. Lisa, 22, actress  
"I am a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often buy things. I don’t usually go with a plan, but if I see something nice, I buy it."
G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant  
"I am a careful shopper. I like to shop, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I feel worse because I spend too much money."
H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker  
"I love shopping, but I only go on certain days and never on Saturdays because it is too busy. I am a careful shopper. I have an idea of what I want and I look in different shops to find the best price. It takes me a long time!"
I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager  
"I don’t like shopping. I work in the city, so shopping is not fun for me anymore. When I have to shop, I don’t try on clothes because it is too much work. Sometimes the clothes don’t fit, but I don’t care too much. I would rather make mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping."

**Gallery News**

During the Easter holidays, children can join a fun quiz about surprises. You can get free quiz sheets at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will find 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz sheets are available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.
**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings like this in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is normal for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has bought works by three Spanish painters: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. They are the main focus of the exhibition. Two other artists, Ramon (Francisco's brother) and Antonio Gonzalez, are also included. There are two Italian artists, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, who worked in Spain during this time. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. A group of children aged ten to fifteen spend their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food.
Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together." 
Flora is twelve years old. She has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby instead of staying home on weekends. At first, I was not very excited, but now I am really happy I came."
Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, but the kitchen can be messy when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. STAMP COLLECTING - A FUN HOBBY
Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting. It is a fun hobby that can last a long time. Starting your collection is easy because you can find stamps everywhere. You can get stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends.
When you start collecting stamps seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways:

When you join, the Club will send you a Starter Pack for free. This pack has 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You will also get a 4-page guide with tips on how to collect stamps and addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Why not start this fun adventure? You will enjoy looking at the different stamps in your collection and searching for new ones. MONEY
What is money? Money can be a pound, a dollar, or a franc. It is like a gram or a kilometre, but you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that does not cost much to make.
A long time ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, traded corn for honey with Mr. Hive. They both had something the other wanted. 
Over time, many societies created their own types of money, called currencies. Now, most people use a national currency to buy and sell things.

**Write a Winning Story!**
You can win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other people will win £100. We need people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a television reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories.
Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here are some tips to help you:
1. **Write About What You Know**: Write about things you understand. Last year, many stories were about love, family, and problems with friends. Make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read more.
2. **Get Your Facts Right**: If you describe a place or explain something, make sure it is correct. Don’t write about things you are not sure about.
3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A bad ending can ruin a good story.
4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using good words to describe them.
Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and on one side of the paper only. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions.
You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not have been printed or recorded anywhere in the world. 
You need to pay a fee of £5 to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. 
The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.

THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST
Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist in history books. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he made sure she got a good education. This was special because most women at that time could not study much.
Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. After that, she went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have her books, but we know she wrote important works about math. Hypatia also liked technology and invented tools to help her work.
At that time, many leaders were afraid of science, and people who worked in science were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It is a great place for a family day out. There are many areas for picnics, boating lakes, and a nature reserve. There is also a miniature railway.

**Grass**
Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 types of grass, and they grow in every part of the earth. Grass can live in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. 
Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass to survive. 
Grass grows back very quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food for them.

Kal Kaur Rai is a young woman who loves fashion. She just won the title of Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she liked to draw clothes and create designs. She never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her job. She thought they wanted her to have a different job, so she studied management at university.
After university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She went to many events but could not buy the expensive clothes she wanted. So, she started making skirts and tops for herself. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. 
Kal found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs. The clothes were very popular, and none of them came back. This made her feel confident, so she decided to leave her advertising job. She took a loan of £20,000 to start her own women’s clothing brand. 
Kal's parents were happy for her and said they would support her. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business makes more than £500,000. Her designs are in fashion magazines, and she creates clothes for pop stars. Winning this award has made her well-known. 
Kal feels very lucky. She says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Sunningdale Hotel**
The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has given great service to many people from all over the world. In the last 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here.
The hotel is on a main road that goes to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes to get to the center by bus. Many buses stop outside the hotel, but guests should not take the blue buses with the sign "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. There is also an underground station less than 100 meters away.
The hotel has 200 comfortable single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the hall. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. Guests can park their cars in the hotel parking area. Daily newspapers are free, and guests can buy stamps at the office.
Guests who stay for a long time must pay for their room every week in advance. They need to tell the hotel one week before they leave. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first.
Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. If guests are studying or working late, they can ask for dinner until 11 pm by writing their name on a list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 choices for breakfast and dinner.
No animals or fires are allowed in the hotel. Guests should be quiet, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If guests arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main train station.

**Tom Cruise**
Tom Cruise is a very successful actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked to be in school plays.
After finishing high school, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. 
Ten years later, Tom became very successful. He was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood and made millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and has many fans all over the world.

LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN?
Bo the cat wanted to explore a furniture van. She had a big adventure! The driver found her after he drove for more than 500 kilometres. It was a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. The driver gave Bo some milk and tried to find her owner. He called his last customers, but they did not lose a cat.
It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner was also looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that delivered to a neighbor. He remembered the name of the company and called them. Soon, Bo was back home safely.

**The Ghan Train**
Mark Ottaway took a train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the cooler south. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late.
In the 1920s, there was a plan to connect Darwin and Adelaide by train. They built a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but floods often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished a few months before Mark's trip. The train can go fast, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday.
The Ghan was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia by train would save time and money. The Ghan is said to be the world's first north-south train.
When Mark waited to get on the Ghan, he saw that everyone was excited for the trip. Many older Australians were especially eager to board. The first stop was Katherine, where the train stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip. Mark stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where he went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so they just walked around it and watched the sunset.
From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with cattle. But on the third day, they reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. Mark's journey was over. Even if the train did not meet all the promises, it took him to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**
Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is very cold there because it is in the north. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis.
It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We climbed up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters high, which is probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the "Carries." These are big bowls in the mountain, halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow is very hard, like ice. 
Even though some people in my group were very experienced, we took a lot of safety equipment. This included lights to get help, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started climbing. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always hard.
The path went up, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest person in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but when I did, they started climbing again. I promised myself to train better before my next climb.
After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge. It is only 1.5 meters wide, and the mountain drops down hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. But we were not lucky; a mist came down.
Getting back down to camp can be just as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn can lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was happy we took turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I enjoyed the climb when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top!

**Anna's New School**
This week is very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a great place. The builders used wood to make it, like our old school, but this school is also good for the environment. It took many months to build, and we watched it being built. It was exciting to see the builders work, but it also meant some nice land was gone. The building machines were very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of the rain. We thought the building would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms. They are much bigger than the old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We are excited to use them when our new sports field is ready.
When you enter the school, you will notice there are no heaters! The heat comes from us inside the school - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps the heat and sound inside, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!
Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on it! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went with our teacher to see it yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that we can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.
Even though we are using the school now, some parts are still being finished. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

A month ago, I did not know that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and having fun. Now, I looked down at the river far below me and understood why people like rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place where we stayed was not great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.
On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon. Sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we were not sure how.
Half of us went caving in the morning, while the others went rock-climbing. Then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**
On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I lost it, it was too late. I didn’t know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I felt very worried. I stood by the road and cried.
A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they found my handbag and would bring it back to me.
I got my handbag back, and everything was inside and untouched. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. I really appreciate their kindness and honesty.
Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**
Sharks are some of the most scary animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food underwater because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat.
Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks must swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they do not sleep much. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is helpful for scientists who need to study sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting animals.

Joining the Kirov Ballet
My name is Nathalie. Last year, I was one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak in Russian, and then they started talking to me in English, so we could understand each other.
Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers better. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mom stayed with me. When she left, I felt a little sad. One night, I called her because I felt lonely.
The ballet classes in Russia are much harder than in England. I eat a lot to have enough energy. This helps me do well in class. In the evenings, I watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish.
Now that I feel settled, I really like it here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the Russians said it was warm for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.
Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.

**THE ICEHOTEL**
For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in winter, there were only a few people living there, and they enjoyed the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people decided that the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. 
In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, on the frozen Torne River. This building was called Arctic Hall, and many visitors came to see it. One night, some guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel started.
Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world. When winter starts, a team of builders, architects, and artists from many countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As they finish one part, it opens for visitors and guests, while they continue to build other parts. The first part is ready in December, and each week after that, a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully completed. 
The ICEHOTEL is built outside, using snow and ice, so the finishing date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, even if it is very cold outside. 
Guests get warm winter clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves included in their stay. It is also a good idea to bring sweaters, scarves, and many warm socks. Guests should wear shoes that are a bit bigger than normal to fit the thick socks. 
If you want to visit the hotel, you can buy warm clothes and other things on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be in your room when you arrive. 
The hotel is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange a bus to take you from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Shopping for Furniture**
A report by Dave Worthington
Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday but had to close very quickly. Up to 6,000 people came to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). 
The shop's normal hours are 9 am to 9 pm every day. Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours at first. But it had to close within half an hour of opening. 
A police officer said that many people were expected, but they were not patient. The shop became very full, and the managers decided to close the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could go in. They did not want to wait quietly in line. 
There was also a long line of cars trying to get to the parking lot. Many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.
One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I didn’t have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained what was happening. They had to close because it was not safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don’t want to wait in line again."

**Membership**
The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is now one of the most active art groups in Britain.
**Society Magazines**
We make several magazines, including the popular *Short Story Review*. This magazine has short stories from famous British writers and gives new writers a chance to share their work. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can read some articles from recent issues on our website.
**National Short Story Competition**
We have the National Short Story Competition, which is the biggest competition for short stories. Anyone aged 18 and older can enter. You can write about any topic. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society can enter for free, but non-members pay £5. The competition is open from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be in the Society's annual book. The winner will get a contract to publish their own book of short stories.
**Education**
For almost thirty years, the Society has worked with schools to help children and teachers with writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 for writers aged 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.
**The Writers' Cafe**
The Writers' Cafe is a nice place for members to relax. It has vegetarian food, good coffee, and cold drinks. You can read the Society's magazines there. The Cafe also has monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the center of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm on weekdays and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturdays. Members get discounts on some products and events.
